#Text=Produced by An Anonymous Volunteer and David Widger KIDNAPPED BEING MEMOIRS OF THE ADVENTURES OF DAVID BALFOUR IN THE YEAR 1751 HOW HE WAS KIDNAPPED AND CAST AWAY ; HIS SUFFERINGS IN A DESERT ISLE ; HIS JOURNEY IN THE WILD HIGHLANDS ; HIS ACQUAINTANCE WITH ALAN BRECK STEWART AND OTHER NOTORIOUS HIGHLAND JACOBITES ; WITH ALL THAT HE SUFFERED AT THE HANDS OF HIS UNCLE , EBENEZER BALFOUR OF SHAWS , FALSELY SO CALLED WRITTEN BY HIMSELF AND NOW SET FORTH BY ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON WITH A PREFACE BY MRS .
#Text=STEVENSON PREFACE TO THE BIOGRAPHICAL EDITION While my husband and Mr. Henley were engaged in writing plays in Bournemouth they made a number of titles , hoping to use them in the future .
#Text=Dramatic composition was not what my husband preferred , but the torrent of Mr. Henley 's enthusiasm swept him off his feet .

#Text=However , after several plays had been finished , and his health seriously impaired by his endeavours to keep up with Mr. Henley , play writing was abandoned forever , and my husband returned to his legitimate vocation .

#Text=Having added one of the titles , The Hanging Judge , to the list of projected plays , now thrown aside , and emboldened by my husband 's offer to give me any help needed , I concluded to try and write it myself .

#Text=As I wanted a trial scene in the Old Bailey , I chose the period of 1700 for my purpose ; but being shamefully ignorant of my subject , and my husband confessing to little more knowledge than I possessed , a London bookseller was commissioned to send us everything he could procure bearing on Old Bailey trials .

#Text=A great package came in response to our order , and very soon we were both absorbed , not so much in the trials as in following the brilliant career of a Mr. Garrow , who appeared as counsel in many of the cases .

#Text=We sent for more books , and yet more , still intent on Mr. Garrow , whose subtle cross-examination of witnesses and masterly , if sometimes startling , methods of arriving at the truth seemed more thrilling to us than any novel .

#Text=Occasionally other trials than those of the Old Bailey would be included in the package of books we received from London ; among these my husband found and read with avidity: -- THE TRIAL OF JAMES STEWART in Aucharn in Duror of Appin FOR THE Murder of COLIN CAMPBELL of Glenure , Efq ; Factor for His Majefty on the forfeited Estate of Ardfhiel .
#Text=My husband was always interested in this period of his country 's history , and had already the intention of writing a story that should turn on the Appin murder .

#Text=The tale was to be of a boy , David Balfour , supposed to belong to my husband 's own family , who should travel in Scotland as though it were a foreign country , meeting with various adventures and misadventures by the way .
#Text=From the trial of James Stewart my husband gleaned much valuable material for his novel , the most important being the character of Alan Breck .
#Text=Aside from having described him as smallish in stature , my husband seems to have taken Alan Breck 's personal appearance , even to his clothing , from the book .

#Text=A letter from James Stewart to Mr. John Macfarlane , introduced as evidence in the trial , says : There is one Alan Stewart , a distant friend of the late Ardshiel 's , who is in the French service , and came over in March last , as he said to some , in order to settle at home ; to others , that he was to go soon back ; and was , as I hear , the day that the murder was committed , seen not far from the place where it happened , and is not now to be seen ; by which it is believed he was the actor .
#Text=He is a desperate foolish fellow ; and if he is guilty , came to the country for that very purpose .
#Text=He is a tall , pock-pitted lad , very black hair , and wore a blue coat and metal buttons , an old red vest , and breeches of the same colour .

#Text=A second witness testified to having seen him wearing a blue coat with silver buttons , a red waistcoat , black shag breeches , tartan hose , and a feathered hat , with a big coat , dun coloured , a costume referred to by one of the counsel as French cloathes which were remarkable .
#Text=There are many incidents given in the trial that point to Alan 's fiery spirit and Highland quickness to take offence .
#Text=One witness declared also That the said Alan Breck threatened that he would challenge Ballieveolan and his sons to fight because of his removing the declarant last year from Glenduror .

#Text=On another page : Duncan Campbell , change-keeper at Annat , aged thirty-five years , married , witness cited , sworn , purged and examined ut supra , depones , That , in the month of April last , the deponent met with Alan Breck Stewart , with whom he was not acquainted , and John Stewart , in Auchnacoan , in the house of the walk miller of Auchofragan , and went on with them to the house : Alan Breck Stewart said , that he hated all the name of Campbell ; and the deponent said , he had no reason for doing so : But Alan said , he had very good reason for it : that thereafter they left that house ; and , after drinking a dram at another house , came to the deponent 's house , where they went in , and drunk some drams , and Alan Breck renewed the former Conversation ; and the deponent , making the same answer , Alan said , that , if the deponent had any respect for his friends , he would tell them , that if they offered to turn out the possessors of Ardshiel 's estate , he would make black cocks of them , before they entered into possession by which the deponent understood shooting them , it being a common phrase in the country .

#Text=Some time after the publication of Kidnapped we stopped for a short while in the Appin country , where we were surprised and interested to discover that the feeling concerning the murder of Glenure ( the Red Fox , also called Colin Roy ) was almost as keen as though the tragedy had taken place the day before .
#Text=For several years my husband received letters of expostulation or commendation from members of the Campbell and Stewart clans .

#Text=I have in my possession a paper , yellow with age , that was sent soon after the novel appeared , containing The Pedigree of the Family of Appine , wherein it is said that Alan 3rd Baron of Appine was not killed at Flowdoun , tho there , but lived to a great old age .
#Text=He married Cameron Daughter to Ewen Cameron of Lochiel .
#Text=Following this is a paragraph stating that John Stewart 1st of Ardsheall of his descendants Alan Breck had better be omitted .
#Text=Duncan Baan Stewart in Achindarroch his father was a Bastard .
#Text=One day , while my husband was busily at work , I sat beside him reading an old cookery book called The Compleat Housewife : or Accomplish 'd Gentlewoman 's Companion .

#Text=In the midst of receipts for Rabbits , and Chickens mumbled , Pickled Samphire , Skirret Pye , Baked Tansy , and other forgotten delicacies , there were directions for the preparation of several lotions for the preservation of beauty .
#Text=One of these was so charming that I interrupted my husband to read it aloud .
#Text=Just what I wanted !
#Text=he exclaimed ; and the receipt for the Lily of the Valley Water was instantly incorporated into Kidnapped .

#Text=F. V. DE G. S. DEDICATION MY DEAR CHARLES BAXTER : If you ever read this tale , you will likely ask yourself more questions than I should care to answer : as for instance how the Appin murder has come to fall in the year 1751 , how the Torran rocks have crept so near to Earraid , or why the printed trial is silent as to all that touches David Balfour .
#Text=These are nuts beyond my ability to crack .
#Text=But if you tried me on the point of Alan 's guilt or innocence , I think I could defend the reading of the text .
#Text=To this day you will find the tradition of Appin clear in Alan 's favour .
#Text=If you inquire , you may even hear that the descendants of the other man who fired the shot are in the country to this day .
#Text=But that other man 's name , inquire as you please , you shall not hear ; for the Highlander values a secret for itself and for the congenial exercise of keeping it .
#Text=I might go on for long to justify one point and own another indefensible ; it is more honest to confess at once how little I am touched by the desire of accuracy .

#Text=This is no furniture for the scholar 's library , but a book for the winter evening school-room when the tasks are over and the hour for bed draws near ; and honest Alan , who was a grim old fire-eater in his day has in this new avatar no more desperate purpose than to steal some young gentleman 's attention from his Ovid , carry him awhile into the Highlands and the last century , and pack him to bed with some engaging images to mingle with his dreams .
#Text=As for you , my dear Charles , I do not even ask you to like this tale .

#Text=But perhaps when he is older , your son will ; he may then be pleased to find his father 's name on the fly-leaf ; and in the meanwhile it pleases me to set it there , in memory of many days that were happy and some ( now perhaps as pleasant to remember ) that were sad .

#Text=If it is strange for me to look back from a distance both in time and space on these bygone adventures of our youth , it must be stranger for you who tread the same streets--who may to-morrow open the door of the old Speculative , where we begin to rank with Scott and Robert Emmet and the beloved and inglorious Macbean--or may pass the corner of the close where that great society , the L. J. R. , held its meetings and drank its beer , sitting in the seats of Burns and his companions .
#Text=I think I see you , moving there by plain daylight , beholding with your natural eyes those places that have now become for your companion a part of the scenery of dreams .
#Text=How , in the intervals of present business , the past must echo in your memory !
#Text=Let it not echo often without some kind thoughts of your friend , R.L.S. SKERRYVORE , BOURNEMOUTH .

#Text=CHAPTER I I SET OFF UPON MY JOURNEY TO THE HOUSE OF SHAWS I will begin the story of my adventures with a certain morning early in the month of June , the year of grace 1751 , when I took the key for the last time out of the door of my father 's house .

#Text=The sun began to shine upon the summit of the hills as I went down the road ; and by the time I had got the key into the keyhole and had just turned it , when all upon a sudden , without sound of wind or thunder , the whole sky lighted up with wild fire and went black again .
#Text=I had to put my hand over my eyes to get back to the colour of the darkness ; and indeed I was already half blinded when I stepped into the tower .

#Text=It was so dark inside , it seemed a body could scarce breathe ; but I pushed out with foot and hand , and presently struck the wall with the one , and the lowermost round of the stair with the other .
#Text=The wall , by the touch , was of fine hewn stone ; the steps too , though somewhat steep and narrow , were of polished masonwork , and regular and solid underfoot .
#Text=Minding my uncle 's word about the bannisters , I kept close to the tower side , and felt my way in the pitch darkness with a beating heart .
#Text=The house of Shaws stood some five full storeys high , not counting lofts .

#Text=Well , as I advanced , it seemed to me the stair grew airier and a thought more lightsome ; and I was wondering what might be the cause of this change , when a second blink of the summer lightning came and went .
#Text=If I did not cry out , it was because fear had me by the throat ; and if I did not fall , it was more by Heaven 's mercy than my own strength .

#Text=It was not only that the flash shone in on every side through breaches in the wall , so that I seemed to be clambering aloft upon an open scaffold , but the same passing brightness showed me the steps were of unequal length , and that one of my feet rested that moment within two inches of the well .
#Text=This was the grand stair !
#Text=I thought ; and with the thought , a gust of a kind of angry courage came into my heart .
#Text=My uncle had sent me here , certainly to run great risks , perhaps to die .

#Text=I swore I would settle that perhaps , if I should break my neck for it ; got me down upon my hands and knees ; and as slowly as a snail , feeling before me every inch , and testing the solidity of every stone , I continued to ascend the stair .

#Text=The darkness , by contrast with the flash , appeared to have redoubled ; nor was that all , for my ears were now troubled and my mind confounded by a great stir of bats in the top part of the tower , and the foul beasts , flying downwards , sometimes beat about my face and body .
#Text=The tower , I should have said , was square ; and in every corner the step was made of a great stone of a different shape to join the flights .
#Text=Well , I had come close to one of these turns , when , feeling forward as usual , my hand slipped upon an edge and found nothing but emptiness beyond it .

#Text=The stair had been carried no higher ; to set a stranger mounting it in the darkness was to send him straight to his death ; and ( although , thanks to the lightning and my own precautions , I was safe enough ) the mere thought of the peril in which I might have stood , and the dreadful height I might have fallen from , brought out the sweat upon my body and relaxed my joints .
#Text=But I knew what I wanted now , and turned and groped my way down again , with a wonderful anger in my heart .
#Text=About half-way down , the wind sprang up in a clap and shook the tower , and died again ; the rain followed ; and before I had reached the ground level it fell in buckets .
#Text=I put out my head into the storm , and looked along towards the kitchen .

#Text=The door , which I had shut behind me when I left , now stood open , and shed a little glimmer of light ; and I thought I could see a figure standing in the rain , quite still , like a man hearkening .
#Text=And then there came a blinding flash , which showed me my uncle plainly , just where I had fancied him to stand ; and hard upon the heels of it , a great tow-row of thunder .
#Text=Now , whether my uncle thought the crash to be the sound of my fall , or whether he heard in it God 's voice denouncing murder , I will leave you to guess .
#Text=Certain it is , at least , that he was seized on by a kind of panic fear , and that he ran into the house and left the door open behind him .
#Text=I followed as softly as I could , and , coming unheard into the kitchen , stood and watched him .
#Text=He had found time to open the corner cupboard and bring out a great case bottle of aqua vitae , and now sat with his back towards me at the table .
#Text=Ever and again he would be seized with a fit of deadly shuddering and groan aloud , and carrying the bottle to his lips , drink down the raw spirits by the mouthful .
#Text=I stepped forward , came close behind him where he sat , and suddenly clapping my two hands down upon his shoulders--Ah !
#Text=cried I. My uncle gave a kind of broken cry like a sheep 's bleat , flung up his arms , and tumbled to the floor like a dead man .
#Text=I was somewhat shocked at this ; but I had myself to look to first of all , and did not hesitate to let him lie as he had fallen .
#Text=The keys were hanging in the cupboard ; and it was my design to furnish myself with arms before my uncle should come again to his senses and the power of devising evil .

#Text=In the cupboard were a few bottles , some apparently of medicine ; a great many bills and other papers , which I should willingly enough have rummaged , had I had the time ; and a few necessaries that were nothing to my purpose .
#Text=Thence I turned to the chests .

#Text=The first was full of meal ; the second of moneybags and papers tied into sheaves ; in the third , with many other things ( and these for the most part clothes ) I found a rusty , ugly-looking Highland dirk without the scabbard .
#Text=This , then , I concealed inside my waistcoat , and turned to my uncle .
#Text=He lay as he had fallen , all huddled , with one knee up and one arm sprawling abroad ; his face had a strange colour of blue , and he seemed to have ceased breathing .
#Text=Fear came on me that he was dead ; then I got water and dashed it in his face ; and with that he seemed to come a little to himself , working his mouth and fluttering his eyelids .
#Text=At last he looked up and saw me , and there came into his eyes a terror that was not of this world .
#Text=Come , come , said I ; sit up .
#Text=Are ye alive ?
#Text=he sobbed .
#Text=O man , are ye alive ?
#Text=That am I , said I. Small thanks to you !
#Text=He had begun to seek for his breath with deep sighs .
#Text=The blue phial , said he--in the aumry--the blue phial .
#Text=His breath came slower still .
#Text=I ran to the cupboard , and , sure enough , found there a blue phial of medicine , with the dose written on it on a paper , and this I administered to him with what speed I might .
#Text=It 's the trouble , said he , reviving a little ; I have a trouble , Davie .
#Text=It 's the heart .
#Text=I set him on a chair and looked at him .

#Text=It is true I felt some pity for a man that looked so sick , but I was full besides of righteous anger ; and I numbered over before him the points on which I wanted explanation : why he lied to me at every word ; why he feared that I should leave him ; why he disliked it to be hinted that he and my father were twins--Is that because it is true ?
#Text=I asked ; why he had given me money to which I was convinced I had no claim ; and , last of all , why he had tried to kill me .
#Text=He heard me all through in silence ; and then , in a broken voice , begged me to let him go to bed .
#Text=I 'll tell ye the morn , he said ; as sure as death I will .
#Text=And so weak was he that I could do nothing but consent .

#Text=I locked him into his room , however , and pocketed the key , and then returning to the kitchen , made up such a blaze as had not shone there for many a long year , and wrapping myself in my plaid , lay down upon the chests and fell asleep .
#Text=CHAPTER V I GO TO THE QUEEN 'S FERRY Much rain fell in the night ; and the next morning there blew a bitter wintry wind out of the north-west , driving scattered clouds .
#Text=For all that , and before the sun began to peep or the last of the stars had vanished , I made my way to the side of the burn , and had a plunge in a deep whirling pool .
#Text=All aglow from my bath , I sat down once more beside the fire , which I replenished , and began gravely to consider my position .
#Text=There was now no doubt about my uncle 's enmity ; there was no doubt I carried my life in my hand , and he would leave no stone unturned that he might compass my destruction .
#Text=But I was young and spirited , and like most lads that have been country-bred , I had a great opinion of my shrewdness .

#Text=I had come to his door no better than a beggar and little more than a child ; he had met me with treachery and violence ; it would be a fine consummation to take the upper hand , and drive him like a herd of sheep .
#Text=I sat there nursing my knee and smiling at the fire ; and I saw myself in fancy smell out his secrets one after another , and grow to be that man 's king and ruler .

#Text=The warlock of Essendean , they say , had made a mirror in which men could read the future ; it must have been of other stuff than burning coal ; for in all the shapes and pictures that I sat and gazed at , there was never a ship , never a seaman with a hairy cap , never a big bludgeon for my silly head , or the least sign of all those tribulations that were ripe to fall on me .
#Text=Presently , all swollen with conceit , I went up-stairs and gave my prisoner his liberty .
#Text=He gave me good-morning civilly ; and I gave the same to him , smiling down upon him , from the heights of my sufficiency .
#Text=Soon we were set to breakfast , as it might have been the day before .
#Text=Well , sir , said I , with a jeering tone , have you nothing more to say to me ?
#Text=And then , as he made no articulate reply , It will be time , I think , to understand each other , I continued .
#Text=You took me for a country Johnnie Raw , with no more mother-wit or courage than a porridge-stick .
#Text=I took you for a good man , or no worse than others at the least .
#Text=It seems we were both wrong .

#Text=What cause you have to fear me , to cheat me , and to attempt my life -- He murmured something about a jest , and that he liked a bit of fun ; and then , seeing me smile , changed his tone , and assured me he would make all clear as soon as we had breakfasted .
#Text=I saw by his face that he had no lie ready for me , though he was hard at work preparing one ; and I think I was about to tell him so , when we were interrupted by a knocking at the door .
#Text=Bidding my uncle sit where he was , I went to open it , and found on the doorstep a half-grown boy in sea-clothes .

#Text=He had no sooner seen me than he began to dance some steps of the sea-hornpipe ( which I had never before heard of far less seen ) , snapping his fingers in the air and footing it right cleverly .
#Text=For all that , he was blue with the cold ; and there was something in his face , a look between tears and laughter , that was highly pathetic and consisted ill with this gaiety of manner .
#Text=What cheer , mate ?
#Text=says he , with a cracked voice .
#Text=I asked him soberly to name his pleasure .
#Text=O , pleasure !
#Text=says he ; and then began to sing : For it 's my delight , of a shiny night , In the season of the year .
#Text=Well , said I , if you have no business at all , I will even be so unmannerly as to shut you out .
#Text=Stay , brother !
#Text=he cried .
#Text=Have you no fun about you ?
#Text=or do you want to get me thrashed ?
#Text=I 've brought a letter from old Heasyoasy to Mr. Belflower .
#Text=He showed me a letter as he spoke .
#Text=And I say , mate , he added , I 'm mortal hungry .
#Text=Well , said I , come into the house , and you shall have a bite if I go empty for it .

#Text=With that I brought him in and set him down to my own place , where he fell-to greedily on the remains of breakfast , winking to me between whiles , and making many faces , which I think the poor soul considered manly .
#Text=Meanwhile , my uncle had read the letter and sat thinking ; then , suddenly , he got to his feet with a great air of liveliness , and pulled me apart into the farthest corner of the room .
#Text=Read that , said he , and put the letter in my hand .
#Text=Here it is , lying before me as I write : The Hawes Inn , at the Queen 's Ferry .
#Text=Sir lie here with my hawser up and down , and send my cabin-boy to informe .
#Text=If you have any further commands for over-seas , to-day will be the last occasion , as the wind will serve us well out of the firth .
#Text=I will not seek to deny that I have had crosses with your Mr. Rankeillor ; of which , if not speedily redd up , you may looke to see some losses follow .
#Text=I have drawn a bill upon you , as per margin , and am , sir , your most obedt .
#Text=, humble servant , ELIAS HOSEASON .
#Text=Agent .
#Text=You see , Davie , resumed my uncle , as soon as he saw that I had done , I have a venture with this man Hoseason , the captain of a trading brig , the Covenant , of Dysart .

#Text=Now , if you and me was to walk over with yon lad , I could see the captain at the Hawes , or maybe on board the Covenant if there was papers to be signed ; and so far from a loss of time , we can jog on to the lawyer , Mr. Rankeillor 's .
#Text=After a'that 's come and gone , ye would be to believe me upon my naked word ; but ye 'll believe Rankeillor .
#Text=He 's factor to half the gentry in these parts ; an auld man , forby : highly respeckit , and he kenned your father .
#Text=Unwilling .
#Text=I stood awhile and thought .
#Text=I was going to some place of shipping , which was doubtless populous , and where my uncle durst attempt no violence , and , indeed , even the society of the cabin-boy so far protected me .

#Text=Once there , I believed I could force on the visit to the lawyer , even if my uncle were now insincere in proposing it ; and , perhaps , in the bottom of my heart , I wished a nearer view of the sea and ships .

#Text=You are to remember I had lived all my life in the inland hills , and just two days before had my first sight of the firth lying like a blue floor , and the sailed ships moving on the face of it , no bigger than toys .
#Text=One thing with another , I made up my mind .
#Text=Very well , says I , let us go to the Ferry .
#Text=My uncle got into his hat and coat , and buckled an old rusty cutlass on ; and then we trod the fire out , locked the door , and set forth upon our walk .
#Text=The wind , being in that cold quarter the north-west , blew nearly in our faces as we went .

#Text=It was the month of June ; the grass was all white with daisies , and the trees with blossom ; but , to judge by our blue nails and aching wrists , the time might have been winter and the whiteness a December frost .
#Text=Uncle Ebenezer trudged in the ditch , jogging from side to side like an old ploughman coming home from work .
#Text=He never said a word the whole way ; and I was thrown for talk on the cabin-boy .
#Text=He told me his name was Ransome , and that he had followed the sea since he was nine , but could not say how old he was , as he had lost his reckoning .

#Text=He showed me tattoo marks , baring his breast in the teeth of the wind and in spite of my remonstrances , for I thought it was enough to kill him ; he swore horribly whenever he remembered , but more like a silly schoolboy than a man ; and boasted of many wild and bad things that he had done : stealthy thefts , false accusations , ay , and even murder ; but all with such a dearth of likelihood in the details , and such a weak and crazy swagger in the delivery , as disposed me rather to pity than to believe him .
#Text=I asked him of the brig ( which he declared was the finest ship that sailed ) and of Captain Hoseason , in whose praises he was equally loud .

#Text=Heasyoasy ( for so he still named the skipper ) was a man , by his account , that minded for nothing either in heaven or earth ; one that , as people said , would crack on all sail into the day of judgment ; rough , fierce , unscrupulous , and brutal ; and all this my poor cabin-boy had taught himself to admire as something seamanlike and manly .
#Text=He would only admit one flaw in his idol .
#Text=He ai n't no seaman , he admitted .
#Text=That 's Mr. Shuan that navigates the brig ; he 's the finest seaman in the trade , only for drink ; and I tell you I believe it !
#Text=Why , look'ere ; and turning down his stocking he showed me a great , raw , red wound that made my blood run cold .
#Text=He done that--Mr .
#Text=Shuan done it , he said , with an air of pride .
#Text=What !
#Text=I cried , do you take such savage usage at his hands ?
#Text=Why , you are no slave , to be so handled !
#Text=No , said the poor moon-calf , changing his tune at once , and so he 'll find .
#Text=See'ere ; and he showed me a great case-knife , which he told me was stolen .
#Text=O , says he , let me see him try ; I dare him to ; I 'll do for him !
#Text=O , he ai n't the first !
#Text=And he confirmed it with a poor , silly , ugly oath .

#Text=I have never felt such pity for any one in this wide world as I felt for that half-witted creature , and it began to come over me that the brig Covenant ( for all her pious name ) was little better than a hell upon the seas .
#Text=Have you no friends ?
#Text=said I. He said he had a father in some English seaport , I forget which .
#Text=He was a fine man , too , he said , but he 's dead .
#Text=In Heaven 's name , cried I , can you find no reputable life on shore ?
#Text=O , no , says he , winking and looking very sly , they would put me to a trade .
#Text=I know a trick worth two of that , I do !

#Text=I asked him what trade could be so dreadful as the one he followed , where he ran the continual peril of his life , not alone from wind and sea , but by the horrid cruelty of those who were his masters .

#Text=He said it was very true ; and then began to praise the life , and tell what a pleasure it was to get on shore with money in his pocket , and spend it like a man , and buy apples , and swagger , and surprise what he called stick-in-the-mud boys .
#Text=And then it 's not all as bad as that , says he ; there 's worse off than me : there 's the twenty-pounders .
#Text=O , laws !
#Text=you should see them taking on .

#Text=Why , I 've seen a man as old as you , I dessay--(to him I seemed old)--ah , and he had a beard , too--well , and as soon as we cleared out of the river , and he had the drug out of his head--my !
#Text=how he cried and carried on !
#Text=I made a fine fool of him , I tell you !
#Text=And then there 's little uns , too : oh , little by me !
#Text=I tell you , I keep them in order .
#Text=When we carry little uns , I have a rope 's end of my own to wollop 'em .

#Text=And so he ran on , until it came in on me what he meant by twenty-pounders were those unhappy criminals who were sent over-seas to slavery in North America , or the still more unhappy innocents who were kidnapped or trepanned ( as the word went ) for private interest or vengeance .
#Text=Just then we came to the top of the hill , and looked down on the Ferry and the Hope .

#Text=The Firth of Forth ( as is very well known ) narrows at this point to the width of a good-sized river , which makes a convenient ferry going north , and turns the upper reach into a landlocked haven for all manner of ships .

#Text=Right in the midst of the narrows lies an islet with some ruins ; on the south shore they have built a pier for the service of the Ferry ; and at the end of the pier , on the other side of the road , and backed against a pretty garden of holly-trees and hawthorns , I could see the building which they called the Hawes Inn .
#Text=The town of Queensferry lies farther west , and the neighbourhood of the inn looked pretty lonely at that time of day , for the boat had just gone north with passengers .

#Text=A skiff , however , lay beside the pier , with some seamen sleeping on the thwarts ; this , as Ransome told me , was the brig 's boat waiting for the captain ; and about half a mile off , and all alone in the anchorage , he showed me the Covenant herself .
#Text=There was a sea-going bustle on board ; yards were swinging into place ; and as the wind blew from that quarter , I could hear the song of the sailors as they pulled upon the ropes .
#Text=After all I had listened to upon the way , I looked at that ship with an extreme abhorrence ; and from the bottom of my heart I pitied all poor souls that were condemned to sail in her .
#Text=We had all three pulled up on the brow of the hill ; and now I marched across the road and addressed my uncle .
#Text=I think it right to tell you , sir , says I , there 's nothing that will bring me on board that Covenant .
#Text=He seemed to waken from a dream .
#Text=Eh ?
#Text=he said .
#Text=What 's that ?
#Text=I told him over again .
#Text=Well , well , he said , we 'll have to please ye , I suppose .
#Text=But what are we standing here for ?
#Text=It 's perishing cold ; and if I 'm no mistaken , they 're busking the Covenant for sea .
#Text=CHAPTER VI WHAT BEFELL AT THE QUEEN 'S FERRY As soon as we came to the inn , Ransome led us up the stair to a small room , with a bed in it , and heated like an oven by a great fire of coal .
#Text=At a table hard by the chimney , a tall , dark , sober-looking man sat writing .
#Text=In spite of the heat of the room , he wore a thick sea-jacket , buttoned to the neck , and a tall hairy cap drawn down over his ears ; yet tomorrow .

#Text=All these pleasant things , and a thousand others , crowded into my mind , as I sat staring before me out of the inn window , and paying no heed to what I saw ; only I remember that my eye lighted on Captain Hoseason down on the pier among his seamen , and speaking with some authority .

#Text=And presently he came marching back towards the house , with no mark of a sailor 's clumsiness , but carrying his fine , tall figure with a manly bearing , and still with the same sober , grave expression on his face .
#Text=I wondered if it was possible that Ransome 's stories could be true , and half disbelieved them ; they fitted so ill with the man 's looks .

#Text=But indeed , he was neither so good as I supposed him , nor quite so bad as Ransome did ; for , in fact , he was two men , and left the better one behind as soon as he set foot on board his vessel .
#Text=The next thing , I heard my uncle calling me , and found the pair in the road together .
#Text=It was the captain who addressed me , and that with an air ( very flattering to a young lad ) of grave equality .
#Text=Sir , said he , Mr. Balfour tells me great things of you ; and for my own part , I like your looks .
#Text=I wish I was for longer here , that we might make the better friends ; but we 'll make the most of what we have .
#Text=Ye shall come on board my brig for half an hour , till the ebb sets , and drink a bowl with me .
#Text=Now , I longed to see the inside of a ship more than words can tell ; but I was not going to put myself in jeopardy , and I told him my uncle and I had an appointment with a lawyer .
#Text=Ay , ay , said he , he passed me word of that .
#Text=But , ye see , the boat 'll set ye ashore at the town pier , and that 's but a penny stonecast from Rankeillor 's house .
#Text=And here he suddenly leaned down and whispered in my ear : Take care of the old tod ; he means mischief .
#Text=Come aboard till I can get a word with ye .
#Text=And then , passing his arm through mine , he continued aloud , as he set off towards his boat : But , come , what can I bring ye from the Carolinas ?
#Text=Any friend of Mr. Balfour 's can command .
#Text=A roll of tobacco ?
#Text=Indian feather-work ?
#Text=a skin of a wild beast ?
#Text=a stone pipe ?
#Text=the mocking-bird that mews for all the world like a cat ?
#Text=the cardinal bird that is as red as blood ?
#Text=-- take your pick and say your pleasure .
#Text=Fox .
#Text=By this time we were at the boat-side , and he was handing me in .
#Text=I did not dream of hanging back ; I thought ( the poor fool !
#Text=) that I had found a good friend and helper , and I was rejoiced to see the ship .

#Text=As soon as we were all set in our places , the boat was thrust off from the pier and began to move over the waters : and what with my pleasure in this new movement and my surprise at our low position , and the appearance of the shores , and the growing bigness of the brig as we drew near to it , I could hardly understand what the captain said , and must have answered him at random .

#Text=As soon as we were alongside ( where I sat fairly gaping at the ship 's height , the strong humming of the tide against its sides , and the pleasant cries of the seamen at their work ) Hoseason , declaring that he and I must be the first aboard , ordered a tackle to be sent down from the main-yard .
#Text=In this I was whipped into the air and set down again on the deck , where the captain stood ready waiting for me , and instantly slipped back his arm under mine .

#Text=There I stood some while , a little dizzy with the unsteadiness of all around me , perhaps a little afraid , and yet vastly pleased with these strange sights ; the captain meanwhile pointing out the strangest , and telling me their names and uses .
#Text=But where is my uncle ?
#Text=said I suddenly .
#Text=Ay , said Hoseason , with a sudden grimness , that 's the point .
#Text=I felt I was lost .
#Text=With all my strength , I plucked myself clear of him and ran to the bulwarks .
#Text=Sure enough , there was the boat pulling for the town , with my uncle sitting in the stern .
#Text=I gave a piercing cry--Help , help !
#Text=Murder !
#Text=-- so that both sides of the anchorage rang with it , and my uncle turned round where he was sitting , and showed me a face full of cruelty and terror .
#Text=It was the last I saw .
#Text=Already strong hands had been plucking me back from the ship 's side ; and now a thunderbolt seemed to strike me ; I saw a great flash of fire , and fell senseless .
#Text=CHAPTER VII I GO TO SEA IN THE BRIG COVENANT OF DYSART I came to myself in darkness , in great pain , bound hand and foot , and deafened by many unfamiliar noises .
#Text=There sounded in my ears a roaring of water as of a huge mill-dam , the thrashing of heavy sprays , the thundering of the sails , and the shrill cries of seamen .

#Text=The whole world now heaved giddily up , and now rushed giddily downward ; and so sick and hurt was I in body , and my mind so much confounded , that it took me a long while , chasing my thoughts up and down , and ever stunned again by a fresh stab of pain , to realise that I must be lying somewhere bound in the belly of that unlucky ship , and that the wind must have strengthened to a gale .

#Text=With the clear perception of my plight , there fell upon me a blackness of despair , a horror of remorse at my own folly , and a passion of anger at my uncle , that once more bereft me of my senses .

#Text=When I returned again to life , the same uproar , the same confused and violent movements , shook and deafened me ; and presently , to my other pains and distresses , there was added the sickness of an unused landsman on the sea .
#Text=In that time of my adventurous youth , I suffered many hardships ; but none that was so crushing to my mind and body , or lit by so few hopes , as these first hours aboard the brig .
#Text=I heard a gun fire , and supposed the storm had proved too strong for us , and we were firing signals of distress .
#Text=The thought of deliverance , even by death in the deep sea , was welcome to me .
#Text=Yet it was no such matter ; but ( as I was afterwards told ) a common habit of the captain 's , which I here set down to show that even the worst man may have his kindlier side .

#Text=We were then passing , it appeared , within some miles of Dysart , where the brig was built , and where old Mrs. Hoseason , the captain 's mother , had come some years before to live ; and whether outward or inward bound , the Covenant was never suffered to go by that place by day , without a gun fired and colours shown .
#Text=I had no measure of time ; day and night were alike in that ill-smelling cavern of the ship 's bowels where I lay ; and the misery of my situation drew out the hours to double .
#Text=How long , therefore , I lay waiting to hear the ship split upon some rock , or to feel her reel head foremost into the depths of the sea , I have not the means of computation .
#Text=But sleep at length stole from me the consciousness of sorrow .
#Text=I was awakened by the light of a hand-lantern shining in my face .
#Text=A small man of about thirty , with green eyes and a tangle of fair hair , stood looking down at me .
#Text=Well , said he , how goes it ?
#Text=I answered by a sob ; and my visitor then felt my pulse and temples , and set himself to wash and dress the wound upon my scalp .
#Text=Ay , said he , a sore .
#Text=What , man ?
#Text=Cheer up !
#Text=The world 's no done ; you 've made a bad start of it but you 'll make a better .
#Text=Have you had any meat ?
#Text=Stroke .
#Text=I said I could not look at it : and thereupon he gave me some brandy and water in a tin pannikin , and left me once more to myself .

#Text=The next time he came to see me , I was lying betwixt sleep and waking , my eyes wide open in the darkness , the sickness quite departed , but succeeded by a horrid giddiness and swimming that was almost worse to bear .
#Text=I ached , besides , in every limb , and the cords that bound me seemed to be of fire .

#Text=The smell of the hole in which I lay seemed to have become a part of me ; and during the long interval since his last visit I had suffered tortures of fear , now from the scurrying of the ship 's rats , that sometimes pattered on my very face , and now from the dismal imaginings that haunt the bed of fever .

#Text=The glimmer of the lantern , as a trap opened , shone in like the heaven 's sunlight ; and though it only showed me the strong , dark beams of the ship that was my prison , I could have cried aloud for gladness .
#Text=The man with the green eyes was the first to descend the ladder , and I noticed that he came somewhat unsteadily .
#Text=He was followed by the captain .
#Text=Neither said a word ; but the first set to and examined me , and dressed my wound as before , while Hoseason looked me in my face with an odd , black look .
#Text=Now , sir , you see for yourself , said the first : a high fever , no appetite , no light , no meat : you see for yourself what that means .
#Text=I am no conjurer , Mr. Riach , said the captain .

#Text=Give me leave , sir , said Riach ; you 've a good head upon your shoulders , and a good Scotch tongue to ask with ; but I will leave you no manner of excuse ; I want that boy taken out of this hole and put in the forecastle .
#Text=What ye may want , sir , is a matter of concern to nobody but yoursel ' , returned the captain ; but I can tell ye that which is to be .
#Text=Here he is ; here he shall bide .
#Text=Admitting that you have been paid in a proportion , said the other , I will crave leave humbly to say that I have not .
#Text=Paid I am , and none too much , to be the second officer of this old tub , and you ken very well if I do my best to earn it .
#Text=But I was paid for nothing more .

#Text=If ye could hold back your hand from the tin-pan , Mr. Riach , I would have no complaint to make of ye , returned the skipper ; and instead of asking riddles , I make bold to say that ye would keep your breath to cool your porridge .
#Text=We 'll be required on deck , he added , in a sharper note , and set one foot upon the ladder .
#Text=But Mr. Riach caught him by the sleeve .
#Text=Admitting that you have been paid to do a murder -- -- he began .
#Text=Hoseason turned upon him with a flash .
#Text=What 's that ?
#Text=he cried .
#Text=What kind of talk is that ?
#Text=It seems it is the talk that you can understand , said Mr. Riach , looking him steadily in the face .
#Text=Mr. Riach , I have sailed with ye three cruises , replied the captain .
#Text=In all that time , sir , ye should have learned to know me : I 'm a stiff man , and a dour man ; but for what ye say the now--fie , fie !
#Text=-- it comes from a bad heart and a black conscience .
#Text=If ye say the lad will die -- -- Ay , will he !
#Text=said Mr. Riach .
#Text=Well , sir , is not that enough ?
#Text=said Hoseason .
#Text=Flit him where ye please !

#Text=Thereupon the captain ascended the ladder ; and I , who had lain silent throughout this strange conversation , beheld Mr. Riach turn after him and bow as low as to his knees in what was plainly a spirit of derision .
#Text=Even in my then state of sickness , I perceived two things : that the mate was touched with liquor , as the captain hinted , and that ( drunk or sober ) he was like to prove a valuable friend .

#Text=Five minutes afterwards my bonds were cut , I was hoisted on a man 's back , carried up to the forecastle , and laid in a bunk on some sea-blankets ; where the first thing that I did was to lose my senses .
#Text=It was a blessed thing indeed to open my eyes again upon the daylight , and to find myself in the society of men .
#Text=The forecastle was a roomy place enough , set all about with berths , in which the men of the watch below were seated smoking , or lying down asleep .

#Text=The day being calm and the wind fair , the scuttle was open , and not only the good daylight , but from time to time ( as the ship rolled ) a dusty beam of sunlight shone in , and dazzled and delighted me .
#Text=I had no sooner moved , moreover , than one of the men brought me a drink of something healing which Mr. Riach had prepared , and bade me lie still and I should soon be well again .
#Text=There were no bones broken , he explained : A on the head was naething .
#Text=Man , said he , it was me that gave it ye !
#Text=Blow .
#Text=Here I lay for the space of many days a close prisoner , and not only got my health again , but came to know my companions .
#Text=They were a rough lot indeed , as sailors mostly are : being men rooted out of all the kindly parts of life , and condemned to toss together on the rough seas , with masters no less cruel .

#Text=There were some among them that had sailed with the pirates and seen things it would be a shame even to speak of ; some were men that had run from the king 's ships , and went with a halter round their necks , of which they made no secret ; and all , as the saying goes , were at a word and a blow with their best friends .
#Text=Yet I had not been many days shut up with them before I began to be ashamed of my first judgment , when I had drawn away from them at the Ferry pier , as though they had been unclean beasts .
#Text=No class of man is altogether bad , but each has its own faults and virtues ; and these shipmates of mine were no exception to the rule .
#Text=Rough they were , sure enough ; and bad , I suppose ; but they had many virtues .
#Text=They were kind when it occurred to them , simple even beyond the simplicity of a country lad like me , and had some glimmerings of honesty .
#Text=There was one man , of maybe forty , that would sit on my berthside for hours and tell me of his wife and child .
#Text=He was a fisher that had lost his boat , and thus been driven to the deep-sea voyaging .
#Text=Well , it is years ago now : but I have never forgotten him .

#Text=His wife ( who was young by him , as he often told me ) waited in vain to see her man return ; he would never again make the fire for her in the morning , nor yet keep the bairn when she was sick .

#Text=Indeed , many of these poor fellows ( as the event proved ) were upon their last cruise ; the deep seas and cannibal fish received them ; and it is a thankless business to speak ill of the dead .

#Text=Among other good deeds that they did , they returned my money , which had been shared among them ; and though it was about a third short , I was very glad to get it , and hoped great good from it in the land I was going to .
#Text=The ship was bound for the Carolinas ; and you must not suppose that I was going to that place merely as an exile .

#Text=The trade was even then much depressed ; since that , and with the rebellion of the colonies and the formation of the United States , it has , of course , come to an end ; but in those days of my youth , white men were still sold into slavery on the plantations , and that was the destiny to which my wicked uncle had condemned me .

#Text=The cabin-boy Ransome ( from whom I had first heard of these atrocities ) came in at times from the round-house , where he berthed and served , now nursing a bruised limb in silent agony , now raving against the cruelty of Mr. Shuan .
#Text=It made my heart bleed ; but the men had a great respect for the chief mate , who was , as they said , the only seaman of the whole jing-bang , and none such a bad man when he was sober .

#Text=Indeed , I found there was a strange peculiarity about our two mates : that Mr. Riach was sullen , unkind , and harsh when he was sober , and Mr. Shuan would not hurt a fly except when he was drinking .
#Text=I asked about the captain ; but I was told drink made no difference upon that man of iron .
#Text=I did my best in the small time allowed me to make some thing like a man , or rather I should say something like a boy , of the poor creature , Ransome .
#Text=But his mind was scarce truly human .

#Text=He could remember nothing of the time before he came to sea ; only that his father had made clocks , and had a starling in the parlour , which could whistle The North Countrie ; all else had been blotted out in these years of hardship and cruelties .

#Text=He had a strange notion of the dry land , picked up from sailor 's stories : that it was a place where lads were put to some kind of slavery called a trade , and where apprentices were continually lashed and clapped into foul prisons .
#Text=In a town , he thought every second person a decoy , and every third house a place in which seamen would be drugged and murdered .

#Text=To be sure , I would tell him how kindly I had myself been used upon that dry land he was so much afraid of , and how well fed and carefully taught both by my friends and my parents : and if he had been recently hurt , he would weep bitterly and swear to run away ; but if he was in his usual crackbrain humour , or ( still more ) if he had had a glass of spirits in the roundhouse , he would deride the notion .
#Text=It was Mr. Riach ( Heaven forgive him !

#Text=) who gave the boy drink ; and it was , doubtless , kindly meant ; but besides that it was ruin to his health , it was the pitifullest thing in life to see this unhappy , unfriended creature staggering , and dancing , and talking he knew not what .

#Text=Some of the men laughed , but not all ; others would grow as black as thunder ( thinking , perhaps , of their own childhood or their own children ) and bid him stop that nonsense , and think what he was doing .
#Text=As for me , I felt ashamed to look at him , and the poor child still comes about me in my dreams .

#Text=All this time , you should know , the Covenant was meeting continual head-winds and tumbling up and down against head-seas , so that the scuttle was almost constantly shut , and the forecastle lighted only by a swinging lantern on a beam .

#Text=There was constant labour for all hands ; the sails had to be made and shortened every hour ; the strain told on the men 's temper ; there was a growl of quarrelling all day long from berth to berth ; and as I was never allowed to set my foot on deck , you can picture to yourselves how weary of my life I grew to be , and how impatient for a change .
#Text=And a change I was to get , as you shall hear ; but I must first tell of a conversation I had with Mr. Riach , which put a little heart in me to bear my troubles .
#Text=Getting him in a favourable stage of drink ( for indeed he never looked near me when he was sober ) , I pledged him to secrecy , and told him my whole story .

#Text=He declared it was like a ballad ; that he would do his best to help me ; that I should have paper , pen , and ink , and write one line to Mr. Campbell and another to Mr. Rankeillor ; and that if I had told the truth , ten to one he would be able ( with their help ) to pull me through and set me in my rights .
#Text=And in the meantime , says he , keep your heart up .
#Text=You 're not the only one , I 'll tell you that .
#Text=There 's many a man hoeing tobacco over-seas that should be mounting his horse at his own door at home ; many and many !
#Text=And life is all a variorum , at the best .
#Text=Look at me : I 'm a laird 's son and more than half a doctor , and here I am , man-Jack to Hoseason !
#Text=I thought it would be civil to ask him for his story .
#Text=He whistled loud .
#Text=Never had one , said he .
#Text=I like fun , that 's all .
#Text=And he skipped out of the forecastle .

#Text=CHAPTER VIII THE ROUND-HOUSE One night , about eleven o'clock , a man of Mr. Riach 's watch ( which was on deck ) came below for his jacket ; and instantly there began to go a whisper about the forecastle that Shuan had done for him at last .

#Text=There was no need of a name ; we all knew who was meant ; but we had scarce time to get the idea rightly in our heads , far less to speak of it , when the scuttle was again flung open , and Captain Hoseason came down the ladder .
#Text=He looked sharply round the bunks in the tossing light of the lantern ; and then , walking straight up to me , he addressed me , to my surprise , in tones of kindness .
#Text=My man , said he , we want ye to serve in the round-house .
#Text=You and Ransome are to change berths .
#Text=Run away aft with ye .

#Text=Even as he spoke , two seamen appeared in the scuttle , carrying Ransome in their arms ; and the ship at that moment giving a great sheer into the sea , and the lantern swinging , the light fell direct on the boy 's face .
#Text=It was as white as wax , and had a look upon it like a dreadful smile .
#Text=The blood in me ran cold , and I drew in my breath as if I had been struck .
#Text=Run away aft ; run away aft with ye !
#Text=cried Hoseason .
#Text=And at that I brushed by the sailors and the boy ( who neither spoke nor moved ) , and ran up the ladder on deck .
#Text=The brig was sheering swiftly and giddily through a long , cresting swell .
#Text=She was on the starboard tack , and on the left hand , under the arched foot of the foresail , I could see the sunset still quite bright .

#Text=This , at such an hour of the night , surprised me greatly ; but I was too ignorant to draw the true conclusion--that we were going north-about round Scotland , and were now on the high sea between the Orkney and Shetland Islands , having avoided the dangerous currents of the Pentland Firth .
#Text=For my part , who had been so long shut in the dark and knew nothing of head-winds , I thought we might be half-way or more across the Atlantic .

#Text=And indeed ( beyond that I wondered a little at the lateness of the sunset light ) I gave no heed to it , and pushed on across the decks , running between the seas , catching at ropes , and only saved from going overboard by one of the hands on deck , who had been always kind to me .
#Text=The round-house , for which I was bound , and where I was now to sleep and serve , stood some six feet above the decks , and considering the size of the brig , was of good dimensions .
#Text=Inside were a fixed table and bench , and two berths , one for the captain and the other for the two mates , turn and turn about .

#Text=It was all fitted with lockers from top to bottom , so as to stow away the officers'belongings and a part of the ship 's stores ; there was a second store-room underneath , which you entered by a hatchway in the middle of the deck ; indeed , all the best of the meat and drink and the whole of the powder were collected in this place ; and all the firearms , except the two pieces of brass ordnance , were set in a rack in the aftermost wall of the round-house .
#Text=The most of the cutlasses were in another place .
#Text=A small window with a shutter on each side , and a skylight in the roof , gave it light by day ; and after dark there was a lamp always burning .
#Text=It was burning when I entered , not brightly , but enough to show Mr. Shuan sitting at the table , with the brandy bottle and a tin pannikin in front of him .
#Text=He was a tall man , strongly made and very black ; and he stared before him on the table like one stupid .
#Text=He took no notice of my coming in ; nor did he move when the captain followed and leant on the berth beside me , looking darkly at the mate .
#Text=I stood in great fear of Hoseason , and had my reasons for it ; but something told me I need not be afraid of him just then ; and I whispered in his ear : How is he ?
#Text=He shook his head like one that does not know and does not wish to think , and his face was very stern .
#Text=Presently Mr. Riach came in .

#Text=He gave the captain a glance that meant the boy was dead as plain as speaking , and took his place like the rest of us ; so that we all three stood without a word , staring down at Mr. Shuan , and Mr. Shuan ( on his side ) sat without a word , looking hard upon the table .

#Text=All of a sudden he put out his hand to take the bottle ; and at that Mr. Riach started forward and caught it away from him , rather by surprise than violence , crying out , with an oath , that there had been too much of this work altogether , and that a judgment would fall upon the ship .
#Text=And as he spoke ( the weather sliding-doors standing open ) he tossed the bottle into the sea .

#Text=Mr. Shuan was on his feet in a trice ; he still looked dazed , but he meant murder , ay , and would have done it , for the second time that night , had not the captain stepped in between him and his victim .
#Text=Sit down !
#Text=roars the captain .
#Text=Ye sot and swine , do ye know what ye 've done ?
#Text=Ye 've murdered the boy !
#Text=Mr. Shuan seemed to understand ; for he sat down again , and put up his hand to his brow .
#Text=Well , he said , he brought me a dirty pannikin !

#Text=At that word , the captain and I and Mr. Riach all looked at each other for a second with a kind of frightened look ; and then Hoseason walked up to his chief officer , took him by the shoulder , led him across to his bunk , and bade him lie down and go to sleep , as you might speak to a bad child .
#Text=The murderer cried a little , but he took off his sea-boots and obeyed .
#Text=Ah !
#Text=cried Mr. Riach , with a dreadful voice , ye should have interfered long syne .
#Text=It 's too late now .
#Text=Mr. Riach , said the captain , this night 's work must never be kennt in Dysart .
#Text=The boy went overboard , sir ; that 's what the story is ; and I would give five pounds out of my pocket it was true !
#Text=He turned to the table .
#Text=What made ye throw the good bottle away ?
#Text=he added .
#Text=There was nae sense in that , sir .
#Text=Here , David , draw me another .
#Text=They 're in the bottom locker ; and he tossed me a key .
#Text=Ye 'll need a glass yourself , sir , he added to Riach .
#Text=Yon was an ugly thing to see .
#Text=So the pair sat down and hob-a-nobbed ; and while they did so , the murderer , who had been lying and whimpering in his berth , raised himself upon his elbow and looked at them and at me .
#Text=That was the first night of my new duties ; and in the course of the next day I had got well into the run of them .

#Text=I had to serve at the meals , which the captain took at regular hours , sitting down with the officer who was off duty ; all the day through I would be running with a dram to one or other of my three masters ; and at night I slept on a blanket thrown on the deck boards at the aftermost end of the round-house , and right in the draught of the two doors .

#Text=It was a hard and a cold bed ; nor was I suffered to sleep without interruption ; for some one would be always coming in from deck to get a dram , and when a fresh watch was to be set , two and sometimes all three would sit down and brew a bowl together .
#Text=How they kept their health , I know not , any more than how I kept my own .
#Text=And yet in other ways it was an easy service .

#Text=There was no cloth to lay ; the meals were either of oatmeal porridge or salt junk , except twice a week , when there was duff : and though I was clumsy enough and ( not being firm on my sealegs ) sometimes fell with what I was bringing them , both Mr. Riach and the captain were singularly patient .
#Text=I could not but fancy they were making up lee-way with their consciences , and that they would scarce have been so good with me if they had not been worse with Ransome .
#Text=As for Mr. Shuan , the drink or his crime , or the two together , had certainly troubled his mind .
#Text=I cannot say I ever saw him in his proper wits .
#Text=He never grew used to my being there , stared at me continually ( sometimes , I could have thought , with terror ) , and more than once drew back from my hand when I was serving him .
#Text=I was pretty sure from the first that he had no clear mind of what he had done , and on my second day in the round-house I had the proof of it .
#Text=We were alone , and he had been staring at me a long time , when all at once , up he got , as pale as death , and came close up to me , to my great terror .
#Text=But I had no cause to be afraid of him .
#Text=You were not here before ?
#Text=he asked .
#Text=No , sir , said I. There was another boy ?
#Text=he asked again ; and when I had answered him , Ah !
#Text=says he , I thought that , and went and sat down , without another word , except to call for brandy .
#Text=You may think it strange , but for all the horror I had , I was still sorry for him .
#Text=He was a married man , with a wife in Leith ; but whether or no he had a family , I have now forgotten ; I hope not .
#Text=Altogether it was no very hard life for the time it lasted , which ( as you are to hear ) was not long .

#Text=I was as well fed as the best of them ; even their pickles , which were the great dainty , I was allowed my share of ; and had I liked I might have been drunk from morning to night , like Mr. Shuan .
#Text=I had company , too , and good company of its sort .

#Text=Mr. Riach , who had been to the college , spoke to me like a friend when he was not sulking , and told me many curious things , and some that were informing ; and even the captain , though he kept me at the stick 's end the most part of the time , would sometimes unbuckle a bit , and tell me of the fine countries he had visited .
#Text=The shadow of poor Ransome , to be sure , lay on all four of us , and on me and Mr. Shuan in particular , most heavily .
#Text=And then I had another trouble of my own .

#Text=Here I was , doing dirty work for three men that I looked down upon , and one of whom , at least , should have hung upon a gallows ; that was for the present ; and as for the future , I could only see myself slaving alongside of negroes in the tobacco fields .

#Text=Mr. Riach , perhaps from caution , would never suffer me to say another word about my story ; the captain , whom I tried to approach , rebuffed me like a dog and would not hear a word ; and as the days came and went , my heart sank lower and lower , till I was even glad of the work which kept me from thinking .
#Text=CHAPTER IX THE MAN WITH THE BELT OF GOLD More than a week went by , in which the ill-luck that had hitherto pursued the Covenant upon this voyage grew yet more strongly marked .
#Text=Some days she made a little way ; others , she was driven actually back .
#Text=At last we were beaten so far to the south that we tossed and tacked to and fro the whole of the ninth day , within sight of Cape Wrath and the wild , rocky coast on either hand of it .

#Text=There followed on that a council of the officers , and some decision which I did not rightly understand , seeing only the result : that we had made a fair wind of a foul one and were running south .
#Text=The tenth afternoon there was a falling swell and a thick , wet , white fog that hid one end of the brig from the other .

#Text=All afternoon , when I went on deck , I saw men and officers listening hard over the bulwarks--for breakers , they said ; and though I did not so much as understand the word , I felt danger in the air , and was excited .
#Text=Maybe about ten at night , I was serving Mr. Riach and the captain at their supper , when the ship struck something with a great sound , and we heard voices singing out .
#Text=My two masters leaped to their feet .
#Text=She 's struck !
#Text=said Mr. Riach .
#Text=No , sir , said the captain .
#Text=We 've only run a boat down .
#Text=And they hurried out .
#Text=The captain was in the right of it .
#Text=We had run down a boat in the fog , and she had parted in the midst and gone to the bottom with all her crew but one .
#Text=This man ( as I heard afterwards ) had been sitting in the stern as a passenger , while the rest were on the benches rowing .

#Text=At the moment of the blow , the stern had been thrown into the air , and the man ( having his hands free , and for all he was encumbered with a frieze overcoat that came below his knees ) had leaped up and caught hold of the brig 's bowsprit .
#Text=It showed he had luck and much agility and unusual strength , that he should have thus saved himself from such a pass .
#Text=And yet , when the captain brought him into the round-house , and I set eyes on him for the first time , he looked as cool as I did .

#Text=He was smallish in stature , but well set and as nimble as a goat ; his face was of a good open expression , but sunburnt very dark , and heavily freckled and pitted with the small-pox ; his eyes were unusually light and had a kind of dancing madness in them , that was both engaging and alarming ; and when he took off his great-coat , he laid a pair of fine silver-mounted pistols on the table , and I saw that he was belted with a great sword .
#Text=His manners , besides , were elegant , and he pledged the captain handsomely .
#Text=Altogether I thought of him , at the first sight , that here was a man I would rather call my friend than my enemy .
#Text=The captain , too , was taking his observations , but rather of the man 's clothes than his person .

#Text=And to be sure , as soon as he had taken off the great-coat , he showed forth mighty fine for the round-house of a merchant brig : having a hat with feathers , a red waistcoat , breeches of black plush , and a blue coat with silver buttons and handsome silver lace ; costly clothes , though somewhat spoiled with the fog and being slept in .
#Text=I 'm vexed , sir , about the boat , says the captain .
#Text=There are some pretty men gone to the bottom , said the stranger , that I would rather see on the dry land again than half a score of boats .
#Text=Friends of yours ?
#Text=said Hoseason .
#Text=You have none such friends in your country , was the reply .
#Text=They would have died for me like dogs .
#Text=Well , sir , said the captain , still watching him , there are more men in the world than boats to put them in .
#Text=And that 's true , too , cried the other , and ye seem to be a gentleman of great penetration .
#Text=I have been in France , sir , says the captain , so that it was plain he meant more by the words than showed upon the face of them .
#Text=Well , sir , says the other , and so has many a pretty man , for the matter of that .
#Text=No doubt , sir , says the captain , and fine coats .
#Text=Oho !
#Text=says the stranger , is that how the wind sets ?
#Text=And he laid his hand quickly on his pistols .
#Text=Do n't be hasty , said the captain .
#Text=Do n't do a mischief before ye see the need of it .
#Text=Ye 've a French soldier 's coat upon your back and a Scotch tongue in your head , to be sure ; but so has many an honest fellow in these days , and I dare say none the worse of it .
#Text=So ?
#Text=said the gentleman in the fine coat : are ye of the honest party ?
#Text=( meaning , Was he a Jacobite ?
#Text=for each side , in these sort of civil broils , takes the name of honesty for its own ) .
#Text=Why , sir , replied the captain , I am a true-blue Protestant , and I thank God for it .
#Text=( It was the first word of any religion I had ever heard from him , but I learnt afterwards he was a great church-goer while on shore .
#Text=) But , for all that , says he , I can be sorry to see another man with his back to the wall .
#Text=Can ye so , indeed ?
#Text=asked the Jacobite .

#Text=Well , sir , to be quite plain with ye , I am one of those honest gentlemen that were in trouble about the years forty-five and six ; and ( to be still quite plain with ye ) if I got into the hands of any of the red-coated gentry , it 's like it would go hard with me .
#Text=Now , sir , I was for France ; and there was a French ship cruising here to pick me up ; but she gave us the go-by in the fog--as I wish from the heart that ye had done yoursel ' !
#Text=And the best that I can say is this : If ye can set me ashore where I was going , I have that upon me will reward you highly for your trouble .
#Text=In France ?
#Text=says the captain .
#Text=No , sir ; that I cannot do .
#Text=But where ye come from--we might talk of that .
#Text=And then , unhappily , he observed me standing in my corner , and packed me off to the galley to get supper for the gentleman .
#Text=I lost no time , I promise you ; and when I came back into the round-house , I found the gentleman had taken a money-belt from about his waist , and poured out a guinea or two upon the table .
#Text=The captain was looking at the guineas , and then at the belt , and then at the gentleman 's face ; and I thought he seemed excited .
#Text=Half of it , he cried , and I 'm your man !
#Text=The other swept back the guineas into the belt , and put it on again under his waistcoat .
#Text=I have told ye sir , said he , that not one doit of it belongs to me .

#Text=It belongs to my chieftain , and here he touched his hat , and while I would be but a silly messenger to grudge some of it that the rest might come safe , I should show myself a hound indeed if I bought my own carcase any too dear .
#Text=Thirty guineas on the sea-side , or sixty if ye set me on the Linnhe Loch .
#Text=Take it , if ye will ; if not , ye can do your worst .
#Text=Ay , said Hoseason .
#Text=And if I give ye over to the soldiers ?
#Text=Ye would make a fool 's bargain , said the other .
#Text=My chief , let me tell you , sir , is forfeited , like every honest man in Scotland .
#Text=His estate is in the hands of the man they call King George ; and it is his officers that collect the rents , or try to collect them .
#Text=But for the honour of Scotland , the poor tenant bodies take a thought upon their chief lying in exile ; and this money is a part of that very rent for which King George is looking .
#Text=Now , sir , ye seem to me to be a man that understands things : bring this money within the reach of Government , and how much of it 'll come to you ?
#Text=Little enough , to be sure , said Hoseason ; and then , if they knew , he added , drily .
#Text=But I think , if I was to try , that I could hold my tongue about it .
#Text=Ah , but I 'll ye there !
#Text=cried the gentleman .
#Text=Play me false , and I 'll play you cunning .
#Text=If a hand is laid upon me , they shall ken what money it is .
#Text=.
#Text=Well , returned the captain , what must be must .
#Text=Sixty guineas , and done .
#Text=Here 's my hand upon it .
#Text=And here 's mine , said the other .
#Text=And thereupon the captain went out ( rather hurriedly , I thought ) , and left me alone in the round-house with the stranger .

#Text=At that period ( so soon after the forty-five ) there were many exiled gentlemen coming back at the peril of their lives , either to see their friends or to collect a little money ; and as for the Highland chiefs that had been forfeited , it was a common matter of talk how their tenants would stint themselves to send them money , and their clansmen outface the soldiery to get it in , and run the gauntlet of our great navy to carry it across .

#Text=All this I had , of course , heard tell of ; and now I had a man under my eyes whose life was forfeit on all these counts and upon one more , for he was not only a rebel and a smuggler of rents , but had taken service with King Louis of France .
#Text=And as if all this were not enough , he had a belt full of golden guineas round his loins .
#Text=Whatever my opinions , I could not look on such a man without a lively interest .
#Text=And so you 're a Jacobite ?
#Text=said I , as I set meat before him .
#Text=Ay , said he , beginning to eat .
#Text=And you , by your long face , should be a Whig ?
#Text=Whig or Whigamore was the cant name for those who were loyal to King George .
#Text=Betwixt and between , said I , not to annoy him ; for indeed I was as good a Whig as Mr. Campbell could make me .
#Text=And that 's naething , said he .
#Text=But I 'm saying , Mr. Betwixt-and-Between , he added , this bottle of yours is dry ; and it 's hard if I 'm to pay sixty guineas and be grudged a dram upon the back of it .
#Text=I 'll go and ask for the key , said I , and stepped on deck .
#Text=The fog was as close as ever , but the swell almost down .
#Text=They had laid the brig to , not knowing precisely where they were , and the wind ( what little there was of it ) not serving well for their true course .
#Text=Some of the hands were still hearkening for breakers ; but the captain and the two officers were in the waist with their heads together .
#Text=It struck me ( I do n't know why ) that they were after no good ; and the first word I heard , as I drew softly near , more than confirmed me .
#Text=It was Mr. Riach , crying out as if upon a sudden thought : Could n't we wile him out of the round-house ?
#Text=He 's better where he is , returned Hoseason ; he has n't room to use his sword .
#Text=Well , that 's true , said Riach ; but he 's hard to come at .
#Text=Hut !
#Text=said Hoseason .

#Text=We can get the man in talk , one upon each side , and pin him by the two arms ; or if that 'll not hold , sir , we can make a run by both the doors and get him under hand before he has the time to draw .
#Text=At this hearing , I was seized with both fear and anger at these treacherous , greedy , bloody men that I sailed with .
#Text=My first mind was to run away ; my second was bolder .
#Text=Captain , said I , the gentleman is seeking a dram , and the bottle 's out .
#Text=Will you give me the key ?
#Text=They all started and turned about .
#Text=Why , here 's our chance to get the firearms !
#Text=Riach cried ; and then to me : Hark ye , David , he said , do ye ken where the pistols are ?
#Text=Ay , ay , put in Hoseason .
#Text=David kens ; David 's a good lad .
#Text=Ye see , David my man , yon wild Hielandman is a danger to the ship , besides being a rank foe to King George , God bless him !
#Text=I had never been so be-Davided since I came on board : but I said Yes , as if all I heard were quite natural .
#Text=The trouble is , resumed the captain , that all our firelocks , great and little , are in the round-house under this man 's nose ; likewise the powder .
#Text=Now , if I , or one of the officers , was to go in and take them , he would fall to thinking .
#Text=But a lad like you , David , might snap up a horn and a pistol or two without remark .
#Text=And if ye can do it cleverly , I 'll bear it in mind when it 'll be good for you to have friends ; and that 's when we come to Carolina .
#Text=Here Mr. Riach whispered him a little .
#Text=Very right , sir , said the captain ; and then to myself : And see here , David , yon man has a beltful of gold , and I give you my word that you shall have your fingers in it .
#Text=I told him I would do as he wished , though indeed I had scarce breath to speak with ; and upon that he gave me the key of the spirit locker , and I began to go slowly back to the round-house .
#Text=What was I to do ?
#Text=They were dogs and thieves ; they had stolen me from my own country ; they had killed poor Ransome ; and was I to hold the candle to another murder ?
#Text=But then , upon the other hand , there was the fear of death very plain before me ; for what could a boy and a man , if they were as brave as lions , against a whole ship 's company ?

#Text=I was still arguing it back and forth , and getting no great clearness , when I came into the round-house and saw the Jacobite eating his supper under the lamp ; and at that my mind was made up all in a moment .
#Text=I have no credit by it ; it was by no choice of mine , but as if by compulsion , that I walked right up to the table and put my hand on his shoulder .
#Text=Do ye want to be killed ?
#Text=said I. He sprang to his feet , and looked a question at me as clear as if he had spoken .
#Text=O !
#Text=cried I , they 're all murderers here ; it 's a ship full of them !
#Text=They 've murdered a boy already .
#Text=Now it 's you .
#Text=Ay , ay , said he ; but they have n't got me yet .
#Text=And then looking at me curiously , Will ye stand with me ?
#Text=That will I !
#Text=said I. I am no thief , nor yet murderer .
#Text=I 'll stand by you .
#Text=Why , then , said he , what 's your name ?
#Text=David Balfour , said I ; and then , thinking that a man with so fine a coat must like fine people , I added for the first time , of Shaws .
#Text=It never occurred to him to doubt me , for a Highlander is used to see great gentlefolk in great poverty ; but as he had no estate of his own , my words nettled a very childish vanity he had .
#Text=My name is Stewart , he said , drawing himself up .
#Text=Alan Breck , they call me .
#Text=A king 's name is good enough for me , though I bear it plain and have the name of no farm-midden to clap to the hind-end of it .
#Text=And having administered this rebuke , as though it were something of a chief importance , he turned to examine our defences .
#Text=The round-house was built very strong , to support the breaching of the seas .
#Text=Of its five apertures , only the skylight and the two doors were large enough for the passage of a man .
#Text=The doors , besides , could be drawn close : they were of stout oak , and ran in grooves , and were fitted with hooks to keep them either shut or open , as the need arose .
#Text=The one that was already shut I secured in this fashion ; but when I was proceeding to slide to the other , Alan stopped me .
#Text=David , said he--for I cannae bring to mind the name of your landed estate , and so will make so bold as to call you David--that door , being open , is the best part of my defences .
#Text=It would be yet better shut , says I. Not so , David , says he .
#Text=Ye see , I have but one face ; but so long as that door is open and my face to it , the best part of my enemies will be in front of me , where I would aye wish to find them .

#Text=Then he gave me from the rack a cutlass ( of which there were a few besides the firearms ) , choosing it with great care , shaking his head and saying he had never in all his life seen poorer weapons ; and next he set me down to the table with a powder-horn , a bag of bullets and all the pistols , which he bade me charge .
#Text=And that will be better work , let me tell you , said he , for a gentleman of decent birth , than scraping plates and drams to a wheen tarry sailors .
#Text=.
#Text=Thereupon he stood up in the midst with his face to the door , and drawing his great sword , made trial of the room he had to wield it in .
#Text=I must stick to the point , he said , shaking his head ; and that 's a pity , too .
#Text=It does n't set my genius , which is all for the upper guard .
#Text=And , now , said he , do you keep on charging the pistols , and give heed to me .
#Text=I told him I would listen closely .

#Text=My chest was tight , my mouth dry , the light dark to my eyes ; the thought of the numbers that were soon to leap in upon us kept my heart in a flutter : and the sea , which I heard washing round the brig , and where I thought my dead body would be cast ere morning , ran in my mind strangely .
#Text=First of all , said he , how many are against us ?
#Text=I reckoned them up ; and such was the hurry of my mind , I had to cast the numbers twice .
#Text=Fifteen , said I. Alan whistled .
#Text=Well , said he , that ca n't be cured .
#Text=And now follow me .
#Text=It is my part to keep this door , where I look for the main battle .
#Text=In that , ye have no hand .
#Text=And mind and dinnae fire to this side unless they get me down ; for I would rather have ten foes in front of me than one friend like you cracking pistols at my back .
#Text=I told him , indeed I was no great shot .
#Text=And that 's very bravely said , he cried , in a great admiration of my candour .
#Text=There 's many a pretty gentleman that wouldnae dare to say it .
