#Text=But then , sir , said I , there is the door behind you , which they may perhaps break in .
#Text=Ay , said he , and that is a part of your work .
#Text=No sooner the pistols charged , than ye must climb up into yon bed where ye 're handy at the window ; and if they lift hand against the door , ye 're to shoot .
#Text=But that 's not all .
#Text=Let 's make a bit of a soldier of ye , David .
#Text=What else have ye to guard ?
#Text=There 's the skylight , said I. But indeed , Mr. Stewart , I would need to have eyes upon both sides to keep the two of them ; for when my face is at the one , my back is to the other .
#Text=And that 's very true , said Alan .
#Text=But have ye no ears to your head ?
#Text=To be sure !
#Text=cried I. I must hear the bursting of the glass !
#Text=Ye have some rudiments of sense , said Alan , grimly .
#Text=CHAPTER X THE SIEGE OF THE ROUND-HOUSE But now our time of truce was come to an end .
#Text=Those on deck had waited for my coming till they grew impatient ; and scarce had Alan spoken , when the captain showed face in the open door .
#Text=Stand !
#Text=cried Alan , and pointed his sword at him .
#Text=The captain stood , indeed ; but he neither winced nor drew back a foot .
#Text=A naked sword ?
#Text=says he .
#Text=This is a strange return for hospitality .
#Text=Do ye see me ?
#Text=said Alan .
#Text=I am come of kings ; I bear a king 's name .
#Text=My badge is the oak .
#Text=Do ye see my sword ?
#Text=It has slashed the heads off mair Whigamores than you have toes upon your feet .
#Text=Call up your vermin to your back , sir , and fall on !
#Text=The sooner the clash begins , the sooner ye 'll taste this steel throughout your vitals .
#Text=The captain said nothing to Alan , but he looked over at me with an ugly look .
#Text=David , said he , I 'll mind this ; and the sound of his voice went through me with a jar .
#Text=Next moment he was gone .
#Text=And now , said Alan , let your hand keep your head , for the grip is coming .
#Text=Alan drew a dirk , which he held in his left hand in case they should run in under his sword .
#Text=I , on my part , clambered up into the berth with an armful of pistols and something of a heavy heart , and set open the window where I was to watch .
#Text=It was a small part of the deck that I could overlook , but enough for our purpose .
#Text=The sea had gone down , and the wind was steady and kept the sails quiet ; so that there was a great stillness in the ship , in which I made sure I heard the sound of muttering voices .
#Text=A little after , and there came a clash of steel upon the deck , by which I knew they were dealing out the cutlasses and one had been let fall ; and after that , silence again .

#Text=I do not know if I was what you call afraid ; but my heart beat like a bird 's , both quick and little ; and there was a dimness came before my eyes which I continually rubbed away , and which continually returned .
#Text=As for hope , I had none ; but only a darkness of despair and a sort of anger against all the world that made me long to sell my life as dear as I was able .

#Text=I tried to pray , I remember , but that same hurry of my mind , like a man running , would not suffer me to think upon the words ; and my chief wish was to have the thing begin and be done with it .
#Text=It came all of a sudden when it did , with a rush of feet and a roar , and then a shout from Alan , and a sound of blows and some one crying out as if hurt .
#Text=I looked back over my shoulder , and saw Mr. Shuan in the doorway , crossing blades with Alan .
#Text=That 's him that killed the boy !
#Text=I cried .
#Text=Look to your window !
#Text=said Alan ; and as I turned back to my place , I saw him pass his sword through the mate 's body .

#Text=It was none too soon for me to look to my own part ; for my head was scarce back at the window , before five men , carrying a spare yard for a battering-ram , ran past me and took post to drive the door in .
#Text=I had never fired with a pistol in my life , and not often with a gun ; far less against a fellow-creature .
#Text=But it was now or never ; and just as they swang the yard , I cried out : Take that !
#Text=and shot into their midst .
#Text=I must have hit one of them , for he sang out and gave back a step , and the rest stopped as if a little disconcerted .
#Text=Before they had time to recover , I sent another ball over their heads ; and at my third shot ( which went as wide as the second ) the whole party threw down the yard and ran for it .
#Text=Then I looked round again into the deck-house .
#Text=The whole place was full of the smoke of my own firing , just as my ears seemed to be burst with the noise of the shots .

#Text=But there was Alan , standing as before ; only now his sword was running blood to the hilt , and himself so swelled with triumph and fallen into so fine an attitude , that he looked to be invincible .

#Text=Right before him on the floor was Mr. Shuan , on his hands and knees ; the blood was pouring from his mouth , and he was sinking slowly lower , with a terrible , white face ; and just as I looked , some of those from behind caught hold of him by the heels and dragged him bodily out of the round-house .
#Text=I believe he died as they were doing it .
#Text=There 's one of your Whigs for ye !
#Text=cried Alan ; and then turning to me , he asked if I had done much execution .
#Text=I told him I had winged one , and thought it was the captain .
#Text=And I 've settled two , says he .
#Text=No , there 's not enough blood let ; they 'll be back again .
#Text=To your watch , David .
#Text=This was but a dram before meat .
#Text=I settled back to my place , re-charging the three pistols I had fired , and keeping watch with both eye and ear .
#Text=Our enemies were disputing not far off upon the deck , and that so loudly that I could hear a word or two above the washing of the seas .
#Text=It was Shuan it , I heard one say .
#Text=Bungled .
#Text=And another answered him with a Wheesht , man !
#Text=He 's paid the piper .
#Text=After that the voices fell again into the same muttering as before .
#Text=Only now , one person spoke most of the time , as though laying down a plan , and first one and then another answered him briefly , like men taking orders .
#Text=By this , I made sure they were coming on again , and told Alan .
#Text=It 's what we have to pray for , said he .
#Text=Unless we can give them a good distaste of us , and done with it , there 'll be nae sleep for either you or me .
#Text=But this time , mind , they 'll be in earnest .
#Text=By this , my pistols were ready , and there was nothing to do but listen and wait .
#Text=While the brush lasted , I had not the time to think if I was frighted ; but now , when all was still again , my mind ran upon nothing else .

#Text=The thought of the sharp swords and the cold steel was strong in me ; and presently , when I began to hear stealthy steps and a brushing of men 's clothes against the round-house wall , and knew they were taking their places in the dark , I could have found it in my mind to cry out aloud .
#Text=All this was upon Alan 's side ; and I had begun to think my share of the fight was at an end , when I heard some one drop softly on the roof above me .
#Text=Then there came a single call on the sea-pipe , and that was the signal .

#Text=A knot of them made one rush of it , cutlass in hand , against the door ; and at the same moment , the glass of the skylight was dashed in a thousand pieces , and a man leaped through and landed on the floor .

#Text=Before he got his feet , I had clapped a pistol to his back , and might have shot him , too ; only at the touch of him ( and him alive ) my whole flesh misgave me , and I could no more pull the trigger than I could have flown .

#Text=He had dropped his cutlass as he jumped , and when he felt the pistol , whipped straight round and laid hold of me , roaring out an oath ; and at that either my courage came again , or I grew so much afraid as came to the same thing ; for I gave a shriek and shot him in the midst of the body .
#Text=He gave the most horrible , ugly groan and fell to the floor .

#Text=The foot of a second fellow , whose legs were dangling through the skylight , struck me at the same time upon the head ; and at that I snatched another pistol and shot this one through the thigh , so that he slipped through and tumbled in a lump on his companion 's body .
#Text=There was no talk of missing , any more than there was time to aim ; I clapped the muzzle to the very place and fired .
#Text=I might have stood and stared at them for long , but I heard Alan shout as if for help , and that brought me to my senses .
#Text=He had kept the door so long ; but one of the seamen , while he was engaged with others , had run in under his guard and caught him about the body .
#Text=Alan was dirking him with his left hand , but the fellow clung like a leech .
#Text=Another had broken in and had his cutlass raised .
#Text=The door was thronged with their faces .
#Text=I thought we were lost , and catching up my cutlass , fell on them in flank .
#Text=But I had not time to be of help .
#Text=The wrestler dropped at last ; and Alan , leaping back to get his distance , ran upon the others like a bull , roaring as he went .
#Text=They broke before him like water , turning , and running , and falling one against another in their haste .
#Text=The sword in his hands flashed like quicksilver into the huddle of our fleeing enemies ; and at every flash there came the scream of a man hurt .
#Text=I was still thinking we were lost , when lo !
#Text=they were all gone , and Alan was driving them along the deck as a sheep-dog chases sheep .

#Text=Yet he was no sooner out than he was back again , being as cautious as he was brave ; and meanwhile the seamen continued running and crying out as if he was still behind them ; and we heard them tumble one upon another into the forecastle , and clap-to the hatch upon the top .
#Text=The round-house was like a shambles ; three were dead inside , another lay in his death agony across the threshold ; and there were Alan and I victorious and unhurt .
#Text=He came up to me with open arms .
#Text=Come to my arms !
#Text=he cried , and embraced and kissed me hard upon both cheeks .
#Text=David , said he , I love you like a brother .
#Text=And O , man , he cried in a kind of ecstasy , am I no a bonny fighter ?
#Text=Thereupon he turned to the four enemies , passed his sword clean through each of them , and tumbled them out of doors one after the other .
#Text=As he did so , he kept humming and singing and whistling to himself , like a man trying to recall an air ; only what HE was trying was to make one .
#Text=All the while , the flush was in his face , and his eyes were as bright as a five-year-old child 's with a new toy .

#Text=And presently he sat down upon the table , sword in hand ; the air that he was making all the time began to run a little clearer , and then clearer still ; and then out he burst with a great voice into a Gaelic song .
#Text=I have translated it here , not in verse ( of which I have no skill ) but at least in the king 's English .
#Text=He sang it often afterwards , and the thing became popular ; so that I have heard it and had it explained to me , many 's the time .
#Text=This is the song of the sword of Alan ; The smith made it , The fire set it ; Now it shines in the hand of Alan Breck .
#Text=Their eyes were many and bright , Swift were they to behold , Many the hands they guided : The sword was alone .
#Text=The dun deer troop over the hill , They are many , the hill is one ; The dun deer vanish , The hill remains .
#Text=Come to me from the hills of heather , Come from the isles of the sea .
#Text=O far-beholding eagles , Here is your meat .
#Text=Now this song which he made ( both words and music ) in the hour of our victory , is something less than just to me , who stood beside him in the tussle .
#Text=Mr. Shuan and five more were either killed outright or thoroughly disabled ; but of these , two fell by my hand , the two that came by the skylight .
#Text=Four more were hurt , and of that number , one ( and he not the least important ) got his hurt from me .
#Text=So that , altogether , I did my fair share both of the killing and the wounding , and might have claimed a place in Alan 's verses .
#Text=But poets have to think upon their rhymes ; and in good prose talk , Alan always did me more than justice .
#Text=In the meanwhile , I was innocent of any wrong being done me .

#Text=For not only I knew no word of the Gaelic ; but what with the long suspense of the waiting , and the scurry and strain of our two spirts of fighting , and more than all , the horror I had of some of my own share in it , the thing was no sooner over than I was glad to stagger to a seat .

#Text=There was that tightness on my chest that I could hardly breathe ; the thought of the two men I had shot sat upon me like a nightmare ; and all upon a sudden , and before I had a guess of what was coming , I began to sob and cry like any child .
#Text=Alan clapped my shoulder , and said I was a brave lad and wanted nothing but a sleep .
#Text=I 'll take the first watch , said he .
#Text=Ye 've done well by me , David , first and last ; and I would n't lose you for all Appin--no , nor for Breadalbane .
#Text=So I made up my bed on the floor ; and he took the first spell , pistol in hand and sword on knee , three hours by the captain 's watch upon the wall .

#Text=Then he roused me up , and I took my turn of three hours ; before the end of which it was broad day , and a very quiet morning , with a smooth , rolling sea that tossed the ship and made the blood run to and fro on the round-house floor , and a heavy rain that drummed upon the roof .
#Text=All my watch there was nothing stirring ; and by the banging of the helm , I knew they had even no one at the tiller .

#Text=Indeed ( as I learned afterwards ) there were so many of them hurt or dead , and the rest in so ill a temper , that Mr. Riach and the captain had to take turn and turn like Alan and me , or the brig might have gone ashore and nobody the wiser .
#Text=It was a mercy the night had fallen so still , for the wind had gone down as soon as the rain began .

#Text=Even as it was , I judged by the wailing of a great number of gulls that went crying and fishing round the ship , that she must have drifted pretty near the coast or one of the islands of the Hebrides ; and at last , looking out of the door of the round-house , I saw the great stone hills of Skye on the right hand , and , a little more astern , the strange isle of Rum .
#Text=CHAPTER XI THE CAPTAIN KNUCKLES UNDER Alan and I sat down to breakfast about six of the clock .
#Text=The floor was covered with broken glass and in a horrid mess of blood , which took away my hunger .

#Text=In all other ways we were in a situation not only agreeable but merry ; having ousted the officers from their own cabin , and having at command all the drink in the ship--both wine and spirits--and all the dainty part of what was eatable , such as the pickles and the fine sort of bread .

#Text=This , of itself , was enough to set us in good humour , but the richest part of it was this , that the two thirstiest men that ever came out of Scotland ( Mr. Shuan being dead ) were now shut in the fore-part of the ship and condemned to what they hated most--cold water .
#Text=And depend upon it , Alan said , we shall hear more of them ere long .
#Text=Ye may keep a man from the fighting , but never from his bottle .
#Text=We made good company for each other .
#Text=Alan , indeed , expressed himself most lovingly ; and taking a knife from the table , cut me off one of the silver buttons from his coat .
#Text=I had them , says he , from my father , Duncan Stewart ; and now give ye one of them to be a keepsake for last night 's work .
#Text=And wherever ye go and show that button , the friends of Alan Breck will come around you .

#Text=He said this as if he had been Charlemagne , and commanded armies ; and indeed , much as I admired his courage , I was always in danger of smiling at his vanity : in danger , I say , for had I not kept my countenance , I would be afraid to think what a quarrel might have followed .

#Text=As soon as we were through with our meal he rummaged in the captain 's locker till he found a clothes-brush ; and then taking off his coat , began to visit his suit and brush away the stains , with such care and labour as I supposed to have been only usual with women .
#Text=To be sure , he had no other ; and , besides ( as he said ) , it belonged to a king and so behoved to be royally looked after .
#Text=For all that , when I saw what care he took to pluck out the threads where the button had been cut away , I put a higher value on his gift .

#Text=He was still so engaged when we were hailed by Mr. Riach from the deck , asking for a parley ; and I , climbing through the skylight and sitting on the edge of it , pistol in hand and with a bold front , though inwardly in fear of broken glass , hailed him back again and bade him speak out .
#Text=He came to the edge of the round-house , and stood on a coil of rope , so that his chin was on a level with the roof ; and we looked at each other awhile in silence .

#Text=Mr. Riach , as I do not think he had been very forward in the battle , so he had got off with nothing worse than a blow upon the cheek : but he looked out of heart and very weary , having been all night afoot , either standing watch or doctoring the wounded .
#Text=This is a bad job , said he at last , shaking his head .
#Text=It was none of our choosing , said I. The captain , says he , would like to speak with your friend .
#Text=They might speak at the window .
#Text=And how do we know what treachery he means ?
#Text=cried I. He means none , David , returned Mr. Riach , and if he did , I 'll tell ye the honest truth , we couldnae get the men to follow .
#Text=Is that so ?
#Text=said I. I 'll tell ye more than that , said he .
#Text=It 's not only the men ; it 's me .
#Text=I 'm frich'ened , Davie .
#Text=And he smiled across at me .
#Text=No , he continued , what we want is to be shut of him .

#Text=Thereupon I consulted with Alan , and the parley was agreed to and parole given upon either side ; but this was not the whole of Mr. Riach 's business , and he now begged me for a dram with such instancy and such reminders of his former kindness , that at last I handed him a pannikin with about a gill of brandy .
#Text=He drank a part , and then carried the rest down upon the deck , to share it ( I suppose ) with his superior .

#Text=A little after , the captain came ( as was agreed ) to one of the windows , and stood there in the rain , with his arm in a sling , and looking stern and pale , and so old that my heart smote me for having fired upon him .
#Text=Alan at once held a pistol in his face .
#Text=Put that thing up !
#Text=said the captain .
#Text=Have I not passed my word , sir ?
#Text=or do ye seek to affront me ?
#Text=Captain , says Alan , I doubt your word is a breakable .
#Text=Last night ye haggled and argle-bargled like an apple-wife ; and then passed me your word , and gave me your hand to back it ; and ye ken very well what was the upshot .
#Text=Be damned to your word !
#Text=says he .
#Text=Well , well , sir , said the captain , ye 'll get little good by swearing .
#Text=( And truly that was a fault of which the captain was quite free .
#Text=) But we have other things to speak , he continued , bitterly .

#Text=Ye 've made a sore hash of my brig ; I have n't hands enough left to work her ; and my first officer ( whom I could ill spare ) has got your sword throughout his vitals , and passed without speech .
#Text=There is nothing left me , sir , but to put back into the port of Glasgow after hands ; and there ( by your leave ) ye will find them that are better able to talk to you .
#Text=Ay ?
#Text=said Alan ; and faith , I 'll have a talk with them mysel ' !
#Text=Unless there 's naebody speaks English in that town , I have a bonny tale for them .
#Text=Fifteen tarry sailors upon the one side , and a man and a halfling boy upon the other !
#Text=O , man , it 's peetiful !
#Text=Hoseason flushed red .
#Text=No , continued Alan , that 'll no do .
#Text=Ye 'll just have to set me ashore as we agreed .
#Text=Ay , said Hoseason , but my first officer is dead--ye ken best how .
#Text=There 's none of the rest of us acquaint with this coast , sir ; and it 's one very dangerous to ships .
#Text=I give ye your choice , says Alan .

#Text=Set me on dry ground in Appin , or Ardgour , or in Morven , or Arisaig , or Morar ; or , in brief , where ye please , within thirty miles of my own country ; except in a country of the Campbells .
#Text=That 's a broad target .
#Text=If ye miss that , ye must be as feckless at the sailoring as I have found ye at the fighting .
#Text=Why , my poor country people in their bit pass from island to island in all weathers , ay , and by night too , for the matter of that .
#Text=: a small boat used in fishing .
#Text=A coble 's not a ship , sir , said the captain .
#Text=It has nae draught of water .
#Text=Well , then , to Glasgow if ye list !
#Text=says Alan .
#Text=We 'll have the laugh of ye at the least .
#Text=My mind runs little upon laughing , said the captain .
#Text=But all this will cost money , sir .
#Text=Well , sir , says Alan , I am nae weathercock .
#Text=Thirty guineas , if ye land me on the sea-side ; and sixty , if ye put me in the Linnhe Loch .
#Text=But see , sir , where we lie , we are but a few hours'sail from Ardnamurchan , said Hoseason .
#Text=Give me sixty , and I 'll set ye there .
#Text=And I 'm to wear my brogues and run jeopardy of the red-coats to please you ?
#Text=cries Alan .
#Text=No , sir ; if ye want sixty guineas earn them , and set me in my own country .
#Text=It 's to risk the brig , sir , said the captain , and your own lives along with her .
#Text=Take it or want it , says Alan .
#Text=Could ye pilot us at all ?
#Text=asked the captain , who was frowning to himself .
#Text=Well , it 's doubtful , said Alan .
#Text=I 'm more of a fighting man ( as ye have seen for yoursel ' ) than a sailor-man .
#Text=But I have been often enough picked up and set down upon this coast , and should ken something of the lie of it .
#Text=The captain shook his head , still frowning .
#Text=If I had lost less money on this unchancy cruise , says he , I would see you in a rope 's end before I risked my brig , sir .
#Text=But be it as ye will .
#Text=As soon as I get a slant of wind ( and there 's some coming , or I 'm the more mistaken ) I 'll put it in hand .
#Text=But there 's one thing more .
#Text=We may meet in with a king 's ship and she may lay us aboard , sir , with no blame of mine : they keep the cruisers thick upon this coast , ye ken who for .
#Text=Now , sir , if that was to befall , ye might leave the money .
#Text=Captain , says Alan , if ye see a pennant , it shall be your part to run away .
#Text=And now , as I hear you 're a little short of brandy in the fore-part , I 'll offer ye a change : a bottle of brandy against two buckets of water .

#Text=That was the last clause of the treaty , and was duly executed on both sides ; so that Alan and I could at last wash out the round-house and be quit of the memorials of those whom we had slain , and the captain and Mr. Riach could be happy again in their own way , the name of which was drink .
#Text=CHAPTER XII I HEAR OF THE RED FOX Before we had done cleaning out the round-house , a breeze sprang up from a little to the east of north .
#Text=This blew off the rain and brought out the sun .
#Text=And here I must explain ; and the reader would do well to look at a map .
#Text=On the day when the fog fell and we ran down Alan 's boat , we had been running through the Little Minch .
#Text=At dawn after the battle , we lay becalmed to the east of the Isle of Canna or between that and Isle Eriska in the chain of the Long Island .
#Text=Now to get from there to the Linnhe Loch , the straight course was through the narrows of the Sound of Mull .

#Text=But the captain had no chart ; he was afraid to trust his brig so deep among the islands ; and the wind serving well , he preferred to go by west of Tiree and come up under the southern coast of the great Isle of Mull .
#Text=All day the breeze held in the same point , and rather freshened than died down ; and towards afternoon , a swell began to set in from round the outer Hebrides .
#Text=Our course , to go round about the inner isles , was to the west of south , so that at first we had this swell upon our beam , and were much rolled about .
#Text=But after nightfall , when we had turned the end of Tiree and began to head more to the east , the sea came right astern .
#Text=Meanwhile , the early part of the day , before the swell came up , was very pleasant ; sailing , as we were , in a bright sunshine and with many mountainous islands upon different sides .
#Text=Alan and I sat in the round-house with the doors open on each side ( the wind being straight astern ) , and smoked a pipe or two of the captain 's fine tobacco .
#Text=It was at this time we heard each other 's stories , which was the more important to me , as I gained some knowledge of that wild Highland country on which I was so soon to land .
#Text=In those days , so close on the back of the great rebellion , it was needful a man should know what he was doing when he went upon the heather .
#Text=It was I that showed the example , telling him all my misfortune ; which he heard with great good-nature .
#Text=Only , when I came to mention that good friend of mine , Mr. Campbell the minister , Alan fired up and cried out that he hated all that were of that name .
#Text=Why , said I , he is a man you should be proud to give your hand to .
#Text=I know nothing I would help a Campbell to , says he , unless it was a leaden bullet .
#Text=I would hunt all of that name like blackcocks .
#Text=If I lay dying , I would crawl upon my knees to my chamber window for a shot at one .
#Text=Why , Alan , I cried , what ails ye at the Campbells ?

#Text=Well , says he , ye ken very well that I am an Appin Stewart , and the Campbells have long harried and wasted those of my name ; ay , and got lands of us by treachery--but never with the sword , he cried loudly , and with the word brought down his fist upon the table .
#Text=But I paid the less attention to this , for I knew it was usually said by those who have the underhand .

#Text=There 's more than that , he continued , and all in the same story : lying words , lying papers , tricks fit for a peddler , and the show of what 's legal over all , to make a man the more angry .
#Text=You that are so wasteful of your buttons , said I , I can hardly think you would be a good judge of business .
#Text=Ah !
#Text=says he , falling again to smiling , I got my wastefulness from the same man I got the buttons from ; and that was my poor father , Duncan Stewart , grace be to him !
#Text=He was the prettiest man of his kindred ; and the best swordsman in the Hielands , David , and that is the same as to say , in all the world , I should ken , for it was him that taught me .
#Text=He was in the Black Watch , when first it was mustered ; and , like other gentlemen privates , had a gillie at his back to carry his firelock for him on the march .
#Text=Well , the King , it appears , was wishful to see Hieland swordsmanship ; and my father and three more were chosen out and sent to London town , to let him see it at the best .

#Text=So they were had into the palace and showed the whole art of the sword for two hours at a stretch , before King George and Queen Carline , and the Butcher Cumberland , and many more of whom I havenae mind .
#Text=And when they were through , the King ( for all he was a rank usurper ) spoke them fair and gave each man three guineas in his hand .

#Text=Now , as they were going out of the palace , they had a porter 's lodge to go by ; and it came in on my father , as he was perhaps the first private Hieland gentleman that had ever gone by that door , it was right he should give the poor porter a proper notion of their quality .

#Text=So he gives the King 's three guineas into the man 's hand , as if it was his common custom ; the three others that came behind him did the same ; and there they were on the street , never a penny the better for their pains .

#Text=Some say it was one , that was the first to fee the King 's porter ; and some say it was another ; but the truth of it is , that it was Duncan Stewart , as I am willing to prove with either sword or pistol .
#Text=And that was the father that I had , God rest him !
#Text=I think he was not the man to leave you rich , said I. And that 's true , said Alan .
#Text=He left me my breeks to cover me , and little besides .
#Text=And that was how I came to enlist , which was a black spot upon my character at the best of times , and would still be a sore job for me if I fell among the red-coats .
#Text=What , cried I , were you in the English army ?
#Text=That was I , said Alan .
#Text=But I deserted to the right side at Preston Pans--and that 's some comfort .
#Text=I could scarcely share this view : holding desertion under arms for an unpardonable fault in honour .
#Text=But for all I was so young , I was wiser than say my thought .
#Text=Dear , dear , says I , the punishment is death .
#Text=Ay said he , if they got hands on me , it would be a short shrift and a lang tow for Alan !
#Text=But I have the King of France 's commission in my pocket , which would aye be some protection .
#Text=I misdoubt it much , said I. I have doubts mysel ' , said Alan drily .
#Text=And , good heaven , man , cried I , you that are a condemned rebel , and a deserter , and a man of the French King's--what tempts ye back into this country ?
#Text=It 's a braving of Providence .
#Text=Tut !
#Text=says Alan , I have been back every year since forty-six !
#Text=And what brings ye , man ?
#Text=cried I. Well , ye see , I weary for my friends and country , said he .
#Text=France is a braw place , nae doubt ; but I weary for the heather and the deer .
#Text=And then I have bit things that I attend to .
#Text=Whiles I pick up a few lads to serve the King of France : recruits , ye see ; and that 's aye a little money .
#Text=But the heart of the matter is the business of my chief , Ardshiel .
#Text=I thought they called your chief Appin , said I. Ay , but Ardshiel is the captain of the clan , said he , which scarcely cleared my mind .
#Text=Ye see , David , he that was all his life so great a man , and come of the blood and bearing the name of kings , is now brought down to live in a French town like a poor and private person .
#Text=He that had four hundred swords at his whistle , I have seen , with these eyes of mine , buying butter in the market-place , and taking it home in a kale-leaf .
#Text=This is not only a pain but a disgrace to us of his family and clan .
#Text=There are the bairns forby , the children and the hope of Appin , that must be learned their letters and how to hold a sword , in that far country .

#Text=Now , the tenants of Appin have to pay a rent to King George ; but their hearts are staunch , they are true to their chief ; and what with love and a bit of pressure , and maybe a threat or two , the poor folk scrape up a second rent for Ardshiel .
#Text=Well , David , I 'm the hand that carries it .
#Text=And he struck the belt about his body , so that the guineas rang .
#Text=Do they pay both ?
#Text=cried I. Ay , David , both , says he .
#Text=What !
#Text=two rents ?
#Text=I repeated .
#Text=Ay , David , said he .
#Text=I told a different tale to yon captain man ; but this is the truth of it .
#Text=And it 's wonderful to me how little pressure is needed .
#Text=But that 's the handiwork of my good kinsman and my father 's friend , James of the Glens : James Stewart , that is : Ardshiel 's half-brother .
#Text=He it is that gets the money in , and does the management .
#Text=This was the first time I heard the name of that James Stewart , who was afterwards so famous at the time of his hanging .
#Text=But I took little heed at the moment , for all my mind was occupied with the generosity of these poor Highlanders .
#Text=I call it noble , I cried .
#Text=I 'm a Whig , or little better ; but I call it noble .
#Text=Ay said he , ye 're a Whig , but ye 're a gentleman ; and that 's what does it .
#Text=Now , if ye were one of the cursed race of Campbell , ye would gnash your teeth to hear tell of it .
#Text=If ye were the Red Fox And at that name , his teeth shut together , and he ceased speaking .
#Text=I have seen many a grim face , but never a grimmer than Alan 's when he had named the Red Fox .
#Text=And who is the Red Fox ?
#Text=I asked , daunted , but still curious .
#Text=Who is he ?
#Text=cried Alan .
#Text=Well , and I 'll tell you that .

#Text=When the men of the clans were broken at Culloden , and the good cause went down , and the horses rode over the fetlocks in the best blood of the north , Ardshiel had to flee like a poor deer upon the mountains--he and his lady and his bairns .
#Text=A sair job we had of it before we got him shipped ; and while he still lay in the heather , the English rogues , that couldnae come at his life , were striking at his rights .

#Text=They stripped him of his powers ; they stripped him of his lands ; they plucked the weapons from the hands of his clansmen , that had borne arms for thirty centuries ; ay , and the very clothes off their backs--so that it 's now a sin to wear a tartan plaid , and a man may be cast into a gaol if he has but a kilt about his legs .
#Text=to the material , or ( to make a quibble ) to the immaterial .
#Text=I have here a little packet which contains four things .
#Text=He tugged it , as he spoke , and with some great difficulty , from the skirt pocket of his coat .

#Text=Of these four things , the first is your legal due : the little pickle money for your father 's books and plenishing , which I have bought ( as I have explained from the first ) in the design of re-selling at a profit to the incoming dominie .
#Text=The other three are gifties that Mrs. Campbell and myself would be blithe of your acceptance .

#Text=The first , which is round , will likely please ye best at the first off-go ; but , O Davie , laddie , it 's but a drop of water in the sea ; it 'll help you but a step , and vanish like the morning .
#Text=The second , which is flat and square and written upon , will stand by you through life , like a good staff for the road , and a good pillow to your head in sickness .
#Text=And as for the last , which is cubical , that 'll see you , it 's my prayerful wish , into a better land .

#Text=With that he got upon his feet , took off his hat , and prayed a little while aloud , and in affecting terms , for a young man setting out into the world ; then suddenly took me in his arms and embraced me very hard ; then held me at arm 's length , looking at me with his face all working with sorrow ; and then whipped about , and crying good-bye to me , set off backward by the way that we had come at a sort of jogging run .
#Text=It might have been laughable to another ; but I was in no mind to laugh .
#Text=I watched him as long as he was in sight ; and he never stopped hurrying , nor once looked back .

#Text=Then it came in upon my mind that this was all his sorrow at my departure ; and my conscience smote me hard and fast , because I , for my part , was overjoyed to get away out of that quiet country-side , and go to a great , busy house , among rich and respected gentlefolk of my own name and blood .
#Text=Davie , Davie , I thought , was ever seen such black ingratitude ?
#Text=Can you forget old favours and old friends at the mere whistle of a name ?
#Text=Fie , fie ; think shame .
#Text=And I sat down on the boulder the good man had just left , and opened the parcel to see the nature of my gifts .
#Text=That which he had called cubical , I had never had much doubt of ; sure enough it was a little Bible , to carry in a plaid-neuk .

#Text=That which he had called round , I found to be a shilling piece ; and the third , which was to help me so wonderfully both in health and sickness all the days of my life , was a little piece of coarse yellow paper , written upon thus in red ink : TO MAKE LILLY OF THE VALLEY WATER.--Take the flowers of lilly of the valley and distil them in sack , and drink a spooneful or two as there is occasion .
#Text=It restores speech to those that have the dumb palsey .

#Text=It is good against the Gout ; it comforts the heart and strengthens the memory ; and the flowers , put into a Glasse , close stopt , and set into ane hill of ants for a month , then take it out , and you will find a liquor which comes from the flowers , which keep in a vial ; it is good , ill or well , and whether man or woman .
#Text=And then , in the minister 's own hand , was added : Likewise for sprains , rub it in ; and for the cholic , a great spooneful in the hour .

#Text=To be sure , I laughed over this ; but it was rather tremulous laughter ; and I was glad to get my bundle on my staff 's end and set out over the ford and up the hill upon the farther side ; till , just as I came on the green drove-road running wide through the heather , I took my last look of Kirk Essendean , the trees about the manse , and the big rowans in the kirkyard where my father and my mother lay .

#Text=CHAPTER II I COME TO MY JOURNEY 'S END On the forenoon of the second day , coming to the top of a hill , I saw all the country fall away before me down to the sea ; and in the midst of this descent , on a long ridge , the city of Edinburgh smoking like a kiln .

#Text=There was a flag upon the castle , and ships moving or lying anchored in the firth ; both of which , for as far away as they were , I could distinguish clearly ; and both brought my country heart into my mouth .

#Text=Presently after , I came by a house where a shepherd lived , and got a rough direction for the neighbourhood of Cramond ; and so , from one to another , worked my way to the westward of the capital by Colinton , till I came out upon the Glasgow road .

#Text=And there , to my great pleasure and wonder , I beheld a regiment marching to the fifes , every foot in time ; an old red-faced general on a grey horse at the one end , and at the other the company of Grenadiers , with their Pope's-hats .
#Text=The pride of life seemed to mount into my brain at the sight of the red coats and the hearing of that merry music .
#Text=A little farther on , and I was told I was in Cramond parish , and began to substitute in my inquiries the name of the house of Shaws .
#Text=It was a word that seemed to surprise those of whom I sought my way .
#Text=At first I thought the plainness of my appearance , in my country habit , and that all dusty from the road , consorted ill with the greatness of the place to which I was bound .
#Text=But after two , or maybe three , had given me the arrest .
#Text=It 's easier than ye would think , said Alan .
#Text=A bare hillside ( ye see ) is like all one road ; if there 's a sentry at one place , ye just go by another .
#Text=And then the heather 's a great help .
#Text=And everywhere there are friends'houses and friends'byres and haystacks .
#Text=And besides , when folk talk of a country covered with troops , it 's but a kind of a byword at the best .
#Text=A soldier covers nae mair of it than his boot-soles .

#Text=I have fished a water with a sentry on the other side of the brae , and killed a fine trout ; and I have sat in a heather bush within six feet of another , and learned a real bonny tune from his whistling .
#Text=This was it , said he , and whistled me the air .
#Text=And then , besides , he continued , it 's no sae bad now as it was in forty-six .
#Text=The Hielands are what they call pacified .
#Text=Small wonder , with never a gun or a sword left from Cantyre to Cape Wrath , but what folk have hidden in their thatch !
#Text=But what I would like to ken , David , is just how long ?
#Text=Not long , ye would think , with men like Ardshiel in exile and men like the Red Fox sitting birling the wine and oppressing the poor at home .
#Text=But it 's a kittle thing to decide what folk 'll bear , and what they will not .
#Text=Or why would Red Colin be riding his horse all over my poor country of Appin , and never a pretty lad to put a bullet in him ?
#Text=Careful .
#Text=And with this Alan fell into a muse , and for a long time sate very sad and silent .

#Text=I will add the rest of what I have to say about my friend , that he was skilled in all kinds of music , but principally pipe-music ; was a well-considered poet in his own tongue ; had read several books both in French and English ; was a dead shot , a good angler , and an excellent fencer with the small sword as well as with his own particular weapon .
#Text=For his faults , they were on his face , and I now knew them all .
#Text=But the worst of them , his childish propensity to take offence and to pick quarrels , he greatly laid aside in my case , out of regard for the battle of the round-house .
#Text=But whether it was because I had done well myself , or because I had been a witness of his own much greater prowess , is more than I can tell .
#Text=For though he had a great taste for courage in other men , yet he admired it most in Alan Breck .

#Text=CHAPTER XIII THE LOSS OF THE BRIG It was already late at night , and as dark as it ever would be at that season of the year ( and that is to say , it was still pretty bright ) , when Hoseason clapped his head into the round-house door .
#Text=Here , said he , come out and see if ye can pilot .
#Text=Is this one of your tricks ?
#Text=asked Alan .
#Text=Do I look like tricks ?
#Text=cries the captain .
#Text=I have other things to think of--my brig 's in danger !

#Text=By the concerned look of his face , and , above all , by the sharp tones in which he spoke of his brig , it was plain to both of us he was in deadly earnest ; and so Alan and I , with no great fear of treachery , stepped on deck .
#Text=The sky was clear ; it blew hard , and was bitter cold ; a great deal of daylight lingered ; and the moon , which was nearly full , shone brightly .

#Text=The brig was close hauled , so as to round the southwest corner of the Island of Mull , the hills of which ( and Ben More above them all , with a wisp of mist upon the top of it ) lay full upon the lar-board bow .
#Text=Though it was no good point of sailing for the Covenant , she tore through the seas at a great rate , pitching and straining , and pursued by the westerly swell .

#Text=Altogether it was no such ill night to keep the seas in ; and I had begun to wonder what it was that sat so heavily upon the captain , when the brig rising suddenly on the top of a high swell , he pointed and cried to us to look .
#Text=Away on the lee bow , a thing like a fountain rose out of the moonlit sea , and immediately after we heard a low sound of roaring .
#Text=What do ye call that ?
#Text=asked the captain , gloomily .
#Text=The sea breaking on a reef , said Alan .
#Text=And now ye ken where it is ; and what better would ye have ?
#Text=Ay , said Hoseason , if it was the only one .
#Text=And sure enough , just as he spoke there came a second fountain farther to the south .
#Text=There !
#Text=said Hoseason .
#Text=Ye see for yourself .
#Text=If I had kent of these reefs , if I had had a chart , or if Shuan had been spared , it 's not sixty guineas , no , nor six hundred , would have made me risk my brig in sic a stoneyard !
#Text=But you , sir , that was to pilot us , have ye never a word ?
#Text=I 'm thinking , said Alan , these 'll be what they call the Torran Rocks .
#Text=Are there many of them ?
#Text=says the captain .
#Text=Truly , sir , I am nae pilot , said Alan ; but it sticks in my mind there are ten miles of them .
#Text=Mr. Riach and the captain looked at each other .
#Text=There 's a way through them , I suppose ?
#Text=said the captain .
#Text=Doubtless , said Alan , but where ?
#Text=But it somehow runs in my mind once more that it is clearer under the land .
#Text=So ?
#Text=said Hoseason .

#Text=We 'll have to haul our wind then , Mr. Riach ; we 'll have to come as near in about the end of Mull as we can take her , sir ; and even then we 'll have the land to kep the wind off us , and that stoneyard on our lee .
#Text=Well , we 're in for it now , and may as well crack on .
#Text=With that he gave an order to the steersman , and sent Riach to the foretop .
#Text=There were only five men on deck , counting the officers ; these being all that were fit ( or , at least , both fit and willing ) for their work .
#Text=So , as I say , it fell to Mr. Riach to go aloft , and he sat there looking out and hailing the deck with news of all he saw .
#Text=The sea to the south is thick , he cried ; and then , after a while , it does seem clearer in by the land .
#Text=Well , sir , said Hoseason to Alan , we 'll try your way of it .
#Text=But I think I might as well trust to a blind fiddler .
#Text=Pray God you 're right .
#Text=Pray God I am !
#Text=says Alan to me .
#Text=But where did I hear it ?
#Text=Well , well , it will be as it must .
#Text=As we got nearer to the turn of the land the reefs began to be sown here and there on our very path ; and Mr. Riach sometimes cried down to us to change the course .
#Text=Sometimes , indeed , none too soon ; for one reef was so close on the brig 's weather board that when a sea burst upon it the lighter sprays fell upon her deck and wetted us like rain .
#Text=The brightness of the night showed us these perils as clearly as by day , which was , perhaps , the more alarming .

#Text=It showed me , too , the face of the captain as he stood by the steersman , now on one foot , now on the other , and sometimes blowing in his hands , but still listening and looking and as steady as steel .
#Text=Neither he nor Mr. Riach had shown well in the fighting ; but I saw they were brave in their own trade , and admired them all the more because I found Alan very white .
#Text=Ochone , David , says he , this is no the kind of death I fancy !
#Text=What , Alan !
#Text=I cried , you 're not afraid ?
#Text=No , said he , wetting his lips , but you 'll allow , yourself , it 's a cold ending .
#Text=By this time , now and then sheering to one side or the other to avoid a reef , but still hugging the wind and the land , we had got round Iona and begun to come alongside Mull .
#Text=The tide at the tail of the land ran very strong , and threw the brig about .

#Text=Two hands were put to the helm , and Hoseason himself would sometimes lend a help ; and it was strange to see three strong men throw their weight upon the tiller , and it ( like a living thing ) struggle against and drive them back .
#Text=This would have been the greater danger had not the sea been for some while free of obstacles .
#Text=Mr. Riach , besides , announced from the top that he saw clear water ahead .
#Text=Ye were right , said Hoseason to Alan .
#Text=Ye have saved the brig , sir .
#Text=I 'll mind that when we come to clear accounts .
#Text=And I believe he not only meant what he said , but would have done it ; so high a place did the Covenant hold in his affections .
#Text=But this is matter only for conjecture , things having gone otherwise than he forecast .
#Text=Keep her away a point , sings out Mr. Riach .
#Text=Reef to windward !
#Text=And just at the same time the tide caught the brig , and threw the wind out of her sails .

#Text=She came round into the wind like a top , and the next moment struck the reef with such a dunch as threw us all flat upon the deck , and came near to shake Mr. Riach from his place upon the mast .
#Text=I was on my feet in a minute .
#Text=The reef on which we had struck was close in under the southwest end of Mull , off a little isle they call Earraid , which lay low and black upon the larboard .

#Text=Sometimes the swell broke clean over us ; sometimes it only ground the poor brig upon the reef , so that we could hear her beat herself to pieces ; and what with the great noise of the sails , and the singing of the wind , and the flying of the spray in the moonlight , and the sense of danger , I think my head must have been partly turned , for I could scarcely understand the things I saw .
#Text=Presently I observed Mr. Riach and the seamen busy round the skiff , and , still in the same blank , ran over to assist them ; and as soon as I set my hand to work , my mind came clear again .

#Text=It was no very easy task , for the skiff lay amidships and was full of hamper , and the breaking of the heavier seas continually forced us to give over and hold on ; but we all wrought like horses while we could .

#Text=Meanwhile such of the wounded as could move came clambering out of the fore-scuttle and began to help ; while the rest that lay helpless in their bunks harrowed me with screaming and begging to be saved .
#Text=The captain took no part .
#Text=It seemed he was struck stupid .
#Text=He stood holding by the shrouds , talking to himself and groaning out aloud whenever the ship hammered on the rock .
#Text=His brig was like wife and child to him ; he had looked on , day by day , at the mishandling of poor Ransome ; but when it came to the brig , he seemed to suffer along with her .

#Text=All the time of our working at the boat , I remember only one other thing : that I asked Alan , looking across at the shore , what country it was ; and he answered , it was the worst possible for him , for it was a land of the Campbells .
#Text=We had one of the wounded men told off to keep a watch upon the seas and cry us warning .
#Text=Well , we had the boat about ready to be launched , when this man sang out pretty shrill : For God 's sake , hold on !
#Text=We knew by his tone that it was something more than ordinary ; and sure enough , there followed a sea so huge that it lifted the brig right up and canted her over on her beam .
#Text=Whether the cry came too late , or my hold was too weak , I know not ; but at the sudden tilting of the ship I was cast clean over the bulwarks into the sea .
#Text=I went down , and drank my fill , and then came up , and got a blink of the moon , and then down again .
#Text=They say a man sinks a third time for good .
#Text=I cannot be made like other folk , then ; for I would not like to write how often I went down , or how often I came up again .
#Text=All the while , I was being hurled along , and beaten upon and choked , and then swallowed whole ; and the thing was so distracting to my wits , that I was neither sorry nor afraid .
#Text=Presently , I found I was holding to a spar , which helped me somewhat .
#Text=And then all of a sudden I was in quiet water , and began to come to myself .
#Text=It was the spare yard I had got hold of , and I was amazed to see how far I had travelled from the brig .
#Text=I hailed her , indeed ; but it was plain she was already out of cry .
#Text=She was still holding together ; but whether or not they had yet launched the boat , I was too far off and too low down to see .
#Text=While I was hailing the brig , I spied a tract of water lying between us where no great waves came , but which yet boiled white all over and bristled in the moon with rings and bubbles .
#Text=Sometimes the whole tract swung to one side , like the tail of a live serpent ; sometimes , for a glimpse , it would all disappear and then boil up again .

#Text=What it was I had no guess , which for the time increased my fear of it ; but I now know it must have been the roost or tide race , which had carried me away so fast and tumbled me about so cruelly , and at last , as if tired of that play , had flung out me and the spare yard upon its landward margin .
#Text=I now lay quite becalmed , and began to feel that a man can die of cold as well as of drowning .
#Text=The shores of Earraid were close in ; I could see in the moonlight the dots of heather and the sparkling of the mica in the rocks .
#Text=Well , thought I to myself , if I cannot get as far as that , it 's strange !

#Text=I had no skill of swimming , Essen Water being small in our neighbourhood ; but when I laid hold upon the yard with both arms , and kicked out with both feet , I soon begun to find that I was moving .
#Text=Hard work it was , and mortally slow ; but in about an hour of kicking and splashing , I had got well in between the points of a sandy bay surrounded by low hills .
#Text=The sea was here quite quiet ; there was no sound of any surf ; the moon shone clear ; and I thought in my heart I had never seen a place so desert and desolate .
#Text=But it was dry land ; and when at last it grew so shallow that I could leave the yard and wade ashore upon my feet , I cannot tell if I was more tired or more grateful .
#Text=Both , at least , I was : tired as I never was before that night ; and grateful to God as I trust I have been often , though never with more cause .
#Text=CHAPTER XIV THE ISLET With my stepping ashore I began the most unhappy part of my adventures .
#Text=It was half-past twelve in the morning , and though the wind was broken by the land , it was a cold night .
#Text=I dared not sit down ( for I thought I should have frozen ) , but took off my shoes and walked to and fro upon the sand , bare-foot , and beating my breast with infinite weariness .

#Text=There was no sound of man or cattle ; not a cock crew , though it was about the hour of their first waking ; only the surf broke outside in the distance , which put me in mind of my perils and those of my friend .
#Text=To walk by the sea at that hour of the morning , and in a place so desert-like and lonesome , struck me with a kind of fear .

#Text=As soon as the day began to break I put on my shoes and climbed a hill--the ruggedest scramble I ever undertook--falling , the whole way , between big blocks of granite , or leaping from one to another .
#Text=When I got to the top the dawn was come .
#Text=There was no sign of the brig , which must have lifted from the reef and sunk .
#Text=The boat , too , was nowhere to be seen .
#Text=There was never a sail upon the ocean ; and in what I could see of the land was neither house nor man .
#Text=I was afraid to think what had befallen my shipmates , and afraid to look longer at so empty a scene .
#Text=What with my wet clothes and weariness , and my belly that now began to ache with hunger , I had enough to trouble me without that .
#Text=So I set off eastward along the south coast , hoping to find a house where I might warm myself , and perhaps get news of those I had lost .
#Text=And at the worst , I considered the sun would soon rise and dry my clothes .

#Text=After a little , my way was stopped by a creek or inlet of the sea , which seemed to run pretty deep into the land ; and as I had no means to get across , I must needs change my direction to go about the end of it .

#Text=It was still the roughest kind of walking ; indeed the whole , not only of Earraid , but of the neighbouring part of Mull ( which they call the Ross ) is nothing but a jumble of granite rocks with heather in among .
#Text=At first the creek kept narrowing as I had looked to see ; but presently to my surprise it began to widen out again .

#Text=At this I scratched my head , but had still no notion of the truth : until at last I came to a rising ground , and it burst upon me all in a moment that I was cast upon a little barren isle , and cut off on every side by the salt seas .
#Text=Instead of the sun rising to dry me , it came on to rain , with a thick mist ; so that my case was lamentable .
#Text=I stood in the rain , and shivered , and wondered what to do , till it occurred to me that perhaps the creek was fordable .
#Text=Back I went to the narrowest point and waded in .
#Text=But not three yards from shore , I plumped in head over ears ; and if ever I was heard of more , it was rather by God 's grace than my own prudence .
#Text=I was no wetter ( for that could hardly be ) , but I was all the colder for this mishap ; and having lost another hope was the more unhappy .
#Text=And now , all at once , the yard came in my head .
#Text=What had carried me through the roost would surely serve me to cross this little quiet creek in safety .
#Text=With that I set off , undaunted , across the top of the isle , to fetch and carry it back .
#Text=It was a weary tramp in all ways , and if hope had not buoyed me up , I must have cast myself down and given up .
#Text=Whether with the sea salt , or because I was growing fevered , I was distressed with thirst , and had to stop , as I went , and drink the peaty water out of the hags .
#Text=I came to the bay at last , more dead than alive ; and at the first glance , I thought the yard was something farther out than when I left it .
#Text=In I went , for the third time , into the sea .
#Text=The sand was smooth and firm , and shelved gradually down , so that I could wade out till the water was almost to my neck and the little waves splashed into my face .
#Text=But at that depth my feet began to leave me , and I durst venture in no farther .
#Text=As for the yard , I saw it bobbing very quietly some twenty feet beyond .
#Text=I had borne up well until this last disappointment ; but at that I came ashore , and flung myself down upon the sands and wept .
#Text=The time I spent upon the island is still so horrible a thought to me , that I must pass it lightly over .
#Text=In all the books I have read of people cast away , they had either their pockets full of tools , or a chest of things would be thrown upon the beach along with them , as if on purpose .
#Text=My case was very different .
#Text=I had nothing in my pockets but money and Alan 's silver button ; and being inland bred , I was as much short of knowledge as of means .

#Text=I knew indeed that shell-fish were counted good to eat ; and among the rocks of the isle I found a great plenty of limpets , which at first I could scarcely strike from their places , not knowing quickness to be needful .
#Text=There were , besides , some of the little shells that we call buckies ; I think periwinkle is the English name .
#Text=Of these two I made my whole diet , devouring them cold and raw as I found them ; and so hungry was I , that at first they seemed to me delicious .
#Text=Perhaps they were out of season , or perhaps there was something wrong in the sea about my island .
#Text=But at least I had no sooner eaten my first meal than I was seized with giddiness and retching , and lay for a long time no better than dead .
#Text=A second trial of the same food ( indeed I had no other ) did better with me , and revived my strength .

#Text=But as long as I was on the island , I never knew what to expect when I had eaten ; sometimes all was well , and sometimes I was thrown into a miserable sickness ; nor could I ever distinguish what particular fish it was that hurt me .

#Text=All day it streamed rain ; the island ran like a sop , there was no dry spot to be found ; and when I lay down that night , between two boulders that made a kind of roof , my feet were in a bog .
#Text=The second day I crossed the island to all sides .

#Text=There was no one part of it better than another ; it was all desolate and rocky ; nothing living on it but game birds which I lacked the means to kill , and the gulls which haunted the outlying rocks in a prodigious number .

#Text=But the creek , or strait , that cut off the isle from the main-land of the Ross , opened out on the north into a bay , and the bay again opened into the Sound of Iona ; and it was the neighbourhood of this place that I chose to be my home ; though if I had thought upon the very name of home in such a spot , I must have burst out weeping .
#Text=I had good reasons for my choice .

#Text=There was in this part of the isle a little hut of a house like a pig 's hut , where fishers used to sleep when they came there upon their business ; but the turf roof of it had fallen entirely in ; so that the hut was of no use to me , and gave me less shelter than my rocks .
#Text=What was more important , the shell-fish on which I lived grew there in great plenty ; when the tide was out I could gather a peck at a time : and this was doubtless a convenience .
#Text=But the other reason went deeper .

#Text=I had become in no way used to the horrid solitude of the isle , but still looked round me on all sides ( like a man that was hunted ) , between fear and hope that I might see some human creature coming .
#Text=Now , from a little up the hillside over the bay , I could catch a sight of the great , ancient church and the roofs of the people 's houses in Iona .
#Text=And on the other hand , over the low country of the Ross , I saw smoke go up , morning and evening , as if from a homestead in a hollow of the land .
#Text=I used to watch this smoke , when I was wet and cold , and had my head half turned with loneliness ; and think of the fireside and the company , till my heart burned .
#Text=It was the same with the roofs of Iona .

#Text=Altogether , this sight I had of men 's homes and comfortable lives , although it put a point on my own sufferings , yet it kept hope alive , and helped me to eat my raw shell-fish ( which had soon grown to be a disgust ) , and saved me from the sense of horror I had whenever I was quite alone with dead rocks , and fowls , and the rain , and the cold sea .
#Text=I say it kept hope alive ; and indeed it seemed impossible that I should be left to die on the shores of my own country , and within view of a church-tower and the smoke of men 's houses .
#Text=But the second day passed ; and though as long as the light lasted I kept a bright look-out for boats on the Sound or men passing on the Ross , no help came near me .

#Text=It still rained , and I turned in to sleep , as wet as ever , and with a cruel sore throat , but a little comforted , perhaps , by having said good-night to my next neighbours , the people of Iona .
#Text=Charles the Second declared a man could stay outdoors more days in the year in the climate of England than in any other .
#Text=This was very like a king , with a palace at his back and changes of dry clothes .
#Text=But he must have had better luck on his flight from Worcester than I had on that miserable isle .
#Text=It was the height of the summer ; yet it rained for more than twenty-four hours , and did not clear until the afternoon of the third day .
#Text=This was the day of incidents .

#Text=In the morning I saw a red deer , a buck with a fine spread of antlers , standing in the rain on the top of the island ; but he had scarce seen me rise from under my rock , before he trotted off upon the other side .
#Text=I supposed he must have swum the strait ; though what should bring any creature to Earraid , was more than I could fancy .
#Text=A little after , as I was jumping about after my limpets , I was startled by a guinea-piece , which fell upon a rock in front of me and glanced off into the sea .

#Text=When the sailors gave me my money again , they kept back not only about a third of the whole sum , but my father 's leather purse ; so that from that day out , I carried my gold loose in a pocket with a button .
#Text=I now saw there must be a hole , and clapped my hand to the place in a great hurry .
#Text=But this was to lock the stable door after the steed was stolen .
#Text=I had left the shore at Queensferry with near on fifty pounds ; now I found no more than two guinea-pieces and a silver shilling .
#Text=It is true I picked up a third guinea a little after , where it lay shining on a piece of turf .
#Text=That made a fortune of three pounds and four shillings , English money , for a lad , the rightful heir of an estate , and now starving on an isle at the extreme end of the wild Highlands .
#Text=This state of my affairs dashed me still further ; and , indeed my plight on that third morning was truly pitiful .

#Text=My clothes were beginning to rot ; my stockings in particular were quite worn through , so that my shanks went naked ; my hands had grown quite soft with the continual soaking ; my throat was very sore , my strength had much abated , and my heart so turned against the horrid stuff I was condemned to eat , that the very sight of it came near to sicken me .
#Text=And yet the worst was not yet come .

#Text=There is a pretty high rock on the northwest of Earraid , which ( because it had a flat top and overlooked the Sound ) I was much in the habit of frequenting ; not that ever I stayed in one place , save when asleep , my misery giving me no rest .
#Text=Indeed , I wore myself down with continual and aimless goings and comings in the rain .
#Text=As soon , however , as the sun came out , I lay down on the top of that rock to dry myself .
#Text=The comfort of the sunshine is a thing I cannot tell .
#Text=It set me thinking hopefully of my deliverance , of which I had begun to despair ; and I scanned the sea and the Ross with a fresh interest .
#Text=On the south of my rock , a part of the island jutted out and hid the open ocean , so that a boat could thus come quite near me upon that side , and I be none the wiser .
#Text=Well , all of a sudden , a coble with a brown sail and a pair of fishers aboard of it , came flying round that corner of the isle , bound for Iona .
#Text=I shouted out , and then fell on my knees on the rock and reached up my hands and prayed to them .
#Text=They were near enough to hear--I could even see the colour of their hair ; and there was no doubt but they observed me , for they cried out in the Gaelic tongue , and laughed .
#Text=But the boat never turned aside , and flew on , right before my eyes , for Iona .

#Text=I could not believe such wickedness , and ran along the shore from rock to rock , crying on them piteously even after they were out of reach of my voice , I still cried and waved to them ; and when they were quite gone , I thought my heart would have burst .
#Text=All the time of my troubles I wept only twice .
#Text=Once , when I could not reach the yard , and now , the second time , when these fishers turned a deaf ear to my cries .
#Text=But this time I wept and roared like a wicked child , tearing up the turf with my nails , and grinding my face in the earth .
#Text=If a wish would kill men , those two fishers would never have seen morning , and I should likely have died upon my island .
#Text=When I was a little over my anger , I must eat again , but with such loathing of the mess as I could now scarce control .
#Text=Sure enough , I should have done as well to fast , for my fishes poisoned me again .

#Text=I had all my first pains ; my throat was so sore I could scarce swallow ; I had a fit of strong shuddering , which clucked my teeth together ; and there came on me that dreadful sense of illness , which we have no name for either in Scotch or English .

#Text=I thought I should have died , and made my peace with God , forgiving all men , even my uncle and the fishers ; and as soon as I had thus made up my mind to the worst , clearness came upon me ; I observed the night was falling dry ; my clothes were dried a good deal ; truly , I was in a better case than ever before , since I had landed on the isle ; and so I got to sleep at last , with a thought of gratitude .
#Text=The next day ( which was the fourth of this horrible life of mine ) I found my bodily strength run very low .
#Text=But the sun shone , the air was sweet , and what I managed to eat of the shell-fish agreed well with me and revived my courage .
#Text=I was scarce back on my rock ( where I went always the first thing after I had eaten ) before I observed a boat coming down the Sound , and with her head , as I thought , in my direction .
#Text=I began at once to hope and fear exceedingly ; for I thought these men might have thought better of their cruelty and be coming back to my assistance .
#Text=But another disappointment , such as yesterday 's , was more than I could bear .
#Text=I turned my back , accordingly , upon the sea , and did not look again till I had counted many hundreds .
#Text=The boat was still heading for the island .
#Text=The next time I counted the full thousand , as slowly as I could , my heart beating so as to hurt me .
#Text=And then it was out of all question .
#Text=She was coming straight to Earraid !
#Text=I could no longer hold myself back , but ran to the seaside and out , from one rock to another , as far as I could go .
#Text=It is a marvel I was not drowned ; for when I was brought to a stand at last , my legs shook under me , and my mouth was so dry , I must wet it with the sea-water before I was able to shout .
#Text=All this time the boat was coming on ; and now I was able to perceive it was the same boat and the same two men as yesterday .
#Text=This I knew by their hair , which the one had of a bright yellow and the other black .
#Text=But now there was a third man along with them , who looked to be of a better class .
#Text=As soon as they were come within easy speech , they let down their sail and lay quiet .
#Text=In spite of my supplications , they drew no nearer in , and what frightened me most of all , the new man tee-hee 'd with laughter as he talked and looked at me .
#Text=Then he stood up in the boat and addressed me a long while , speaking fast and with many wavings of his hand .
#Text=I told him I had no Gaelic ; and at this he became very angry , and I began to suspect he thought he was talking English .
#Text=Listening very close , I caught the word whateffer several times ; but all the rest was Gaelic and might have been Greek and Hebrew for me .
#Text=Whatever , said I , to show him I had caught a word .
#Text=Yes , yes--yes , yes , says he , and then he looked at the other men , as much as to say , I told you I spoke English , and began again as hard as ever in the Gaelic .
#Text=This time I picked out another word , tide .
#Text=Then I had a flash of hope .
#Text=I remembered he was always waving his hand towards the mainland of the Ross .
#Text=Do you mean when the tide is out -- ?
#Text=I cried , and could not finish .
#Text=Yes , yes , said he .
#Text=Tide .

#Text=At that I turned tail upon their boat ( where my adviser had once more begun to tee-hee with laughter ) , leaped back the way I had come , from one stone to another , and set off running across the isle as I had never run before .

#Text=In about half an hour I came out upon the shores of the creek ; and , sure enough , it was shrunk into a little trickle of water , through which I dashed , not above my knees , and landed with a shout on the main island .

#Text=A sea-bred boy would not have stayed a day on Earraid ; which is only what they call a tidal islet , and except in the bottom of the neaps , can be entered and left twice in every twenty-four hours , either dry-shod , or at the most by wading .

#Text=Even I , who had the tide going out and in before me in the bay , and even watched for the ebbs , the better to get my shellfish--even I ( I say ) if I had sat down to think , instead of raging at my fate , must have soon guessed the secret , and got free .
#Text=It was no wonder the fishers had not understood me .
#Text=The wonder was rather that they had ever guessed my pitiful illusion , and taken the trouble to come back .
#Text=I had starved with cold and hunger on that island for close upon one hundred hours .
#Text=But for the fishers , I might have left my bones there , in pure folly .

#Text=And even as it was , I had paid for it pretty dear , not only in past sufferings , but in my present case ; being clothed like a beggar-man , scarce able to walk , and in great pain of my sore throat .
#Text=I have seen wicked men and fools , a great many of both ; and I believe they both get paid in the end ; but the fools first .

#Text=CHAPTER XV THE LAD WITH THE SILVER BUTTON : THROUGH THE ISLE OF MULL The Ross of Mull , which I had now got upon , was rugged and trackless , like the isle I had just left ; being all bog , and brier , and big stone .
#Text=There may be roads for them that know that country well ; but for my part I had no better guide than my own nose , and no other landmark than Ben More .

#Text=I aimed as well as I could for the smoke I had seen so often from the island ; and with all my great weariness and the difficulty of the way came upon the house in the bottom of a little hollow about five or six at night .
#Text=It was low and longish , roofed with turf and built of unmortared stones ; and on a mound in front of it , an old gentleman sat smoking his pipe in the sun .
#Text=With what little English he had , he gave me to understand that my shipmates had got safe ashore , and had broken bread in that very house on the day after .
#Text=Was there one , I asked , dressed like a gentleman ?
#Text=He said they all wore rough great-coats ; but to be sure , the first of them , the one that came alone , wore breeches and stockings , while the rest had sailors'trousers .
#Text=Ah , said I , and he would have a feathered hat ?
#Text=He told me , no , that he was bareheaded like myself .
#Text=At first I thought Alan might have lost his hat ; and then the rain came in my mind , and I judged it more likely he had it out of harm 's way under his great-coat .
#Text=This set me smiling , partly because my friend was safe , partly to think of his vanity in dress .
#Text=And then the old gentleman clapped his hand to his brow , and cried out that I must be the lad with the silver button .
#Text=Why , yes !
#Text=said I , in some wonder .
#Text=Well , then , said the old gentleman , I have a word for you , that you are to follow your friend to his country , by Torosay .
#Text=He then asked me how I had fared , and I told him my tale .

#Text=A south-country man would certainly have laughed ; but this old gentleman ( I call him so because of his manners , for his clothes were dropping off his back ) heard me all through with nothing but gravity and pity .
#Text=When I had done , he took me by the hand , led me into his hut ( it was no better ) and presented me before his wife , as if she had been the Queen and I a duke .

#Text=The good woman set oat-bread before me and a cold grouse , patting my shoulder and smiling to me all the time , for she had no English ; and the old gentleman ( not to be behind ) brewed me a strong punch out of their country spirit .

#Text=All the while I was eating , and after that when I was drinking the punch , I could scarce come to believe in my good fortune ; and the house , though it was thick with the peat-smoke and as full of holes as a colander , seemed like a palace .

#Text=The punch threw me in a strong sweat and a deep slumber ; the good people let me lie ; and it was near noon of the next day before I took the road , my throat already easier and my spirits quite restored by good fare and good news .

#Text=The old gentleman , although I pressed him hard , would take no money , and gave me an old bonnet for my head ; though I am free to own I was no sooner out of view of the house than I very jealously washed this gift of his in a wayside fountain .
#Text=Thought I to myself : If these are the wild Highlanders , I could wish my own folk wilder .
#Text=I not only started late , but I must have wandered nearly half the time .
#Text=True , I met plenty of people , grubbing in little miserable fields that would not keep a cat , or herding little kine about the bigness of asses .
#Text=The Highland dress being forbidden by law since the rebellion , and the people condemned to the Lowland habit , which they much disliked , it was strange to see the variety of their array .

#Text=Some went bare , only for a hanging cloak or great-coat , and carried their trousers on their backs like a useless burthen : some had made an imitation of the tartan with little parti-coloured stripes patched together like an old wife 's quilt ; others , again , still wore the Highland philabeg , but by putting a few stitches between the legs transformed it into a pair of trousers like a Dutchman 's .

#Text=All those makeshifts were condemned and punished , for the law was harshly applied , in hopes to break up the clan spirit ; but in that out-of-the-way , sea-bound isle , there were few to make remarks and fewer to tell tales .

#Text=They seemed in great poverty ; which was no doubt natural , now that rapine was put down , and the chiefs kept no longer an open house ; and the roads ( even such a wandering , country by-track as the one I followed ) were infested with beggars .
#Text=And here again I marked a difference from my own part of the country .

#Text=For our Lowland beggars--even the gownsmen themselves , who beg by patent--had a louting , flattering way with them , and if you gave them a plaek and asked change , would very civilly return you a boddle .
#Text=But these Highland beggars stood on their dignity , asked alms only to buy snuff ( by their account ) and would give no change .
#Text=To be sure , this was no concern of mine , except in so far as it entertained me by the way .
#Text=What was much more to the purpose , few had any English , and these few ( unless they were of the brotherhood of beggars ) not very anxious to place it at my service .

#Text=I knew Torosay to be my destination , and repeated the name to them and pointed ; but instead of simply pointing in reply , they would give me a screed of the Gaelic that set me foolish ; so it was small wonder if I went out of my road as often as I stayed in it .

#Text=At last , about eight at night , and already very weary , I came to a lone house , where I asked admittance , and was refused , until I bethought me of the power of money in so poor a country , and held up one of my guineas in my finger and thumb .

#Text=Thereupon , the man of the house , who had hitherto pretended to have no English , and driven me from his door by signals , suddenly began to speak as clearly as was needful , and agreed for five shillings to give me a night 's lodging and guide me the next day to Torosay .
#Text=I slept uneasily that night , fearing I should be robbed ; but I might have spared myself the pain ; for my host was no robber , only miserably poor and a great cheat .
#Text=He was not alone in his poverty ; for the next morning , we must go five miles about to the house of what he called a rich man to have one of my guineas changed .

#Text=This was perhaps a rich man for Mull ; he would have scarce been thought so in the south ; for it took all he had--the whole house was turned upside down , and a neighbour brought under contribution , before he could scrape together twenty shillings in silver .
#Text=The odd shilling he kept for himself , protesting he could ill afford to have so great a sum of money lying locked up .

#Text=For all that he was very courteous and well spoken , made us both sit down with his family to dinner , and brewed punch in a fine china bowl , over which my rascal guide grew so merry that he refused to start .
#Text=I was for getting angry , and appealed to the rich man ( Hector Maclean was his name ) , who had been a witness to our bargain and to my payment of the five shillings .
