#Text=But Maclean had taken his share of the punch , and vowed that no gentleman should leave his table after the bowl was brewed ; so there was nothing for it but to sit and hear Jacobite toasts and Gaelic songs , till all were tipsy and staggered off to the bed or the barn for their night 's rest .

#Text=Next day ( the fourth of my travels ) we were up before five upon the clock ; but my rascal guide got to the bottle at once , and it was three hours before I had him clear of the house , and then ( as you shall hear ) only for a worse disappointment .

#Text=As long as we went down a heathery valley that lay before Mr. Maclean 's house , all went well ; only my guide looked constantly over his shoulder , and when I asked him the cause , only grinned at me .

#Text=No sooner , however , had we crossed the back of a hill , and got out of sight of the house windows , than he told me Torosay lay right in front , and that a hill-top ( which he pointed out ) was my best landmark .
#Text=I care very little for that , said I , since you are going with me .
#Text=The impudent cheat answered me in the Gaelic that he had no English .
#Text=My fine fellow , I said , I know very well your English comes and goes .
#Text=Tell me what will bring it back ?
#Text=Is it more money you wish ?
#Text=Five shillings mair , said he , and hersel'will bring ye there .
#Text=I reflected awhile and then offered him two , which he accepted greedily , and insisted on having in his hands at once for luck , as he said , but I think it was rather for my misfortune .
#Text=The two shillings carried him not quite as many miles ; at the end of which distance , he sat down upon the wayside and took off his brogues from his feet , like a man about to rest .
#Text=I was now red-hot .
#Text=Ha !
#Text=said I , have you no more English ?
#Text=He said impudently , No. At that I boiled over , and lifted my hand to strike him ; and he , drawing a knife from his rags , squatted back and grinned at me like a wildcat .
#Text=At that , forgetting everything but my anger , I ran in upon him , put aside his knife with my left , and struck him in the mouth with the right .
#Text=I was a strong lad and very angry , and he but a little man ; and he went down before me heavily .
#Text=By good luck , his knife flew out of his hand as he fell .
#Text=I picked up both that and his brogues , wished him a good morning , and set off upon my way , leaving him barefoot and disarmed .
#Text=I chuckled to myself as I went , being sure I was done with that rogue , for a variety of reasons .

#Text=First , he knew he could have no more of my money ; next , the brogues were worth in that country only a few pence ; and , lastly , the knife , which was really a dagger , it was against the law for him to carry .
#Text=In about half an hour of walk , I overtook a great , ragged man , moving pretty fast but feeling before him with a staff .
#Text=He was quite blind , and told me he was a catechist , which should have put me at my ease .

#Text=But his face went against me ; it seemed dark and dangerous and secret ; and presently , as we began to go on alongside , I saw the steel butt of a pistol sticking from under the flap of his coat-pocket .
#Text=To carry such a thing meant a fine of fifteen pounds sterling upon a first offence , and transportation to the colonies upon a second .
#Text=Nor could I quite see why a religious teacher should go armed , or what a blind man could be doing with a pistol .
#Text=I told him about my guide , for I was proud of what I had done , and my vanity for once got the heels of my prudence .
#Text=At the mention of the five shillings he cried out so loud that I made up my mind I should say nothing of the other two , and was glad he could not see my blushes .
#Text=Was it too much ?
#Text=I asked , a little faltering .
#Text=Too much !
#Text=cries he .
#Text=Why , I will guide you to Torosay myself for a dram of brandy .
#Text=And give you the great pleasure of my company ( me that is a man of some learning ) in the bargain .
#Text=I said I did not see how a blind man could be a guide ; but at that he laughed aloud , and said his stick was eyes enough for an eagle .
#Text=In the Isle of Mull , at least , says he , where I know every stone and heather-bush by mark of head .

#Text=See , now , he said , striking right and left , as if to make sure , down there a burn is running ; and at the head of it there stands a bit of a small hill with a stone cocked upon the top of that ; and it 's hard at the foot of the hill , that the way runs by to Torosay ; and the way here , being for droves , is plainly trodden , and will show grassy through the heather .
#Text=I had to own he was right in every feature , and told my wonder .
#Text=Ha !
#Text=says he , that 's nothing .
#Text=Would ye believe me now , that before the Act came out , and when there were weepons in this country , I could shoot ?
#Text=Ay , could I !
#Text=cries he , and then with a leer : If ye had such a thing as a pistol here to try with , I would show ye how it 's done .
#Text=I told him I had nothing of the sort , and gave him a wider berth .
#Text=If he had known , his pistol stuck at that time quite plainly out of his pocket , and I could see the sun twinkle on the steel of the butt .
#Text=But by the better luck for me , he knew nothing , thought all was covered , and lied on in the dark .

#Text=He then began to question me cunningly , where I came from , whether I was rich , whether I could change a five-shilling piece for him ( which he declared he had that moment in his sporran ) , and all the time he kept edging up to me and I avoiding him .
#Text=We were now upon a sort of green cattle-track which crossed the hills towards Torosay , and we kept changing sides upon that like dancers in a reel .

#Text=I had so plainly the upper-hand that my spirits rose , and indeed I took a pleasure in this game of blindman 's buff ; but the catechist grew angrier and angrier , and at last began to swear in Gaelic and to strike for my legs with his staff .
#Text=Then I told him that , sure enough , I had a pistol in my pocket as well as he , and if he did not strike across the hill due south I would even blow his brains out .
#Text=He became at once very polite , and after trying to soften me for some time , but quite in vain , he cursed me once more in Gaelic and took himself off .
#Text=I watched him striding along , through bog and brier , tapping with his stick , until he turned the end of a hill and disappeared in the next hollow .
#Text=Then I struck on again for Torosay , much better pleased to be alone than to travel with that man of learning .
#Text=This was an unlucky day ; and these two , of whom I had just rid myself , one after the other , were the two worst men I met with in the Highlands .

#Text=At Torosay , on the Sound of Mull and looking over to the mainland of Morven , there was an inn with an innkeeper , who was a Maclean , it appeared , of a very high family ; for to keep an inn is thought even more genteel in the Highlands than it is with us , perhaps as partaking of hospitality , or perhaps because the trade is idle and drunken .
#Text=He spoke good English , and finding me to be something of a scholar , tried me first in French , where he easily beat me , and then in the Latin , in which I do n't know which of us did best .

#Text=This pleasant rivalry put us at once upon friendly terms ; and I sat up and drank punch with him ( or to be more correct , sat up and watched him drink it ) , until he was so tipsy that he wept upon my shoulder .
#Text=I tried him , as if by accident , with a sight of Alan 's button ; but it was plain he had never seen or heard of it .

#Text=Indeed , he bore some grudge against the family and friends of Ardshiel , and before he was drunk he read me a lampoon , in very good Latin , but with a very ill meaning , which he had made in elegiac verses upon a person of that house .
#Text=When I told him of my catechist , he shook his head , and said I was lucky to have got clear off .

#Text=That is a very dangerous man , he said ; Duncan Mackiegh is his name ; he can shoot by the ear at several yards , and has same look and the same answer , I began to take it in my head there was something strange about the Shaws itself .

#Text=The better to set this fear at rest , I changed the form of my inquiries ; and spying an honest fellow coming along a lane on the shaft of his cart , I asked him if he had ever heard tell of a house they called the house of Shaws .
#Text=He stopped his cart and looked at me , like the others .
#Text=Ay said he .
#Text=What for ?
#Text=It 's a great house ?
#Text=I asked .
#Text=Doubtless , says he .
#Text=The house is a big , muckle house .
#Text=Ay , said I , but the folk that are in it ?
#Text=Folk ?
#Text=cried he .
#Text=Are ye daft ?
#Text=There 's nae folk there--to call folk .
#Text=What ?
#Text=say I ; not Mr. Ebenezer ?
#Text=Ou , ay says the man ; there 's the laird , to be sure , if it 's him you 're wanting .
#Text=What 'll like be your business , mannie ?
#Text=I was led to think that I would get a situation , I said , looking as modest as I could .
#Text=What ?

#Text=cries the carter , in so sharp a note that his very horse started ; and then , Well , mannie , he added , it 's nane of my affairs ; but ye seem a decent-spoken lad ; and if ye 'll take a word from me , ye 'll keep clear of the Shaws .

#Text=The next person I came across was a dapper little man in a beautiful white wig , whom I saw to be a barber on his rounds ; and knowing well that barbers were great gossips , I asked him plainly what sort of a man was Mr. Balfour of the Shaws .

#Text=Hoot , hoot , hoot , said the barber , nae kind of a man , nae kind of a man at all ; and began to ask me very shrewdly what my business was ; but I was more than a match for him at that , and he went on to his next customer no wiser than he came .
#Text=I cannot well describe the blow this dealt to my illusions .
#Text=The more indistinct the accusations were , the less I liked them , for they left the wider field to fancy .
#Text=What kind of a great house was this , that all the parish should start and stare to be asked the way to it ?
#Text=or what sort of a gentleman , that his ill-fame should be thus current on the wayside ?
#Text=If an hour 's walking would have brought me back to Essendean , I had left my adventure then and there , and returned to Mr. Campbell 's .

#Text=But when I had come so far a way already , mere shame would not suffer me to desist till I had put the matter to the touch of proof ; I was bound , out of mere self-respect , to carry it through ; and little as I liked the sound of what I heard , and slow as I began to travel , I still kept asking my way and still kept advancing .

#Text=It was drawing on to sundown when I met a stout , dark , sour-looking woman coming trudging down a hill ; and she , when I had put my usual question , turned sharp about , accompanied me back to the summit she had just left , and pointed to a great bulk of building standing very bare upon a green in the bottom of the next valley .

#Text=The country was pleasant round about , running in low hills , pleasantly watered and wooded , and the crops , to my eyes , wonderfully good ; but the house itself appeared to be a kind of ruin ; no road led up to it ; no smoke arose from any of the chimneys ; nor was there any semblance of a garden .
#Text=My heart sank .
#Text=That !
#Text=I cried .
#Text=The woman 's face lit up with a malignant anger .
#Text=That is the house of Shaws !
#Text=she cried .
#Text=Blood built it ; blood stopped the building of it ; blood shall bring it down .
#Text=See here !
#Text=she cried again--I spit upon the ground , and crack my thumb at it !
#Text=Black be its fall !

#Text=If ye see the laird , tell him what ye hear ; tell him this makes the twelve hunner and nineteen time that Jennet Clouston has called down the curse on him and his house , byre and stable , man , guest , and master , wife , miss , or bairn--black , black be their fall !
#Text=And the woman , whose voice had risen to a kind of eldritch sing-song , turned with a skip , and was gone .
#Text=I stood where she left me , with my hair on end .

#Text=In those days folk still believed in witches and trembled at a curse ; and this one , falling so pat , like a wayside omen , to arrest me ere I carried out my purpose , took the pith out of my legs .
#Text=I sat me down and stared at the house of Shaws .

#Text=The more I looked , the pleasanter that country-side appeared ; being all set with hawthorn bushes full of flowers ; the fields dotted with sheep ; a fine flight of rooks in the sky ; and every sign of a kind soil and climate ; and yet the barrack in the midst of it went sore against my fancy .
#Text=Country folk went by from the fields as I sat there on the side of the ditch , but I lacked the spirit to give them a good-e'en .

#Text=At last the sun went down , and then , right up against the yellow sky , I saw a scroll of smoke go mounting , not much thicker , as it seemed to me , than the smoke of a candle ; but still there it was , and meant a fire , and warmth , and cookery , and some living inhabitant that must have lit it ; and this comforted my heart .
#Text=So I set forward by a little faint track in the grass that led in my direction .
#Text=It was very faint indeed to be the only way to a place of habitation ; yet I saw no other .
#Text=Presently it brought me to stone uprights , with an unroofed lodge beside them , and coats of arms upon the top .
#Text=A main entrance it was plainly meant to be , but never finished ; been often accused of highway robberies , and once of murder .
#Text=The cream of it is , says I , that he called himself a catechist .
#Text=And why should he not ?
#Text=says he , when that is what he is .
#Text=It was Maclean of Duart gave it to him because he was blind .

#Text=But perhaps it was a peety , says my host , for he is always on the road , going from one place to another to hear the young folk say their religion ; and , doubtless , that is a great temptation to the poor man .

#Text=At last , when my landlord could drink no more , he showed me to a bed , and I lay down in very good spirits ; having travelled the greater part of that big and crooked Island of Mull , from Earraid to Torosay , fifty miles as the crow flies , and ( with my wanderings ) much nearer a hundred , in four days and with little fatigue .
#Text=Indeed I was by far in better heart and health of body at the end of that long tramp than I had been at the beginning .
#Text=CHAPTER XVI THE LAD WITH THE SILVER BUTTON : ACROSS MORVEN There is a regular ferry from Torosay to Kinlochaline on the mainland .
#Text=Both shores of the Sound are in the country of the strong clan of the Macleans , and the people that passed the ferry with me were almost all of that clan .

#Text=The skipper of the boat , on the other hand , was called Neil Roy Macrob ; and since Macrob was one of the names of Alan 's clansmen , and Alan himself had sent me to that ferry , I was eager to come to private speech of Neil Roy .
#Text=In the crowded boat this was of course impossible , and the passage was a very slow affair .
#Text=There was no wind , and as the boat was wretchedly equipped , we could pull but two oars on one side , and one on the other .
#Text=The men gave way , however , with a good will , the passengers taking spells to help them , and the whole company giving the time in Gaelic boat-songs .
#Text=And what with the songs , and the sea-air , and the good-nature and spirit of all concerned , and the bright weather , the passage was a pretty thing to have seen .
#Text=But there was one melancholy part .

#Text=In the mouth of Loch Aline we found a great sea-going ship at anchor ; and this I supposed at first to be one of the King 's cruisers which were kept along that coast , both summer and winter , to prevent communication with the French .

#Text=As we got a little nearer , it became plain she was a ship of merchandise ; and what still more puzzled me , not only her decks , but the sea-beach also , were quite black with people , and skiffs were continually plying to and fro between them .
#Text=Yet nearer , and there began to come to our ears a great sound of mourning , the people on board and those on the shore crying and lamenting one to another so as to pierce the heart .
#Text=Then I understood this was an emigrant ship bound for the American colonies .
#Text=We put the ferry-boat alongside , and the exiles leaned over the bulwarks , weeping and reaching out their hands to my fellow-passengers , among whom they counted some near friends .

#Text=How long this might have gone on I do not know , for they seemed to have no sense of time : but at last the captain of the ship , who seemed near beside himself ( and no great wonder ) in the midst of this crying and confusion , came to the side and begged us to depart .

#Text=Thereupon Neil sheered off ; and the chief singer in our boat struck into a melancholy air , which was presently taken up both by the emigrants and their friends upon the beach , so that it sounded from all sides like a lament for the dying .

#Text=I saw the tears run down the cheeks of the men and women in the boat , even as they bent at the oars ; and the circumstances and the music of the song ( which is one called Lochaber no more ) were highly affecting even to myself .
#Text=At Kinlochaline I got Neil Roy upon one side on the beach , and said I made sure he was one of Appin 's men .
#Text=And what for no ?
#Text=said he .
#Text=I am seeking somebody , said I ; and it comes in my mind that you will have news of him .
#Text=Alan Breck Stewart is his name .
#Text=And very foolishly , instead of showing him the button , I sought to pass a shilling in his hand .
#Text=At this he drew back .
#Text=I am very much affronted , he said ; and this is not the way that one shentleman should behave to another at all .
#Text=The man you ask for is in France ; but if he was in my sporran , says he , and your belly full of shillings , I would not hurt a hair upon his body .
#Text=I saw I had gone the wrong way to work , and without wasting time upon apologies , showed him the button lying in the hollow of my palm .
#Text=Aweel , aweel , said Neil ; and I think ye might have begun with that end of the stick , whatever !
#Text=But if ye are the lad with the silver button , all is well , and I have the word to see that ye come safe .

#Text=But if ye will pardon me to speak plainly , says he , there is a name that you should never take into your mouth , and that is the name of Alan Breck ; and there is a thing that ye would never do , and that is to offer your dirty money to a Hieland shentleman .
#Text=It was not very easy to apologise ; for I could scarce tell him ( what was the truth ) that I had never dreamed he would set up to be a gentleman until he told me so .
#Text=Neil on his part had no wish to prolong his dealings with me , only to fulfil his orders and be done with it ; and he made haste to give me my route .

#Text=This was to lie the night in Kinlochaline in the public inn ; to cross Morven the next day to Ardgour , and lie the night in the house of one John of the Claymore , who was warned that I might come ; the third day , to be set across one loch at Corran and another at Balachulish , and then ask my way to the house of James of the Glens , at Aucharn in Duror of Appin .
#Text=There was a good deal of ferrying , as you hear ; the sea in all this part running deep into the mountains and winding about their roots .
#Text=It makes the country strong to hold and difficult to travel , but full of prodigious wild and dreadful prospects .

#Text=I had some other advice from Neil : to speak with no one by the way , to avoid Whigs , Campbells , and the red-soldiers ; to leave the road and lie in a bush if I saw any of the latter coming , for it was never chancy to meet in with them ; and in brief , to conduct myself like a robber or a Jacobite agent , as perhaps Neil thought me .
#Text=The inn at Kinlochaline was the most beggarly vile place that ever pigs were styed in , full of smoke , vermin , and silent Highlanders .
#Text=I was not only discontented with my lodging , but with myself for my mismanagement of Neil , and thought I could hardly be worse off .

#Text=But very wrongly , as I was soon to see ; for I had not been half an hour at the inn ( standing in the door most of the time , to ease my eyes from the peat smoke ) when a thunderstorm came close by , the springs broke in a little hill on which the inn stood , and one end of the house became a running water .

#Text=Places of public entertainment were bad enough all over Scotland in those days ; yet it was a wonder to myself , when I had to go from the fireside to the bed in which I slept , wading over the shoes .

#Text=Early in my next day 's journey I overtook a little , stout , solemn man , walking very slowly with his toes turned out , sometimes reading in a book and sometimes marking the place with his finger , and dressed decently and plainly in something of a clerical style .

#Text=This I found to be another catechist , but of a different order from the blind man of Mull : being indeed one of those sent out by the Edinburgh Society for Propagating Christian Knowledge , to evangelise the more savage places of the Highlands .

#Text=His name was Henderland ; he spoke with the broad south-country tongue , which I was beginning to weary for the sound of ; and besides common countryship , we soon found we had a more particular bond of interest .
#Text=For my good friend , the minister of Essendean , had translated into the Gaelic in his by-time a number of hymns and pious books which Henderland used in his work , and held in great esteem .
#Text=Indeed , it was one of these he was carrying and reading when we met .
#Text=We fell in company at once , our ways lying together as far as to Kingairloch .

#Text=As we went , he stopped and spoke with all the wayfarers and workers that we met or passed ; and though of course I could not tell what they discoursed about , yet I judged Mr. Henderland must be well liked in the countryside , for I observed many of them to bring out their mulls and share a pinch of snuff with him .

#Text=I told him as far in my affairs as I judged wise ; as far , that is , as they were none of Alan 's ; and gave Balachulish as the place I was travelling to , to meet a friend ; for I thought Aucharn , or even Duror , would be too particular , and might put him on the scent .
#Text=On his part , he told me much of his work and the people he worked among , the hiding priests and Jacobites , the Disarming Act , the dress , and many other curiosities of the time and place .

#Text=He seemed moderate ; blaming Parliament in several points , and especially because they had framed the Act more severely against those who wore the dress than against those who carried weapons .
#Text=This moderation put it in my mind to question him of the Red Fox and the Appin tenants ; questions which , I thought , would seem natural enough in the mouth of one travelling to that country .
#Text=He said it was a bad business .
#Text=It 's wonderful , said he , where the tenants find the money , for their life is mere starvation .
#Text=( Ye do n't carry such a thing as snuff , do ye , Mr. Balfour ?
#Text=No. Well , I 'm better wanting it .
#Text=) But these tenants ( as I was saying ) are doubtless partly driven to it .
#Text=James Stewart in Duror ( that 's him they call James of the Glens ) is half-brother to Ardshiel , the captain of the clan ; and he is a man much looked up to , and drives very hard .
#Text=And then there 's one they call Alan Breck -- Ah !
#Text=I cried , what of him ?
#Text=What of the wind that bloweth where it listeth ?
#Text=said Henderland .
#Text=He 's here and awa ; here to-day and gone to-morrow : a fair heather-cat .
#Text=He might be glowering at the two of us out of yon whin-bush , and I wouldnae wonder !
#Text=Ye 'll no carry such a thing as snuff , will ye ?
#Text=I told him no , and that he had asked the same thing more than once .
#Text=It 's highly possible , said he , sighing .
#Text=But it seems strange ye shouldnae carry it .
#Text=However , as I was saying , this Alan Breck is a bold , desperate customer , and well kent to be James 's right hand .
#Text=His life is forfeit already ; he would boggle at naething ; and maybe , if a tenant-body was to hang back he would get a dirk in his wame .
#Text=You make a poor story of it all , Mr. Henderland , said I. If it is all fear upon both sides , I care to hear no more of it .
#Text=Na , said Mr. Henderland , but there 's love too , and self-denial that should put the like of you and me to shame .
#Text=There 's something fine about it ; no perhaps Christian , but humanly fine .
#Text=Even Alan Breck , by all that I hear , is a chield to be respected .

#Text=There 's many a lying sneck-draw sits close in kirk in our own part of the country , and stands well in the world 's eye , and maybe is a far worse man , Mr. Balfour , than yon misguided shedder of man 's blood .
#Text=Ay , ay , we might take a lesson by them.--Ye 'll perhaps think I 've been too long in the Hielands ?
#Text=he added , smiling to me .
#Text=I told him not at all ; that I had seen much to admire among the Highlanders ; and if he came to that , Mr. Campbell himself was a Highlander .
#Text=Ay , said he , that 's true .
#Text=It 's a fine blood .
#Text=And what is the King 's agent about ?
#Text=I asked .
#Text=Colin Campbell ?
#Text=says Henderland .
#Text=Putting his head in a bees'byke !
#Text=He is to turn the tenants out by force , I hear ?
#Text=said I. Yes , says he , but the business has gone back and forth , as folk say .
#Text=First , James of the Glens rode to Edinburgh , and got some lawyer ( a Stewart , nae doubt--they all hing together like bats in a steeple ) and had the proceedings stayed .
#Text=And then Colin Campbell cam'in again , and had the upper-hand before the Barons of Exchequer .
#Text=And now they tell me the first of the tenants are to flit to-morrow .
#Text=It 's to begin at Duror under James 's very windows , which doesnae seem wise by my humble way of it .
#Text=Do you think they 'll fight ?
#Text=I asked .
#Text=Well , says Henderland , they 're disarmed--or supposed to be--for there 's still a good deal of cold iron lying by in quiet places .
#Text=And then Colin Campbell has the sogers coming .
#Text=But for all that , if I was his lady wife , I wouldnae be well pleased till I got him home again .
#Text=They 're queer customers , the Appin Stewarts .
#Text=I asked if they were worse than their neighbours .
#Text=No they , said he .
#Text=And that 's the worst part of it .
#Text=For if Colin Roy can get his business done in Appin , he has it all to begin again in the next country , which they call Mamore , and which is one of the countries of the Camerons .

#Text=He 's King 's Factor upon both , and from both he has to drive out the tenants ; and indeed , Mr. Balfour ( to be open with ye ) , it 's my belief that if he escapes the one lot , he 'll get his death by the other .

#Text=So we continued talking and walking the great part of the day ; until at last , Mr. Henderland after expressing his delight in my company , and satisfaction at meeting with a friend of Mr. Campbell 's ( whom , says he , I will make bold to call that sweet singer of our covenanted Zion ) , proposed that I should make a short stage , and lie the night in his house a little beyond Kingairloch .

#Text=To say truth , I was overjoyed ; for I had no great desire for John of the Claymore , and since my double misadventure , first with the guide and next with the gentleman skipper , I stood in some fear of any Highland stranger .
#Text=Accordingly we shook hands upon the bargain , and came in the afternoon to a small house , standing alone by the shore of the Linnhe Loch .

#Text=The sun was already gone from the desert mountains of Ardgour upon the hither side , but shone on those of Appin on the farther ; the loch lay as still as a lake , only the gulls were crying round the sides of it ; and the whole place seemed solemn and uncouth .

#Text=We had no sooner come to the door of Mr. Henderland 's dwelling , than to my great surprise ( for I was now used to the politeness of Highlanders ) he burst rudely past me , dashed into the room , caught up a jar and a small horn-spoon , and began ladling snuff into his nose in most excessive quantities .
#Text=Then he had a hearty fit of sneezing , and looked round upon me with a rather silly smile .
#Text=It 's a vow I took , says he .
#Text=I took a vow upon me that I wouldnae carry it .
#Text=Doubtless it 's a great privation ; but when I think upon the martyrs , not only to the Scottish Covenant but to other points of Christianity , I think shame to mind it .

#Text=As soon as we had eaten ( and porridge and whey was the best of the good man 's diet ) he took a grave face and said he had a duty to perform by Mr. Campbell , and that was to inquire into my state of mind towards God .
#Text=I was inclined to smile at him since the business of the snuff ; but he had not spoken long before he brought the tears into my eyes .

#Text=There are two things that men should never weary of , goodness and humility ; we get none too much of them in this rough world among cold , proud people ; but Mr. Henderland had their very speech upon his tongue .

#Text=And though I was a good deal puffed up with my adventures and with having come off , as the saying is , with flying colours ; yet he soon had me on my knees beside a simple , poor old man , and both proud and glad to be there .
#Text=Before we went to bed he offered me sixpence to help me on my way , out of a scanty store he kept in the turf wall of his house ; at which excess of goodness I knew not what to do .
#Text=But at last he was so earnest with me that I thought it the more mannerly part to let him have his way , and so left him poorer than myself .
#Text=CHAPTER XVII THE DEATH OF THE RED FOX The next day Mr. Henderland found for me a man who had a boat of his own and was to cross the Linnhe Loch that afternoon into Appin , fishing .
#Text=Him he prevailed on to take me , for he was one of his flock ; and in this way I saved a long day 's travel and the price of the two public ferries I must otherwise have passed .
#Text=It was near noon before we set out ; a dark day with clouds , and the sun shining upon little patches .
#Text=The sea was here very deep and still , and had scarce a wave upon it ; so that I must put the water to my lips before I could believe it to be truly salt .
#Text=The mountains on either side were high , rough and barren , very black and gloomy in the shadow of the clouds , but all silver-laced with little watercourses where the sun shone upon them .
#Text=It seemed a hard country , this of Appin , for people to care as much about as Alan did .
#Text=There was but one thing to mention .
#Text=A little after we had started , the sun shone upon a little moving clump of scarlet close in along the water-side to the north .
#Text=It was much of the same red as soldiers'coats ; every now and then , too , there came little sparks and lightnings , as though the sun had struck upon bright steel .
#Text=I asked my boatman what it should be , and he answered he supposed it was some of the red soldiers coming from Fort William into Appin , against the poor tenantry of the country .

#Text=Well , it was a sad sight to me ; and whether it was because of my thoughts of Alan , or from something prophetic in my bosom , although this was but the second time I had seen King George 's troops , I had no good will to them .
#Text=At last we came so near the point of land at the entering in of Loch Leven that I begged to be set on shore .

#Text=My boatman ( who was an honest fellow and mindful of his promise to the catechist ) would fain have carried me on to Balachulish ; but as this was to take me farther from my secret destination , I insisted , and was set on shore at last under the wood of Lettermore ( or Lettervore , for I have heard it both ways ) in Alan 's country of Appin .
#Text=This was a wood of birches , growing on a steep , craggy side of a mountain that overhung the loch .

#Text=It had many openings and ferny howes ; and a road or bridle track ran north and south through the midst of it , by the edge of which , where was a spring , I sat down to eat some oat-bread of Mr. Henderland 's and think upon my situation .
#Text=Here I was not only troubled by a cloud of stinging midges , but far more by the doubts of my mind .

#Text=What I ought to do , why I was going to join myself with an outlaw and a would-be murderer like Alan , whether I should not be acting more like a man of sense to tramp back to the south country direct , by my own guidance and at my own charges , and what Mr. Campbell or even Mr. Henderland would think of me if they should ever learn my folly and presumption : these were the doubts that now began to come in on me stronger than ever .
#Text=As I was so sitting and thinking , a sound of men and horses came to me through the wood ; and presently after , at a turning of the road , I saw four travellers come into view .
#Text=The way was in this part so rough and narrow that they came single and led their horses by the reins .
#Text=The first was a great , red-headed gentleman , of an imperious and flushed face , who carried his hat in his hand and fanned himself , for he was in a breathing heat .
#Text=The second , by his decent black garb and white wig , I correctly took to be a lawyer .

#Text=The third was a servant , and wore some part of his clothes in tartan , which showed that his master was of a Highland family , and either an outlaw or else in singular good odour with the Government , since the wearing of tartan was against the Act .
#Text=If I had been better versed in these things , I would have known the tartan to be of the Argyle ( or Campbell ) colours .

#Text=This servant had a good-sized portmanteau strapped on his horse , and a net of lemons ( to brew punch with ) hanging at the saddle-bow ; as was often enough the custom with luxurious travellers in that part of the country .
#Text=As for the fourth , who brought up the tail , I had seen his like before , and knew him at once to be a sheriff 's officer .

#Text=I had no sooner seen these people coming than I made up my mind ( for no reason that I can tell ) to go through with my adventure ; and when the first came alongside of me , I rose up from the bracken and asked him the way to Aucharn .
#Text=He stopped and looked at me , as I thought , a little oddly ; and then , turning to the lawyer , Mungo , said he , there 's many a man would think this more of a warning than two pyats .
#Text=Here am I on my road to Duror on the job ye ken ; and here is a young lad starts up out of the bracken , and speers if I am on the way to Aucharn .
#Text=Glenure , said the other , this is an ill subject for jesting .
#Text=These two had now drawn close up and were gazing at me , while the two followers had halted about a stone-cast in the rear .
#Text=And what seek ye in Aucharn ?
#Text=said Colin Roy Campbell of Glenure , him they called the Red Fox ; for he it was that I had stopped .
#Text=The man that lives there , said I. James of the Glens , says Glenure , musingly ; and then to the lawyer : Is he gathering his people , think ye ?
#Text=Anyway , says the lawyer , we shall do better to bide where we are , and let the soldiers rally us .
#Text=If you are concerned for me , said I , I am neither of his people nor yours , but an honest subject of King George , owing no man and fearing no man .
#Text=Why , very well said , replies the Factor .
#Text=But if I may make so bold as ask , what does this honest man so far from his country ?
#Text=and why does he come seeking the brother of Ardshiel ?
#Text=I have power here , I must tell you .
#Text=I am King 's Factor upon several of these estates , and have twelve files of soldiers at my back .
#Text=I have heard a waif word in the country , said I , a little nettled , that you were a hard man to drive .
#Text=He still kept looking at me , as if in doubt .
#Text=Well , said he , at last , your tongue is bold ; but I am no unfriend to plainness .
#Text=If ye had asked me the way to the door of James Stewart on any other day but this , I would have set ye right and bidden ye God speed .
#Text=But to-day--eh , Mungo ?
#Text=And he turned again to look at the lawyer .
#Text=But just as he turned there came the shot of a firelock from higher up the hill ; and with the very sound of it Glenure fell upon the road .
#Text=O , I am dead !
#Text=he cried , several times over .
#Text=The lawyer had caught him up and held him in his arms , the servant standing over and clasping his hands .
#Text=And now the wounded man looked from one to another with scared eyes , and there was a change in his voice , that went to the heart .
#Text=Take care of yourselves , says he .
#Text=I am dead .
#Text=He tried to open his clothes as if to look for the wound , but his fingers slipped on the buttons .
#Text=With that he gave a great sigh , his head rolled on his shoulder , and he passed away .

#Text=The lawyer said never a word , but his face was as sharp as a pen and as white as the dead man 's ; the servant broke out into a great noise of crying and weeping , like a child ; and I , on my side , stood staring at them in a kind of horror .
#Text=The sheriff 's officer had run back at the first sound of the shot , to hasten the coming of the soldiers .
#Text=At last the lawyer laid down the dead man in his blood upon the road , and got to his own feet with a kind of stagger .
#Text=I believe it was his movement that brought me to my senses ; for he had no sooner done so than I began to scramble up the hill , crying out , The murderer !
#Text=the murderer !
#Text=So little a time had elapsed , that when I got to the top of the first steepness , and could see some part of the open mountain , the murderer was still moving away at no great distance .
#Text=He was a big man , in a black coat , with metal buttons , and carried a long fowling-piece .
#Text=Here !
#Text=I cried .
#Text=I see him !
#Text=At that the murderer gave a little , quick look over his shoulder , and began to run .

#Text=The next moment he was lost in a fringe of birches ; then he came out again on the upper side , where I could see him climbing like a jackanapes , for that part was again very steep ; and then he dipped behind a shoulder , and I saw him no more .
#Text=All this time I had been running on my side , and had got a good way up , when a voice cried upon me to stand .
#Text=I was at the edge of the upper wood , and so now , when I halted and looked back , I saw all the open part of the hill below me .

#Text=The lawyer and the sheriff 's officer were standing just above the road , crying and waving on me to come back ; and on their left , the red-coats , musket in hand , were beginning to struggle singly out of the lower wood .
#Text=Why should I come back ?
#Text=I cried .
#Text=Come you on !
#Text=Ten pounds if ye take that lad !
#Text=cried the lawyer .
#Text=He 's an accomplice .
#Text=He was posted here to hold us in talk .
#Text=At that word ( which I could hear quite plainly , though it was to the soldiers and not to me that he was crying it ) my heart came in my mouth with quite a new kind of terror .
#Text=Indeed , it is one thing to stand the danger of your life , and quite another to run the peril of both life and character .
#Text=The thing , besides , had come so suddenly , like thunder out of a clear sky , that I was all amazed and helpless .
#Text=The soldiers began to spread , some of them to run , and others to put up their pieces and cover me ; and still I stood .
#Text=in here among the trees , said a voice close by .
#Text=Duck .
#Text=Indeed , I scarce knew what I was doing , but I obeyed ; and as I did so , I heard the firelocks bang and the balls whistle in the birches .
#Text=Just inside the shelter of the trees I found Alan Breck standing , with a fishing-rod .
#Text=He gave me no salutation ; indeed it was no time for civilities ; only Come !
#Text=says he , and set off running along the side of the mountain towards Balachulish ; and I , like a sheep , to follow him .
#Text=Now we ran among the birches ; now stooping behind low humps upon the mountain-side ; now crawling on all fours among the heather .
#Text=The pace was deadly : my heart seemed bursting against my ribs ; and I had neither time to think nor breath to speak with .

#Text=Only I remember seeing with wonder , that Alan every now and then would straighten himself to his full height and look back ; and every time he did so , there came a great far-away cheering and crying of the soldiers .
#Text=Quarter of an hour later , Alan stopped , clapped down flat in the heather , and turned to me .
#Text=Now , said he , it 's earnest .
#Text=Do as I do , for your life .

#Text=And at the same speed , but now with infinitely more precaution , we traced back again across the mountain-side by the same way that we had come , only perhaps higher ; till at last Alan threw himself down in the upper wood of Lettermore , where I had found him at the first , and lay , with his face in the bracken , panting like a dog .
#Text=My own sides so ached , my head so swam , my tongue so hung out of my mouth with heat and dryness , that I lay beside him like one dead .
#Text=CHAPTER XVIII I TALK WITH ALAN IN THE WOOD OF LETTERMORE Alan was the first to come round .
#Text=He rose , went to the border of the wood , peered out a little , and then returned and sat down .
#Text=Well , said he , yon was a hot burst , David .
#Text=I said nothing , nor so much as lifted my face .
#Text=I had seen murder done , and a great , ruddy , jovial gentleman struck out of life in a moment ; the pity of that sight was still sore within me , and yet that was but a part of my concern .

#Text=Here was murder done upon the man Alan hated ; here was Alan skulking in the trees and running from the troops ; and whether his was the hand that fired or only the head that ordered , signified but little .

#Text=By my way of it , my only friend in that wild country was blood-guilty in the first degree ; I held him in horror ; I could not look upon his face ; I would have rather lain alone in the rain on my cold isle , than in that warm wood beside a murderer .
#Text=Are ye still wearied ?
#Text=he asked again .
#Text=No , said I , still with my face in the bracken ; no , I am not wearied now , and I can speak .
#Text=You and me must twine , I said .
#Text=I liked you very well , Alan , but your ways are not mine , and they 're not God 's : and the short and the long of it is just that we must twine .
#Text=Part .
#Text=I will hardly twine from ye , David , without some kind of reason for the same , said Alan , mighty gravely .

#Text=If ye ken anything against my reputation , it 's the least thing that ye should do , for old acquaintance'sake , to let me hear the name of it ; and if ye have only taken a distaste to my society , it will be proper for me to judge if I 'm insulted .
#Text=Alan , said I , what is the sense of this ?
#Text=Ye ken very well yon Campbell-man lies in his blood upon the road .
#Text=He was silent for a little ; then says he , Did ever ye hear tell of the story of the Man and the Good People ?
#Text=-- by which he meant the fairies .
#Text=No , said I , nor do I want to hear it .
#Text=With your permission , Mr. Balfour , I will tell it you , whatever , says Alan .
#Text=The man , ye should ken , was cast upon a rock in the sea , where it appears the Good People were in use to come and rest as they went through to Ireland .
#Text=The name of this rock is called the Skerryvore , and it 's not far from where we suffered ship-wreck .
#Text=Well , it seems the man cried so sore , if he could just see his little bairn before he died !
#Text=that at last the king of the Good People took peety upon him , and sent one flying that brought back the bairn in a and laid it down beside the man where he lay sleeping .
#Text=So when the man woke , there was a poke beside him and something into the inside of it that moved .

#Text=Well , it seems he was one of these gentry that think aye the worst of things ; and for greater security , he stuck his dirk throughout that poke before he opened it , and there was his bairn dead .
#Text=I am thinking to myself , Mr. Balfour , that you and the man are very much alike .
#Text=Bag .
#Text=Do you mean you had no hand in it ?
#Text=cried I , sitting up .

#Text=I will tell you first of all , Mr. Balfour of Shaws , as one friend to another , said Alan , that if I were going to kill a gentleman , it would not be in my own country , to bring trouble on my clan ; and I would not go wanting sword and gun , and with a long fishing-rod upon my back .
#Text=Well , said I , that 's true !
#Text=And now , continued Alan , taking out his dirk and laying his hand upon it in a certain manner , I swear upon the Holy Iron I had neither art nor part , act nor thought in it .
#Text=I thank God for that !
#Text=cried I , and offered him my hand .
#Text=He did not appear to see it .
#Text=And here is a great deal of work about a Campbell !
#Text=said he .
#Text=They are not so scarce , that I ken !
#Text=At least , said I , you cannot justly blame me , for you know very well what you told me in the brig .
#Text=But the temptation and the act are different , I thank God again for that .
#Text=We may all be tempted ; but to take a life in cold blood , Alan !
#Text=And I could say no more for the moment .
#Text=And do you know who did it ?
#Text=I added .
#Text=Do you know that man in the black coat ?
#Text=I have nae clear mind about his coat , said Alan cunningly , but it sticks in my head that it was blue .
#Text=Blue or black , did ye know him ?
#Text=said I. I couldnae just conscientiously swear to him , says Alan .
#Text=He gaed very close by me , to be sure , but it 's a strange thing that I should just have been tying my brogues .
#Text=Can you swear that you do n't know him , Alan ?
#Text=I cried , half angered , half in a mind to laugh at his evasions .
#Text=Not yet , says he ; but I 've a grand memory for forgetting , David .
#Text=And yet there was one thing I saw clearly , said I ; and that was , that you exposed yourself and me to draw the soldiers .
#Text=It 's very likely , said Alan ; and so would any gentleman .
#Text=You and me were innocent of that transaction .
#Text=The better reason , since we were falsely suspected , that we should get clear , I cried .
#Text=The innocent should surely come before the guilty .
#Text=Why , David , said he , the innocent have aye a chance to get assoiled in court ; but for the lad that shot the bullet , I think the best place for him will be the heather .
#Text=Them that havenae dipped their hands in any little difficulty , should be very mindful of the case of them that have .
#Text=And that is the good Christianity .

#Text=For if it was the other way round about , and the lad whom I couldnae just clearly see had been in our shoes , and we in his ( as might very well have been ) , I think we would be a good deal obliged to him oursel 's if he would draw the soldiers .
#Text=When it came to this , I gave Alan up .
#Text=But he looked so innocent all the time , and was in such clear good faith in what he said , and so ready to sacrifice himself for what he deemed his duty , that my mouth was closed .
#Text=Mr. Henderland 's words came back to me : that we ourselves might take a lesson by these wild Highlanders .
#Text=Well , here I had taken mine .
#Text=Alan 's morals were all tail-first ; but he was ready to give his life for them , such as they were .
#Text=Alan , said I , I 'll not say it 's the good Christianity as I understand it , but it 's good enough .
#Text=And here I offer ye my hand for the second time .
#Text=Whereupon he gave me both of his , saying surely I had cast a spell upon him , for he could forgive me anything .

#Text=Then he grew very grave , and said we had not much time to throw away , but must both flee that country : he , because he was a deserter , and the whole of Appin would now be searched like a chamber , and every one obliged to give a good account of himself ; and I , because I was certainly involved in the murder .
#Text=O !
#Text=says I , willing to give him a little lesson , I have no fear of the justice of my country .
#Text=As if this was your country !
#Text=said he .
#Text=Or as if ye would be tried here , in a country of Stewarts !
#Text=It 's all Scotland , said I. Man , I whiles wonder at ye , said Alan .
#Text=This is a Campbell that 's been killed .
#Text=Well , it 'll be tried in Inverara , the Campbells'head place ; with fifteen Campbells in the jury-box and the biggest Campbell of all ( and that 's the Duke ) sitting cocking on the bench .
#Text=Justice , David ?
#Text=The same justice , by all the world , as Glenure found awhile ago at the roadside .

#Text=This frightened me a little , I confess , and would have frightened me more if I had known how nearly exact were Alan 's predictions ; indeed it was but in one point that he exaggerated , there being but eleven Campbells on the jury ; though as the other four were equally in the Duke 's dependence , it mattered less than might appear .
#Text=Still , I cried out that he was unjust to the Duke of Argyle , who ( for all he was a Whig ) was yet a wise and honest nobleman .
#Text=Hoot !
#Text=said Alan , the man 's a Whig , nae doubt ; but I would never deny he was a good chieftain to his clan .
#Text=And what would the clan think if there was a Campbell shot , and naebody hanged , and their own chief the Justice General ?
#Text=But I have often observed , says Alan , that you Low-country bodies have no clear idea of what 's right and wrong .
#Text=At this I did at last laugh out aloud , when to my surprise , Alan joined in , and laughed as merrily as myself .
#Text=Na , na , said he , we 're in the Hielands , David ; and when I tell ye to run , take my word and run .
#Text=Nae doubt it 's a hard thing to skulk and starve in the Heather , but it 's harder yet to lie shackled in a red-coat prison .

#Text=I asked him whither we should flee ; and as he told me to the Lowlands , I was a little better inclined to go with him ; for , indeed , I was growing impatient to get back and have the upper-hand of my uncle .
#Text=Besides , Alan made so sure there would be no question of justice in the matter , that I began to be afraid he might be right .

#Text=Of all deaths , I would truly like least to die by the gallows ; and the picture of that uncanny instrument came into my head with extraordinary clearness ( as I had once seen it engraved at the top of a pedlar 's ballad ) and took away my appetite for courts of justice .
#Text=I 'll chance it , Alan , said I. I 'll go with you .
#Text=But mind you , said Alan , it 's no small thing .
#Text=Ye maun lie bare and hard , and brook many an empty belly .
#Text=Your bed shall be the moorcock 's , and your life shall be like the hunted deer 's , and ye shall sleep with your hand upon your weapons .
#Text=Ay , man , ye shall taigle many a weary foot , the little man cried to me to run , and indeed I thought it was a good observe , and ran .
#Text=The last that I saw they were all in a knot upon the beach , like folk that were not agreeing very well together .
#Text=What do you mean by that ?
#Text=said I. Well , the fists were going , said Alan ; and I saw one man go down like a pair of breeks .
#Text=But I thought it would be better no to wait .
#Text=Ye see there 's a strip of Campbells in that end of Mull , which is no good company for a gentleman like me .
#Text=If it hadnae been for that I would have waited and looked for ye mysel ' , let alone giving a hand to the little man .
#Text=( It was droll how Alan dwelt on Mr. Riach 's stature , for , to say the truth , the one was not much smaller than the other .
#Text=) So , says he , continuing , I set my best foot forward , and whenever I met in with any one I cried out there was a wreck ashore .
#Text=Man , they didnae stop to fash with me !
#Text=Ye should have seen them linking for the beach !
#Text=And when they got there they found they had had the pleasure of a run , which is aye good for a Campbell .
#Text=I 'm thinking it was a judgment on the clan that the brig went down in the lump and didnae break .
#Text=But it was a very unlucky thing for you , that same ; for if any wreck had come ashore they would have hunted high and low , and would soon have found ye .

#Text=CHAPTER XIX THE HOUSE OF FEAR Night fell as we were walking , and the clouds , which had broken up in the afternoon , settled in and thickened , so that it fell , for the season of the year , extremely dark .
#Text=The way we went was over rough mountainsides ; and though Alan pushed on with an assured manner , I could by no means see how he directed himself .
#Text=At last , about half-past ten of the clock , we came to the top of a brae , and saw lights below us .

#Text=It seemed a house door stood open and let out a beam of fire and candle-light ; and all round the house and steading five or six persons were moving hurriedly about , each carrying a lighted brand .
#Text=James must have tint his wits , said Alan .
#Text=If this was the soldiers instead of you and me , he would be in a bonny mess .
#Text=But I dare say he 'll have a sentry on the road , and he would ken well enough no soldiers would find the way that we came .
#Text=Hereupon he whistled three times , in a particular manner .
#Text=It was strange to see how , at the first sound of it , all the moving torches came to a stand , as if the bearers were affrighted ; and how , at the third , the bustle began again as before .

#Text=Having thus set folks'minds at rest , we came down the brae , and were met at the yard gate ( for this place was like a well-doing farm ) by a tall , handsome man of more than fifty , who cried out to Alan in the Gaelic .
#Text=James Stewart , said Alan , I will ask ye to speak in Scotch , for here is a young gentleman with me that has nane of the other .

#Text=This is him , he added , putting his arm through mine , a young gentleman of the Lowlands , and a laird in his country too , but I am thinking it will be the better for his health if we give his name the go-by .
#Text=James of the Glens turned to me for a moment , and greeted me courteously enough ; the next he had turned to Alan .
#Text=This has been a dreadful accident , he cried .
#Text=It will bring trouble on the country .
#Text=And he wrung his hands .
#Text=Hoots !
#Text=said Alan , ye must take the sour with the sweet , man .
#Text=Colin Roy is dead , and be thankful for that !
#Text=Ay said James , and by my troth , I wish he was alive again !
#Text=It 's all very fine to blow and boast beforehand ; but now it 's done , Alan ; and who 's to bear the of it ?
#Text=The accident fell out in Appin--mind ye that , Alan ; it 's Appin that must pay ; and I am a man that has a family .
#Text=Blame .
#Text=While this was going on I looked about me at the servants .

#Text=Some were on ladders , digging in the thatch of the house or the farm buildings , from which they brought out guns , swords , and different weapons of war ; others carried them away ; and by the sound of mattock blows from somewhere farther down the brae , I suppose they buried them .

#Text=Though they were all so busy , there prevailed no kind of order in their efforts ; men struggled together for the same gun and ran into each other with their burning torches ; and James was continually turning about from his talk with Alan , to cry out orders which were apparently never understood .
#Text=The faces in the torchlight were like those of people overborne with hurry and panic ; and though none spoke above his breath , their speech sounded both anxious and angry .
#Text=It was about this time that a lassie came out of the house carrying a pack or bundle ; and it has often made me smile to think how Alan 's instinct awoke at the mere sight of it .
#Text=What 's that the lassie has ?
#Text=he asked .
#Text=We 're just setting the house in order , Alan , said James , in his frightened and somewhat fawning way .
#Text=They 'll search Appin with candles , and we must have all things straight .
#Text=We 're digging the bit guns and swords into the moss , ye see ; and these , I am thinking , will be your ain French clothes .
#Text=We 'll be to bury them , I believe .
#Text=Bury my French clothes !
#Text=cried Alan .
#Text=Troth , no !
#Text=And he laid hold upon the packet and retired into the barn to shift himself , recommending me in the meanwhile to his kinsman .
#Text=James carried me accordingly into the kitchen , and sat down with me at table , smiling and talking at first in a very hospitable manner .

#Text=But presently the gloom returned upon him ; he sat frowning and biting his fingers ; only remembered me from time to time ; and then gave me but a word or two and a poor smile , and back into his private terrors .

#Text=His wife sat by the fire and wept , with her face in her hands ; his eldest son was crouched upon the floor , running over a great mass of papers and now and again setting one alight and burning it to the bitter end ; all the while a servant lass with a red face was rummaging about the room , in a blind hurry of fear , and whimpering as she went ; and every now and again one of the men would thrust in his face from the yard , and cry for orders .
#Text=At last James could keep his seat no longer , and begged my permission to be so unmannerly as walk about .
#Text=I am but poor company altogether , sir , says he , but I can think of nothing but this dreadful accident , and the trouble it is like to bring upon quite innocent persons .
#Text=A little after he observed his son burning a paper which he thought should have been kept ; and at that his excitement burst out so that it was painful to witness .
#Text=He struck the lad repeatedly .
#Text=Are you gone gyte ?
#Text=he cried .
#Text=Do you wish to hang your father ?

#Text=and forgetful of my presence , carried on at him a long time together in the Gaelic , the young man answering nothing ; only the wife , at the name of hanging , throwing her apron over her face and sobbing out louder than before .
#Text=Mad .

#Text=This was all wretched for a stranger like myself to hear and see ; and I was right glad when Alan returned , looking like himself in his fine French clothes , though ( to be sure ) they were now grown almost too battered and withered to deserve the name of fine .

#Text=I was then taken out in my turn by another of the sons , and given that change of clothing of which I had stood so long in need , and a pair of Highland brogues made of deer-leather , rather strange at first , but after a little practice very easy to the feet .
#Text=By the time I came back Alan must have told his story ; for it seemed understood that I was to fly with him , and they were all busy upon our equipment .

#Text=They gave us each a sword and pistols , though I professed my inability to use the former ; and with these , and some ammunition , a bag of oatmeal , an iron pan , and a bottle of right French brandy , we were ready for the heather .
#Text=Money , indeed , was lacking .

#Text=I had about two guineas left ; Alan 's belt having been despatched by another hand , that trusty messenger had no more than seventeen-pence to his whole fortune ; and as for James , it appears he had brought himself so low with journeys to Edinburgh and legal expenses on behalf of the tenants , that he could only scrape together three-and-five-pence-halfpenny , the most of it in coppers .
#Text=This 'll no do , said Alan .
#Text=Ye must find a safe bit somewhere near by , said James , and get word sent to me .
#Text=Ye see , ye 'll have to get this business prettily off , Alan .
#Text=This is no time to be stayed for a guinea or two .
#Text=They 're sure to get wind of ye , sure to seek ye , and by my way of it , sure to lay on ye the wyte of this day 's accident .
#Text=If it falls on you , it falls on me that am your near kinsman and harboured ye while ye were in the country .
#Text=And if it comes on me -- -- he paused , and bit his fingers , with a white face .
#Text=It would be a painful thing for our friends if I was to hang , said he .
#Text=It would be an ill day for Appin , says Alan .
#Text=It 's a day that sticks in my throat , said James .
#Text=O man , man , man--man Alan !
#Text=you and me have spoken like two fools !
#Text=he cried , striking his hand upon the wall so that the house rang again .
#Text=Well , and that 's true , too , said Alan ; and my friend from the Lowlands here ( nodding at me ) gave me a good word upon that head , if I would only have listened to him .
#Text=But see here , said James , returning to his former manner , if they lay me by the heels , Alan , it 's then that you 'll be needing the money .
#Text=For with all that I have said and that you have said , it will look very black against the two of us ; do ye mark that ?
#Text=Well , follow me out , and ye 'll , I 'll see that I 'll have to get a paper out against ye mysel ' ; have to offer a reward for ye ; ay , will I !
#Text=It 's a sore thing to do between such near friends ; but if I get the of this dreadful accident , I 'll have to fend for myself , man .
#Text=Do ye see that ?
#Text=Blame .
#Text=He spoke with a pleading earnestness , taking Alan by the breast of the coat .
#Text=Ay said Alan , I see that .
#Text=And ye 'll have to be clear of the country , Alan--ay , and clear of Scotland--you and your friend from the Lowlands , too .
#Text=For I 'll have to paper your friend from the Lowlands .
#Text=Ye see that , Alan--say that ye see that !
#Text=I thought Alan flushed a bit .
#Text=This is unco hard on me that brought him here , James , said he , throwing his head back .

#Text=It 's like making me a instead of gates of wrought iron , a pair of hurdles were tied across with a straw rope ; and as there were no park walls , nor any sign of avenue , the track that I was following passed on the right hand of the pillars , and went wandering on toward the house .
#Text=The nearer I got to that , the drearier it appeared .
#Text=It seemed like the one wing of a house that had never been finished .
#Text=What should have been the inner end stood open on the upper floors , and showed against the sky with steps and stairs of uncompleted masonry .
#Text=Many of the windows were unglazed , and bats flew in and out like doves out of a dove-cote .
#Text=The night had begun to fall as I got close ; and in three of the lower windows , which were very high up and narrow , and well barred , the changing light of a little fire began to glimmer .
#Text=Was this the palace I had been coming to ?
#Text=Was it within these walls that I was to seek new friends and begin great fortunes ?
#Text=Why , in my father 's house on Essen-Waterside , the fire and the bright lights would show a mile away , and the door open to a beggar 's knock !

#Text=I came forward cautiously , and giving ear as I came , heard some one rattling with dishes , and a little dry , eager cough that came in fits ; but there was no sound of speech , and not a dog barked .
#Text=The door , as well as I could see it in the dim light , was a great piece of wood all studded with nails ; and I lifted my hand with a faint heart under my jacket , and knocked once .
#Text=Then I stood and waited .
#Text=The house had fallen into a dead silence ; a whole minute passed away , and nothing stirred but the bats overhead .
#Text=I knocked again , and hearkened again .

#Text=By this time my ears had grown so accustomed to the quiet , that I could hear the ticking of the clock inside as it slowly counted out the seconds ; but whoever was in that house kept deadly still , and must have held his breath .
#Text=I was in two minds whether to run away ; but anger got the upper hand , and I began instead to rain kicks and buffets on the door , and to shout out aloud for Mr. Balfour .

#Text=I was in full career , when I heard the cough right overhead , and jumping back and looking up , beheld a man 's head in a tall nightcap , and the bell mouth of a blunderbuss , at one of the first-storey windows .
#Text=It 's loaded , said a voice .
#Text=I have come here with a letter , I said , to Mr. Ebenezer Balfour of Shaws .
#Text=Is he here ?
#Text=From whom is it ?
#Text=asked the man with the blunderbuss .
#Text=That is neither here nor there , said I , for I was growing very wroth .
#Text=Well , was the reply , ye can put it down upon the doorstep , and be off with ye .
#Text=I will do no such thing , I cried .
#Text=I will deliver it into Mr. Balfour 's hands , as it was meant I should .
#Text=It is a letter of introduction .
#Text=A what ?
#Text=cried the voice , sharply .
#Text=I repeated what I had said .
#Text=Who are ye , yourself ?
#Text=was the next question , after a considerable pause .
#Text=I am not ashamed of my name , said I. They call me David Balfour .

#Text=At that , I made sure the man started , for I heard the blunderbuss rattle on the window-sill ; and it was after quite a long pause , and with a curious change of voice , that the next question followed : Is your father dead ?
#Text=I was so much surprised at this , that I could find no voice to answer , but stood staring .
#Text=Ay , the man resumed , he 'll be dead , no doubt ; and that 'll be what brings ye chapping to my door .
#Text=Another pause , and then defiantly , Well , man , he said , I 'll let ye in ; and he disappeared from the window .
#Text=CHAPTER III I MAKE ACQUAINTANCE OF MY UNCLE Presently there came a great rattling of chains and bolts , and the door was cautiously opened and shut to again behind me as soon as I had passed .
#Text=Go into the kitchen and touch naething , said the voice ; and while the person of the house set himself to replacing the defences of the door , I groped my way forward and entered the kitchen .
#Text=The fire had burned up fairly bright , and showed me the barest room I think I ever put my eyes on .
#Text=Half-a-dozen dishes stood upon the shelves ; the table was laid for supper with a bowl of porridge , a horn spoon , and a cup of small beer .
#Text=Besides what I have named , there was not another thing in that great , stone-vaulted , empty chamber but lockfast chests arranged along the wall and a corner cupboard with a padlock .
#Text=As soon as the last chain was up , the man rejoined me .
#Text=He was a mean , stooping , narrow-shouldered , clay-faced creature ; and his age might have been anything between fifty and seventy .
#Text=His nightcap was of flannel , and so was the nightgown that he wore , instead of coat and waistcoat , over his ragged shirt .
#Text=He was long unshaved ; but what most distressed and even daunted me , he would neither take his eyes away from me nor look me fairly in the face .

#Text=What he was , whether by trade or birth , was more than I could fathom ; but he seemed most like an old , unprofitable serving-man , who should have been left in charge of that big house upon board wages .
#Text=Are ye sharp-set ?
#Text=he asked , glancing at about the level of my knee .
#Text=Ye can eat that drop parritch ?
#Text=I said I feared it was his own supper .
#Text=the time of King William .

#Text=But for the details of our itinerary , I am all to seek ; our way lying now by short cuts , now by great detours ; our pace being so hurried , our time of journeying usually by night ; and the names of such places as I asked and heard being in the Gaelic tongue and the more easily forgotten .
#Text=The first peep of morning , then , showed us this horrible place , and I could see Alan knit his brow .
#Text=This is no fit place for you and me , he said .
#Text=This is a place they 're bound to watch .
#Text=And with that he ran harder than ever down to the water-side , in a part where the river was split in two among three rocks .
#Text=It went through with a horrid thundering that made my belly quake ; and there hung over the lynn a little mist of spray .

#Text=Alan looked neither to the right nor to the left , but jumped clean upon the middle rock and fell there on his hands and knees to check himself , for that rock was small and he might have pitched over on the far side .
#Text=I had scarce time to measure the distance or to understand the peril before I had followed him , and he had caught and stopped me .
#Text=So there we stood , side by side upon a small rock slippery with spray , a far broader leap in front of us , and the river dinning upon all sides .
#Text=When I saw where I was , there came on me a deadly sickness of fear , and I put my hand over my eyes .

#Text=Alan took me and shook me ; I saw he was speaking , but the roaring of the falls and the trouble of my mind prevented me from hearing ; only I saw his face was red with anger , and that he stamped upon the rock .
#Text=The same look showed me the water raging by , and the mist hanging in the air : and with that I covered my eyes again and shuddered .
#Text=The next minute Alan had set the brandy bottle to my lips , and forced me to drink about a gill , which sent the blood into my head again .
#Text=Then , putting his hands to his mouth , and his mouth to my ear , he shouted , Hang or drown !
#Text=and turning his back upon me , leaped over the farther branch of the stream , and landed safe .

#Text=I was now alone upon the rock , which gave me the more room ; the brandy was singing in my ears ; I had this good example fresh before me , and just wit enough to see that if I did not leap at once , I should never leap at all .
#Text=I bent low on my knees and flung myself forth , with that kind of anger of despair that has sometimes stood me in stead of courage .

#Text=Sure enough , it was but my hands that reached the full length ; these slipped , caught again , slipped again ; and I was sliddering back into the lynn , when Alan seized me , first by the hair , then by the collar , and with a great strain dragged me into safety .
#Text=Never a word he said , but set off running again for his life , and I must stagger to my feet and run after him .

#Text=I had been weary before , but now I was sick and bruised , and partly drunken with the brandy ; I kept stumbling as I ran , I had a stitch that came near to overmaster me ; and when at last Alan paused under a great rock that stood there among a number of others , it was none too soon for David Balfour .
#Text=A great rock I have said ; but by rights it was two rocks leaning together at the top , both some twenty feet high , and at the first sight inaccessible .

#Text=Even Alan ( though you may say he had as good as four hands ) failed twice in an attempt to climb them ; and it was only at the third trial , and then by standing on my shoulders and leaping up with such force as I thought must have broken my collar-bone , that he secured a lodgment .
#Text=Once there , he let down his leathern girdle ; and with the aid of that and a pair of shallow footholds in the rock , I scrambled up beside him .

#Text=Then I saw why we had come there ; for the two rocks , being both somewhat hollow on the top and sloping one to the other , made a kind of dish or saucer , where as many as three or four men might have lain hidden .
#Text=All this while Alan had not said a word , and had run and climbed with such a savage , silent frenzy of hurry , that I knew that he was in mortal fear of some miscarriage .

#Text=Even now we were on the rock he said nothing , nor so much as relaxed the frowning look upon his face ; but clapped flat down , and keeping only one eye above the edge of our place of shelter scouted all round the compass .

#Text=The dawn had come quite clear ; we could see the stony sides of the valley , and its bottom , which was bestrewed with rocks , and the river , which went from one side to another , and made white falls ; but nowhere the smoke of a house , nor any living creature but some eagles screaming round a cliff .
#Text=Then at last Alan smiled .
#Text=Ay said he , now we have a chance ; and then looking at me with some amusement , Ye 're no very at the jumping , said he .
#Text=Brisk .
#Text=At this I suppose I coloured with mortification , for he added at once , Hoots !
#Text=small blame to ye !
#Text=To be feared of a thing and yet to do it , is what makes the prettiest kind of a man .
#Text=And then there was water there , and water 's a thing that dauntons even me .
#Text=No , no , said Alan , it 's no you that 's to blame , it 's me .
#Text=I asked him why .
#Text=Why , said he , I have proved myself a gomeral this night .

#Text=For first the odd sing-song in which he spoke , and no less at that strange trick of dropping out the letter h. To be sure , I had heard Ransome ; but he had taken his ways from all sorts of people , and spoke so imperfectly at the best , that I set down the most of it to childishness .

#Text=My surprise was all the greater to hear that manner of speaking in the mouth of a grown man ; and indeed I have never grown used to it ; nor yet altogether with the English grammar , as perhaps a very critical eye might here and there spy out even in these memoirs .
#Text=The tediousness and pain of these hours upon the rock grew only the greater as the day went on ; the rock getting still the hotter and the sun fiercer .
#Text=There were giddiness , and sickness , and sharp pangs like rheumatism , to be supported .

#Text=I minded then , and have often minded since , on the lines in our Scotch psalm: -- The moon by night thee shall not smite , Nor yet the sun by day ; and indeed it was only by God 's blessing that we were neither of us sun-smitten .
#Text=At last , about two , it was beyond men 's bearing , and there was now temptation to resist , as well as pain to thole .
#Text=For the sun being now got a little into the west , there came a patch of shade on the east side of our rock , which was the side sheltered from the soldiers .
#Text=As well one death as another , said Alan , and slipped over the edge and dropped on the ground on the shadowy side .
#Text=I followed him at once , and instantly fell all my length , so weak was I and so giddy with that long exposure .
#Text=Here , then , we lay for an hour or two , aching from head to foot , as weak as water , and lying quite naked to the eye of any soldier who should have strolled that way .
#Text=None came , however , all passing by on the other side ; so that our rock continued to be our shield even in this new position .
#Text=Presently we began again to get a little strength ; and as the soldiers were now lying closer along the river-side , Alan proposed that we should try a start .

#Text=I was by this time afraid of but one thing in the world ; and that was to be set back upon the rock ; anything else was welcome to me ; so we got ourselves at once in marching order , and began to slip from rock to rock one after the other , now crawling flat on our bellies in the shade , now making a run for it , heart in mouth .

#Text=The soldiers , having searched this side of the valley after a fashion , and being perhaps somewhat sleepy with the sultriness of the afternoon , had now laid by much of their vigilance , and stood dozing at their posts or only kept a look-out along the banks of the river ; so that in this way , keeping down the valley and at the same time towards the mountains , we drew steadily away from their neighbourhood .
#Text=But the business was the most wearing I had ever taken part in .
#Text=A man had need of a hundred eyes in every part of him , to keep concealed in that uneven country and within cry of so many and scattered sentries .

#Text=When we must pass an open place , quickness was not all , but a swift judgment not only of the lie of the whole country , but of the solidity of every stone on which we must set foot ; for the afternoon was now fallen so breathless that the rolling of a pebble sounded abroad like a pistol shot , and would start the echo calling among the hills and cliffs .
#Text=By sundown we had made some distance , even by our slow rate of progress , though to be sure the sentry on the rock was still plainly in our view .
#Text=But now we came on something that put all fears out of season ; and that was a deep rushing burn , that tore down , in that part , to join the glen river .

#Text=At the sight of this we cast ourselves on the ground and plunged head and shoulders in the water ; and I cannot tell which was the more pleasant , the great shock as the cool stream went over us , or the greed with which we drank of it .

#Text=We lay there ( for the banks hid us ) , drank again and again , bathed our chests , let our wrists trail in the running water till they ached with the chill ; and at last , being wonderfully renewed , we got out the meal-bag and made drammach in the iron pan .

#Text=This , though it is but cold water mingled with oatmeal , yet makes a good enough dish for a hungry man ; and where there are no means of making fire , or ( as in our case ) good reason for not making one , it is the chief stand-by of those who have taken to the heather .

#Text=As soon as the shadow of the night had fallen , we set forth again , at first with the same caution , but presently with more boldness , standing our full height and stepping out at a good pace of walking .

#Text=The way was very intricate , lying up the steep sides of mountains and along the brows of cliffs ; clouds had come in with the sunset , and the night was dark and cool ; so that I walked without much fatigue , but in continual fear of falling and rolling down the mountains , and with no guess at our direction .

#Text=The moon rose at last and found us still on the road ; it was in its last quarter , and was long beset with clouds ; but after awhile shone out and showed me many dark heads of mountains , and was reflected far underneath us on the narrow arm of a sea-loch .
#Text=At this sight we both paused : I struck with wonder to find myself so high and walking ( as it seemed to me ) upon clouds ; Alan to make sure of his direction .

#Text=Seemingly he was well pleased , and he must certainly have judged us out of ear-shot of all our enemies ; for throughout the rest of our night-march he beguiled the way with whistling of many tunes , warlike , merry , plaintive ; reel tunes that made the foot go faster ; tunes of my own south country that made me fain to be home from my adventures ; and all these , on the great , dark , desert mountains , making company upon the way .

#Text=CHAPTER XXI THE FLIGHT IN THE HEATHER : THE HEUGH OF CORRYNAKIEGH Early as day comes in the beginning of July , it was still dark when we reached our destination , a cleft in the head of a great mountain , with a water running through the midst , and upon the one hand a shallow cave in a rock .
#Text=Birches grew there in a thin , pretty wood , which a little farther on was changed into a wood of pines .
#Text=The burn was full of trout ; the wood of cushat-doves ; on the open side of the mountain beyond , whaups would be always whistling , and cuckoos were plentiful .
