#Text=From the mouth of the cleft we looked down upon a part of Mamore , and on the sea-loch that divides that country from Appin ; and this from so great a height as made it my continual wonder and pleasure to sit and behold them .

#Text=The name of the cleft was the Heugh of Corrynakiegh ; and although from its height and being so near upon the sea , it was often beset with clouds , yet it was on the whole a pleasant place , and the five days we lived in it went happily .
#Text=We slept in the cave , making our bed of heather bushes which we cut for that purpose , and covering ourselves with Alan 's great-coat .

#Text=There was a low concealed place , in a turning of the glen , where we were so bold as to make fire : so that we could warm ourselves when the clouds set in , and cook hot porridge , and grill the little trouts that we caught with our hands under the stones and overhanging banks of the burn .

#Text=This was indeed our chief pleasure and business ; and not only to save our meal against worse times , but with a rivalry that much amused us , we spent a great part of our days at the water-side , stripped to the waist and groping about or ( as they say ) guddling for these fish .
#Text=The largest we got might have been a quarter of a pound ; but they were of good flesh and flavour , and when broiled upon the coals , lacked only a little salt to be delicious .

#Text=In any by-time Alan must teach me to use my sword , for my ignorance had much distressed him ; and I think besides , as I had sometimes the upper-hand of him in the fishing , he was not sorry to turn to an exercise where he had so much the upper-hand of me .

#Text=He made it somewhat more of a pain than need have been , for he stormed at me all through the lessons in a very violent manner of scolding , and would push me so close that I made sure he must run me through the body .

#Text=I was often tempted to turn tail , but held my ground for all that , and got some profit of my lessons ; if it was but to stand on guard with an assured countenance , which is often all that is required .
#Text=So , though I could never in the least please my master , I was not altogether displeased with myself .
#Text=In the meanwhile , you are not to suppose that we neglected our chief business , which was to get away .

#Text=It will be many a long day , Alan said to me on our first morning , before the red-coats think upon seeking Corrynakiegh ; so now we must get word sent to James , and he must find the siller for us .
#Text=And how shall we send that word ?
#Text=says I. We are here in a desert place , which yet we dare not leave ; and unless ye get the fowls of the air to be your messengers , I see not what we shall be able to do .
#Text=Ay ?
#Text=said Alan .
#Text=Ye 're a man of small contrivance , David .
#Text=Thereupon he fell in a muse , looking in the embers of the fire ; and presently , getting a piece of wood , he fashioned it in a cross , the four ends of which he blackened on the coals .
#Text=Then he looked at me a little shyly .
#Text=Could ye lend me my button ?
#Text=says he .
#Text=It seems a strange thing to ask a gift again , but I own I am laith to cut another .

#Text=I gave him the button ; whereupon he strung it on a strip of his great-coat which he had used to bind the cross ; and tying in a little sprig of birch and another of fir , he looked upon his work with satisfaction .
#Text=Now , said he , there is a little clachan ( what is called a hamlet in the English ) not very far from Corrynakiegh , and it has the name of Koalisnacoan .
#Text=There there are living many friends of mine whom I could trust with my life , and some that I am no just so sure of .
#Text=Ye see , David , there will be money set upon our heads ; James himsel'is to set money on them ; and as for the Campbells , they would never spare siller where there was a Stewart to be hurt .
#Text=If it was otherwise , I would go down to Koalisnacoan whatever , and trust my life into these people 's hands as lightly as I would trust another with my glove .
#Text=But being so ?
#Text=said I. Being so , said he , I would as lief they didnae see me .
#Text=There 's bad folk everywhere , and what 's far worse , weak ones .
#Text=So when it comes dark again , I will steal down into that clachan , and set this that I have been making in the window of a good friend of mine , John Breck Maccoll , a of Appin 's .
#Text=bouman is a tenant who takes stock from the landlord and shares with him the increase .
#Text=With all my heart , says I ; and if he finds it , what is he to think ?
#Text=Well , says Alan , I wish he was a man of more penetration , for by my troth I am afraid he will make little enough of it !
#Text=But this is what I have in my mind .

#Text=This cross is something in the nature of the crosstarrie , or fiery cross , which is the signal of gathering in our clans ; yet he will know well enough the clan is not to rise , for there it is standing in his window , and no word with it .
#Text=So he will say to himsel ' , THE CLAN IS NOT TO RISE , BUT THERE IS SOMETHING .
#Text=Then he will see my button , and that was Duncan Stewart 's .
#Text=And then he will say to himsel ' , THE SON OF DUNCAN IS IN THE HEATHER , AND HAS NEED OF ME .
#Text=Well , said I , it may be .
#Text=But even supposing so , there is a good deal of heather between here and the Forth .
#Text=And that is a very true word , says Alan .

#Text=But then John Breck will see the sprig of birch and the sprig of pine ; and he will say to himsel'(if he is a man of any penetration at all , which I misdoubt ) , ALAN WILL BE LYING IN A WOOD WHICH IS BOTH OF PINES AND BIRCHES .
#Text=Then he will think to himsel ' , THAT IS NOT SO VERY RIFE HEREABOUT ; and then he will come and give us a look up in Corrynakiegh .
#Text=And if he does not , David , the devil may fly away with him , for what I care ; for he will no be worth the salt to his porridge .
#Text=Eh , man , said I , drolling with him a little , you 're very ingenious !
#Text=But would it not be simpler for you to write him a few words in black and white ?

#Text=And that is an excellent observe , Mr. Balfour of Shaws , says Alan , drolling with me ; and it would certainly be much simpler for me to write to him , but it would be a sore job for John Breck to read it .
#Text=He would have to go to the school for two-three years ; and it 's possible we might be wearied waiting on him .
#Text=So that night Alan carried down his fiery cross and set it in the bouman 's window .
#Text=He was troubled when he came back ; for the dogs had barked and the folk run out from their houses ; and he thought he had heard a clatter of arms and seen a red-coat come to one of the doors .

#Text=On all accounts we lay the next day in the borders of the wood and kept a close look-out , so that if it was John Breck that came we might be ready to guide him , and if it was the red-coats we should have time to get away .
#Text=About noon a man was to be spied , straggling up the open side of the mountain in the sun , and looking round him as he came , from under his hand .
#Text=No sooner had Alan seen him than he whistled ; the man turned and came a little towards us : then Alan would give another peep !
#Text=and the man would come still nearer ; and so by the sound of whistling , he was guided to the spot where we lay .
#Text=He was a ragged , wild , bearded man , about forty , grossly disfigured with the small pox , and looked both dull and savage .
#Text=Although his English was very bad and broken , yet Alan ( according to his very handsome use , whenever I was by ) would suffer him to speak no Gaelic .
#Text=Perhaps the strange language made him appear more backward than he really was ; but I thought he had little good-will to serve us , and what he had was the child of terror .
#Text=Alan would have had him carry a message to James ; but the bouman would hear of no message .
#Text=She was forget it , he said in his screaming voice ; and would either have a letter or wash his hands of us .
#Text=I thought Alan would be gravelled at that , for we lacked the means of writing in that desert .

#Text=But he was a man of more resources than I knew ; searched the wood until he found the quill of a cushat-dove , which he shaped into a pen ; made himself a kind of ink with gunpowder from his horn and water from the running stream ; and tearing a corner from his French military commission ( which he carried in his pocket , like a talisman to keep him from the gallows ) , he sat down and wrote as follows : DEAR KINSMAN send the money by the bearer to the place he kens of .
#Text=Your affectionate cousin , A. S. This he intrusted to the bouman , who promised to make what manner of speed he best could , and carried it off with him down the hill .

#Text=He was three full days gone , but about five in the evening of the third , we heard a whistling in the wood , which Alan answered ; and presently the bouman came up the water-side , looking for us , right and left .
#Text=He seemed less sulky than before , and indeed he was no doubt well pleased to have got to the end of such a dangerous commission .

#Text=He gave us the news of the country ; that it was alive with red-coats ; that arms were being found , and poor folk brought in trouble daily ; and that James and some of his servants were already clapped in prison at Fort William , under strong suspicion of complicity .
#Text=It seemed it was noised on all sides that Alan Breck had fired the shot ; and there was a bill issued for both him and me , with one hundred pounds reward .
#Text=This was all as bad as could be ; and the little note the bouman had carried us from Mrs. Stewart was of a miserable sadness .
#Text=In it she besought Alan not to let himself be captured , assuring him , if he fell in the hands of the troops , both he and James were no better than dead men .
#Text=The money she had sent was all that she could beg or borrow , and she prayed heaven we could be doing with it .
#Text=Lastly , she said , she enclosed us one of the bills in which we were described .

#Text=This we looked upon with great curiosity and not a little fear , partly as a man may look in a mirror , partly as he might look into the barrel of an enemy 's gun to judge if it be truly aimed .

#Text=Alan was advertised as a small , pock-marked , active man of thirty-five or thereby , dressed in a feathered hat , a French side-coat of blue with silver buttons , and lace a great deal tarnished , a red waistcoat and breeches of black , shag ; and I as a tall strong lad of about eighteen , wearing an old blue coat , very ragged , an old Highland bonnet , a long homespun waistcoat , blue breeches ; his legs bare , low-country shoes , wanting the toes ; speaks like a Lowlander , and has no beard .
#Text=Alan was well enough pleased to see his finery so fully remembered and set down ; only when he came to the word tarnish , he looked upon his lace like one a little mortified .

#Text=As for myself , I thought I cut a miserable figure in the bill ; and yet was well enough pleased too , for since I had changed these rags , the description had ceased to be a danger and become a source of safety .
#Text=Alan , said I , you should change your clothes .
#Text=Na , troth !
#Text=said Alan , I have nae others .
#Text=A fine sight I would be , if I went back to France in a bonnet !
#Text=This put a second reflection in my mind : that if I were to separate from Alan and his tell-tale clothes I should be safe against arrest , and might go openly about my business .
#Text=Nor was this all ; for suppose I was arrested when I was alone , there was little against me ; but suppose I was taken in company with the reputed murderer , my case would begin to be grave .
#Text=For generosity 's sake I dare not speak my mind upon this head ; but I thought of it none the less .
#Text=I thought of it all the more , too , when the bouman brought out a green purse with four guineas in gold , and the best part of another in small change .
#Text=True , it was more than I had .

#Text=But then Alan , with less than five guineas , had to get as far as France ; I , with my less than two , not beyond Queensferry ; so that taking things in their proportion , Alan 's society was not only a peril to my life , but a burden on my purse .
#Text=But there was no thought of the sort in the honest head of my companion .
#Text=He believed he was serving , helping , and protecting me .
#Text=And what could I do but hold my peace , and chafe , and take my chance of it ?
#Text=It 's little enough , said Alan , putting the purse in his pocket , but it 'll do my business .
#Text=And now , John Breck , if ye will hand me over my button , this gentleman and me will be for taking the road .

#Text=But the bouman , after feeling about in a hairy purse that hung in front of him in the Highland manner ( though he wore otherwise the Lowland habit , with sea-trousers ) , began to roll his eyes strangely , and at last said , Her nainsel will loss it , meaning he thought he had lost it .
#Text=What !
#Text=cried Alan , you will lose my button , that was my father 's before me ?
#Text=Now I will tell you what is in my mind , John Breck : it is in my mind this is the worst day 's work that ever ye did since ye was born .
#Text=And as Alan spoke , he set his hands on his knees and looked at the bouman with a smiling mouth , and that dancing light in his eyes that meant mischief to his enemies .

#Text=Perhaps the bouman was honest enough ; perhaps he had meant to cheat and then , finding himself alone with two of us in a desert place , cast back to honesty as being safer ; at least , and all at once , he seemed to find that button and handed it to Alan .

#Text=Well , and it is a good thing for the honour of the Maccolls , said Alan , and then to me , Here is my button back again , and I thank you for parting with it , which is of a piece with all your friendships to me .
#Text=Then he took the warmest parting of the bouman .
#Text=For , says he , ye have done very well by me , and set your neck at a venture , and I will always give you the name of a good man .
#Text=Lastly , the bouman took himself off by one way ; and Alan and I ( getting our chattels together ) struck into another to resume our flight .
#Text=CHAPTER XXII THE FLIGHT IN THE HEATHER : THE MOOR Some seven hours'incessant , hard travelling brought us early in the morning to the end of a range of mountains .
#Text=In front of us there lay a piece of low , broken , desert land , which we must now cross .

#Text=The sun was not long up , and shone straight in our eyes ; a little , thin mist went up from the face of the moorland like a smoke ; so that ( as Alan said ) there might have been twenty squadron of dragoons there and we none the wiser .
#Text=We sat down , therefore , in a howe of the hill-side till the mist should have risen , and made ourselves a dish of drammach , and held a council of war .
#Text=David , said Alan , this is the kittle bit .
#Text=Shall we lie here till it comes night , or shall we risk it , and stave on ahead ?
#Text=Well , said I , I am tired indeed , but I could walk as far again , if that was all .
#Text=Ay , but it isnae , said Alan , nor yet the half .
#Text=This is how we stand : Appin 's fair death to us .
#Text=To the south it 's all Campbells , and no to be thought of .
#Text=To the north ; well , there 's no muckle to be gained by going north ; neither for you , that wants to get to Queensferry , nor yet for me , that wants to get to France .
#Text=Well , then , we 'll can strike east .
#Text=East be it !
#Text=says I , quite cheerily ; but I was thinking in to myself : O , man , if you would only take one point of the compass and let me take any other , it would be the best for both of us .
#Text=Well , then , east , ye see , we have the muirs , said Alan .
#Text=Once there , David , it 's mere pitch-and-toss .
#Text=Out on yon bald , naked , flat place , where can a body turn to ?
#Text=Let the red-coats come over a hill , they can spy you miles away ; and the sorrow 's in their horses'heels , they would soon ride you down .
#Text=It 's no good place , David ; and I 'm free to say , it 's worse by daylight than by dark .
#Text=Alan , said I , hear my way of it .

#Text=Appin 's death for us ; we have none too much money , nor yet meal ; the longer they seek , the nearer they may guess where we are ; it 's all a risk ; and I give my word to go ahead until we drop .
#Text=Alan was delighted .

#Text=There are whiles , said he , when ye are altogether too canny and Whiggish to be company for a gentleman like me ; but there come other whiles when ye show yoursel'a mettle spark ; and it 's then , David , that I love ye like a brother .

#Text=The mist rose and died away , and showed us that country lying as waste as the sea ; only the moorfowl and the pewees crying upon it , and far over to the east , a herd of deer , moving like dots .

#Text=Much of it was red with heather ; much of the rest broken up with bogs and hags and peaty pools ; some had been burnt black in a heath fire ; and in another place there was quite a forest of dead firs , standing like skeletons .
#Text=A wearier-looking desert man never saw ; but at least it was clear of troops , which was our point .
#Text=We went down accordingly into the waste , and began to make our toilsome and devious travel towards the eastern verge .

#Text=There were the tops of mountains all round ( you are to remember ) from whence we might be spied at any moment ; so it behoved us to keep in the hollow parts of the moor , and when these turned aside from our direction to move upon its naked face with infinite care .
#Text=Sometimes , for half an hour together , we must crawl from one heather bush to another , as hunters do when they are hard upon the deer .

#Text=It was a clear day again , with a blazing sun ; the water in the brandy bottle was soon gone ; and altogether , if I had guessed what it would be to crawl half the time upon my belly and to walk much of the rest stooping nearly to the knees , I should certainly have held back from such a killing enterprise .
#Text=Toiling and resting and toiling again , we wore away the morning ; and about noon lay down in a thick bush of heather to sleep .
#Text=Alan took the first watch ; and it seemed to me I had scarce closed my eyes before I was shaken up to take the second .

#Text=We had no clock to go by ; and Alan stuck a sprig of heath in the ground to serve instead ; so that as soon as the shadow of the bush should fall so far to the east , I might know to rouse him .

#Text=But I was by this time so weary that I could have slept twelve hours at a stretch ; I had the taste of sleep in my throat ; my joints slept even when my mind was waking ; the hot smell of the heather , and the drone of the wild bees , were like possets to me ; and every now and again I would give a jump and find I had been dozing .
#Text=The last time I woke I seemed to come back from farther away , and thought the sun had taken a great start in the heavens .
#Text=I looked at the sprig of heath , and at that I could have cried aloud : for I saw I had betrayed my trust .
#Text=My head was nearly turned with fear and shame ; and at what I saw , when I looked out around me on the moor , my heart was like dying in my body .

#Text=For sure enough , a body of horse-soldiers had come down during my sleep , and were drawing near to us from the south-east , spread out in the shape of a fan and riding their horses to and fro in the deep parts of the heather .

#Text=When I waked Alan , he glanced first at the soldiers , then at the mark and the position of the sun , and knitted his brows with a sudden , quick look , both ugly and anxious , which was all the reproach I had of him .
#Text=What are we to do now ?
#Text=I asked .
#Text=We 'll have to play at being hares , said he .
#Text=Do ye see yon mountain ?
#Text=pointing to one on the north-eastern sky .
#Text=Ay , said I. Well , then , says he , let us strike for that .
#Text=Its name is Ben Alder .
#Text=it is a wild , desert mountain full of hills and hollows , and if we can win to it before the morn , we may do yet .
#Text=But , Alan , cried I , that will take us across the very coming of the soldiers !
#Text=I ken that fine , said he ; but if we are driven back on Appin , we are two dead men .
#Text=So now , David man , be brisk !
#Text=With that he began to run forward on his hands and knees with an incredible quickness , as though it were his natural way of going .
#Text=All the time , too , he kept winding in and out in the lower parts of the moorland where we were the best concealed .
#Text=Some of these had been burned or at least scathed with fire ; and there rose in our faces ( which were close to the ground ) a blinding , choking dust as fine as smoke .
#Text=The water was long out ; and this posture of running on the hands and knees brings an overmastering weakness and weariness , so that the joints ache and the wrists faint under your weight .
#Text=Now and then , indeed , where was a big bush of heather , we lay awhile , and panted , and putting aside the leaves , looked back at the dragoons .
#Text=They had not spied us , for they held straight on ; a half-troop , I think , covering about two miles of ground , and beating it mighty thoroughly as they went .
#Text=I had awakened just in time ; a little later , and we must have fled in front of them , instead of escaping on one side .
#Text=Even as it was , the least misfortune might betray us ; and now and again , when a grouse rose out of the heather with a clap of wings , we lay as still as the dead and were afraid to breathe .

#Text=The aching and faintness of my body , the labouring of my heart , the soreness of my hands , and the smarting of my throat and eyes in the continual smoke of dust and ashes , had soon grown to be so unbearable that I would gladly have given up .
#Text=Nothing but the fear of Alan lent me enough of a false kind of courage to continue .

#Text=As for himself ( and you are to bear in mind that he was cumbered with a great-coat ) he had first turned crimson , but as time went on the redness began to be mingled with patches of white ; his breath cried and whistled as it came ; and his voice , when he whispered his observations in my ear during our halts , sounded like nothing human .
#Text=Yet he seemed in no way dashed in spirits , nor did he at all abate in his activity , so that I was driven to marvel at the man 's endurance .
#Text=At length , in the first gloaming of the night , we heard a trumpet sound , and looking back from among the heather , saw the troop beginning to collect .
#Text=A little after , they had built a fire and camped for the night , about the middle of the waste .
#Text=At this I begged and besought that we might lie down and sleep .
#Text=There shall be no sleep the night !
#Text=said Alan .
#Text=From now on , these weary dragoons of yours will keep the crown of the muirland , and none will get out of Appin but winged fowls .
#Text=We got through in the nick of time , and shall we jeopard what we 've gained ?
#Text=Na , na , when the day comes , it shall find you and me in a fast place on Ben Alder .
#Text=Alan , I said , it 's not the want of will : it 's the strength that I want .
#Text=If I could , I would ; but as sure as I 'm alive I cannot .
#Text=Very well , then , said Alan .
#Text=I 'll carry ye .
#Text=I looked to see if he were jesting ; but no , the little man was in dead earnest ; and the sight of so much resolution shamed me .
#Text=Lead away !
#Text=said I. I 'll follow .
#Text=He gave me one look as much as to say , Well done , David !
#Text=and off he set again at his top speed .
#Text=It grew cooler and even a little darker ( but not much ) with the coming of the night .

#Text=The sky was cloudless ; it was still early in July , and pretty far north ; in the darkest part of that night , you would have needed pretty good eyes to read , but for all that , I have often seen it darker in a winter mid-day .
#Text=Heavy dew fell and drenched the moor like rain ; and this refreshed me for a while .

#Text=When we stopped to breathe , and I had time to see all about me , the clearness and sweetness of the night , the shapes of the hills like things asleep , and the fire dwindling away behind us , like a bright spot in the midst of the moor , anger would come upon me in a clap that I must still drag myself in agony and eat the dust like a worm .
#Text=By what I have read in books , I think few that have held a pen were ever really wearied , or they would write of it more strongly .
#Text=I had no care of my life , neither past nor future , and I scarce remembered there was such a lad as David Balfour .
#Text=I did not think of myself , but just of each fresh step which I was sure would be my last , with despair--and of Alan , who was the cause of it , with hatred .

#Text=Alan was in the right trade as a soldier ; this is the officer 's part to make men continue to do things , they know not wherefore , and when , if the choice was offered , they would lie down where they were and be killed .
#Text=And I dare say I would have made a good enough private ; for in these last hours it never occurred to me that I had any choice but just to obey as long as I was able , and die obeying .
#Text=Day began to come in , after years , I thought ; and by that time we were past the greatest danger , and could walk upon our feet like men , instead of crawling like brutes .
#Text=But , dear heart have mercy !
#Text=what a pair we must have made , going double like old grandfathers , stumbling like babes , and as white as dead folk .

#Text=Never a word passed between us ; each set his mouth and kept his eyes in front of him , and lifted up his foot and set it down again , like people lifting weights at a country play ; all the while , with the moorfowl crying peep !
#Text=in the heather , and the light coming slowly clearer in the east .
#Text=Village fair .
#Text=I say Alan did as I did .

#Text=Not that ever I looked at him , for I had enough ado to keep my feet ; but because it is plain he must have been as stupid with weariness as myself , and looked as little where we were going , or we should not have walked into an ambush like blind men .
#Text=It fell in this way .

#Text=We were going down a heathery brae , Alan leading and I following a pace or two behind , like a fiddler and his wife ; when upon a sudden the heather gave a rustle , three or four ragged men leaped out , and the next moment we were lying on our backs , each with a dirk at his throat .
#Text=I do n't think I cared ; the pain of this rough handling was quite swallowed up by the pains of which I was already full ; and I was too glad to have stopped walking to mind about a dirk .
#Text=I lay looking up in the face of the man that held me ; and I mind his face was black with the sun , and his eyes very light , but I was not afraid of him .
#Text=I heard Alan and another whispering in the Gaelic ; and what they said was all one to me .
#Text=Then the dirks were put up , our weapons were taken away , and we were set face to face , sitting in the heather .
#Text=They are Cluny 's men , said Alan .
#Text=We couldnae have fallen better .
#Text=We 're just to bide here with these , which are his out-sentries , till they can get word to the chief of my arrival .

#Text=Now Cluny Macpherson , the chief of the clan Vourich , had been one of the leaders of the great rebellion six years before ; there was a price on his life ; and I had supposed him long ago in France , with the rest of the heads of that desperate party .
#Text=Even tired as I was , the surprise of what I heard half wakened me .
#Text=What , I cried , is Cluny still here ?
#Text=Ay , is he so !
#Text=said Alan .
#Text=Still in his own country and kept by his own clan .
#Text=King George can do no more .
#Text=I think I would have asked farther , but Alan gave me the put-off .
#Text=I am rather wearied , he said , and I would like fine to get a sleep .
#Text=And without more words , he rolled on his face in a deep heather bush , and seemed to sleep at once .
#Text=There was no such thing possible for me .
#Text=You have heard grasshoppers whirring in the grass in the summer time ?

#Text=Well , I had no sooner closed my eyes , than my body , and above all my head , belly , and wrists , seemed to be filled with whirring grasshoppers ; and I must open my eyes again at once , and tumble and toss , and sit up and lie down ; and look at the sky which dazzled me , or at Cluny 's wild and dirty sentries , peering out over the top of the brae and chattering to each other in the Gaelic .
#Text=That was all the rest I had , until the messenger returned ; when , as it appeared that Cluny would be glad to receive us , we must get once more upon our feet and set forward .

#Text=Alan was in excellent good spirits , much refreshed by his sleep , very hungry , and looking pleasantly forward to a dram and a dish of hot collops , of which , it seems , the messenger had brought him word .
#Text=For my part , it made me sick to hear of eating .
#Text=I had been dead-heavy before , and now I felt a kind of dreadful lightness , which would not suffer me to walk .
#Text=I drifted like a gossamer ; the ground seemed to me a cloud , the hills a feather-weight , the air to have a current , like a running burn , which carried me to and fro .
#Text=With all that , a sort of horror of despair sat on my mind , so that I could have wept at my own helplessness .
#Text=I saw Alan knitting his brows at me , and supposed it was in anger ; and that gave me a pang of light-headed fear , like what a child may have .
#Text=I remember , too , that I was smiling , and could not stop smiling , hard as I tried ; for I thought it was out of place at such a time .

#Text=But my good companion had nothing in his mind but kindness ; and the next moment , two of the gillies had me by the arms , and I began to be carried forward with great swiftness ( or so it appeared to me , although I dare say it was slowly enough in truth ) , through a labyrinth of dreary glens and hollows and into the heart of that dismal mountain of Ben Alder .
#Text=CHAPTER XXIII CLUNY 'S CAGE We came at last to the foot of an exceeding steep wood , which scrambled up a craggy hillside , and was crowned by a naked precipice .
#Text=It 's here , said one of the guides , and we struck up hill .
#Text=The trees clung upon the slope , like sailors on the shrouds of a ship , and their trunks were like the rounds of a ladder , by which we mounted .
#Text=Quite at the top , and just before the rocky face of the cliff sprang above the foliage , we found that strange house which was known in the country as Cluny 's Cage .
#Text=The trunks of several trees had been wattled across , the intervals strengthened with stakes , and the ground behind O , said he , I can do fine wanting it .
#Text=I 'll take the ale , though , for it slockens ( moistens ) my cough .
#Text=He drank the cup about half out , still keeping an eye upon me as he drank ; and then suddenly held out his hand .
#Text=Let 's see the letter , said he .
#Text=I told him the letter was for Mr. Balfour ; not for him .
#Text=And who do ye think I am ?
#Text=says he .
#Text=Give me Alexander 's letter .
#Text=You know my father 's name ?

#Text=It would be strange if I didnae , he returned , for he was my born brother ; and little as ye seem to like either me or my house , or my good parritch , I 'm your born uncle , Davie , my man , and you my born nephew .
#Text=So give us the letter , and sit down and fill your kyte .
#Text=If I had been some years younger , what with shame , weariness , and disappointment , I believe I had burst into tears .
#Text=As it was , I could find no words , neither black nor white , but handed him the letter , and sat down to the porridge with as little appetite for meat as ever a young man had .
#Text=Meanwhile , my uncle , stooping over the fire , turned the letter over and over in his hands .
#Text=Do ye ken what 's in it ?
#Text=he asked , suddenly .
#Text=You see for yourself , sir , said I , that the seal has not been broken .
#Text=Ay , said he , but what brought you here ?
#Text=To give the letter , said I. No , says he , cunningly , but ye 'll have had some hopes , nae doubt ?
#Text=I confess , sir , said I , when I was told that I had kinsfolk well-to-do , I did indeed indulge the hope that they might help me in my life .
#Text=But I am no beggar ; I look for no favours at your hands , and I want none that are not freely given .
#Text=For as poor as I appear , I have friends of my own that will be blithe to help me .
#Text=Hoot-toot !
#Text=said Uncle Ebenezer , dinnae fly up in the snuff at me .
#Text=We 'll agree fine yet .
#Text=And , Davie , my man , if you 're done with that bit parritch , I could just take a sup of it myself .
#Text=Ay , he continued , as soon as he had ousted me from the stool and spoon , they 're fine , halesome food--they 're grand food , parritch .
#Text=He murmured a little grace to himself and fell to .
#Text=Your father was very fond of his meat , I mind ; he was a hearty , if not a great eater ; but as for me , I could never do mair than pyke at food .
#Text=He took a pull at the small beer , which probably reminded him of hospitable duties , for his next speech ran thus : If ye 're dry ye 'll find water behind the door .
#Text=To this I returned no answer , standing stiffly on my two feet , and looking down upon my uncle with a mighty angry heart .
#Text=He , on his part , continued to eat like a man under some pressure of time , and to throw out little darting glances now at my shoes and now at my home-spun stockings .
#Text=Once only , when he had ventured to look a little higher , our eyes met ; and no thief taken with a hand in a man 's pocket could have shown more lively signals of distress .

#Text=This set me in a muse , whether his timidity arose from too long a disuse of any human company ; and whether perhaps , upon a little trial , it might pass off , and my uncle change into an altogether different man .
#Text=From this I was awakened by his sharp voice .
#Text=Your father 's been long dead ?
#Text=he asked .
#Text=Three weeks , sir , said I. He was a secret man , Alexander--a secret , silent man , he continued .
#Text=He never said muckle when he was young .
#Text=He 'll never have spoken muckle of me ?
#Text=I never knew , sir , till you told it me yourself , that he had any brother .
#Text=Dear me , dear me !
#Text=said Ebenezer .
#Text=Nor yet of Shaws , I dare say ?
#Text=Not so much as the name , sir , said I. To think o'that !
#Text=said he .
#Text=A strange nature of a man !
#Text=For all that , he seemed singularly satisfied , but whether with himself , or me , or with this conduct of my father 's , was more than I could read .

#Text=Certainly , however , he seemed to be outgrowing that distaste , or ill-will , that he had conceived at first against my person ; for presently he jumped up , came across the room behind me , and hit me a smack upon the shoulder .
#Text=We 'll agree fine yet !
#Text=he cried .
#Text=I 'm just as glad I let you in .
#Text=And now come awa'to your bed .
#Text=To my surprise , he lit no lamp or candle , but set forth into the dark passage , groped his way , breathing deeply , up a flight of steps , and paused before a door , which he unlocked .
#Text=I was close upon his heels , having stumbled after him as best I might ; and then he bade me go in , for that was my chamber .
#Text=I did as he bid , but paused after a few steps , and begged a light to go to bed with .
#Text=Hoot-toot !
#Text=said Uncle Ebenezer , there 's a fine moon .
#Text=Neither moon nor star , sir , and pit-mirk , said I. I cannae see the bed .
#Text=Dark as the pit .
#Text=Hoot-toot , hoot-toot !
#Text=said he .
#Text=Lights in a house is a thing I dinnae agree with .
#Text=I 'm unco feared of fires .
#Text=Good-night to ye , Davie , my man .
#Text=And before I had time to add a further protest , he pulled the door to , and I heard him lock me in from the outside .
#Text=I did not know whether to laugh or cry .

#Text=The room was as cold as a well , and the bed , when I had found my way to it , as damp as a peat-hag ; but by good fortune I had caught up my bundle and my plaid , and rolling myself in the latter , I lay down upon the floor under lee of the big this barricade levelled up with earth to make the floor .
#Text=A tree , which grew out from the hillside , was the living centre-beam of the roof .
#Text=The walls were of wattle and covered with moss .
#Text=The whole house had something of an egg shape ; and it half hung , half stood in that steep , hillside thicket , like a wasp 's nest in a green hawthorn .
#Text=Within , it was large enough to shelter five or six persons with some comfort .

#Text=A projection of the cliff had been cunningly employed to be the fireplace ; and the smoke rising against the face of the rock , and being not dissimilar in colour , readily escaped notice from below .

#Text=This was but one of Cluny 's hiding-places ; he had caves , besides , and underground chambers in several parts of his country ; and following the reports of his scouts , he moved from one to another as the soldiers drew near or moved away .

#Text=By this manner of living , and thanks to the affection of his clan , he had not only stayed all this time in safety , while so many others had fled or been taken and slain : but stayed four or five years longer , and only went to France at last by the express command of his master .
#Text=There he soon died ; and it is strange to reflect that he may have regretted his Cage upon Ben Alder .
#Text=When we came to the door he was seated by his rock chimney , watching a gillie about some cookery .
#Text=He was mighty plainly habited , with a knitted nightcap drawn over his ears , and smoked a foul cutty pipe .
#Text=For all that he had the manners of a king , and it was quite a sight to see him rise out of his place to welcome us .
#Text=Well , Mr. Stewart , come awa ' , sir !
#Text=said he , and bring in your friend that as yet I dinna ken the name of .
#Text=And how is yourself , Cluny ?
#Text=said Alan .
#Text=I hope ye do brawly , sir .
#Text=And I am proud to see ye , and to present to ye my friend the Laird of Shaws , Mr. David Balfour .
#Text=Alan never referred to my estate without a touch of a sneer , when we were alone ; but with strangers , he rang the words out like a herald .
#Text=Step in by , the both of ye , gentlemen , says Cluny .
#Text=I make ye welcome to my house , which is a queer , rude place for certain , but one where I have entertained a royal personage , Mr. Stewart--ye doubtless ken the personage I have in my eye .
#Text=We 'll take a dram for luck , and as soon as this handless man of mine has the collops ready , we 'll dine and take a hand at the cartes as gentlemen should .

#Text=My life is a bit driegh , says he , pouring out the brandy ; I see little company , and sit and twirl my thumbs , and mind upon a great day that is gone by , and weary for another great day that we all hope will be upon the road .
#Text=And so here 's a toast to ye : The Restoration !
#Text=Thereupon we all touched glasses and drank .
#Text=I am sure I wished no ill to King George ; and if he had been there himself in proper person , it 's like he would have done as I did .

#Text=No sooner had I taken out the drain than I felt hugely better , and could look on and listen , still a little mistily perhaps , but no longer with the same groundless horror and distress of mind .
#Text=It was certainly a strange place , and we had a strange host .
#Text=In his long hiding , Cluny had grown to have all manner of precise habits , like those of an old maid .

#Text=He had a particular place , where no one else must sit ; the Cage was arranged in a particular way , which none must disturb ; cookery was one of his chief fancies , and even while he was greeting us in , he kept an eye to the collops .

#Text=It appears , he sometimes visited or received visits from his wife and one or two of his nearest friends , under the cover of night ; but for the more part lived quite alone , and communicated only with his sentinels and the gillies that waited on him in the Cage .
#Text=The first thing in the morning , one of them , who was a barber , came and shaved him , and gave him the news of the country , of which he was immoderately greedy .

#Text=There was no end to his questions ; he put them as earnestly as a child ; and at some of the answers , laughed out of all bounds of reason , and would break out again laughing at the mere memory , hours after the barber was gone .

#Text=To be sure , there might have been a purpose in his questions ; for though he was thus sequestered , and like the other landed gentlemen of Scotland , stripped by the late Act of Parliament of legal powers , he still exercised a patriarchal justice in his clan .

#Text=Disputes were brought to him in his hiding-hole to be decided ; and the men of his country , who would have snapped their fingers at the Court of Session , laid aside revenge and paid down money at the bare word of this forfeited and hunted outlaw .

#Text=When he was angered , which was often enough , he gave his commands and breathed threats of punishment like any king ; and his gillies trembled and crouched away from him like children before a hasty father .
#Text=With each of them , as he entered , he ceremoniously shook hands , both parties touching their bonnets at the same time in a military manner .

#Text=Altogether , I had a fair chance to see some of the inner workings of a Highland clan ; and this with a proscribed , fugitive chief ; his country conquered ; the troops riding upon all sides in quest of him , sometimes within a mile of where he lay ; and when the least of the ragged fellows whom he rated and threatened , could have made a fortune by betraying him .
#Text=On that first day , as soon as the collops were ready , Cluny gave them with his own hand a squeeze of a lemon ( for he was well supplied with luxuries ) and bade us draw in to our meal .

#Text=They , said he , meaning the collops , are such as I gave his Royal Highness in this very house ; bating the lemon juice , for at that time we were glad to get the meat and never fashed for Indeed , there were mair dragoons than lemons in my country in the year forty-six .
#Text=Condiment .
#Text=I do not know if the collops were truly very good , but my heart rose against the sight of them , and I could eat but little .
#Text=All the while Cluny entertained us with stories of Prince Charlie 's stay in the Cage , giving us the very words of the speakers , and rising from his place to show us where they stood .
#Text=By these , I gathered the Prince was a gracious , spirited boy , like the son of a race of polite kings , but not so wise as Solomon .
#Text=I gathered , too , that while he was in the Cage , he was often drunk ; so the fault that has since , by all accounts , made such a wreck of him , had even then begun to show itself .

#Text=We were no sooner done eating than Cluny brought out an old , thumbed , greasy pack of cards , such as you may find in a mean inn ; and his eyes brightened in his face as he proposed that we should fall to playing .

#Text=Now this was one of the things I had been brought up to eschew like disgrace ; it being held by my father neither the part of a Christian nor yet of a gentleman to set his own livelihood and fish for that of others , on the cast of painted pasteboard .
#Text=To be sure , I might have pleaded my fatigue , which was excuse enough ; but I thought it behoved that I should bear a testimony .
#Text=I must have got very red in the face , but I spoke steadily , and told them I had no call to be a judge of others , but for my own part , it was a matter in which I had no clearness .
#Text=Cluny stopped mingling the cards .
#Text=What in deil 's name is this ?
#Text=says he .
#Text=What kind of Whiggish , canting talk is this , for the house of Cluny Macpherson ?
#Text=I will put my hand in the fire for Mr. Balfour , says Alan .
#Text=He is an honest and a mettle gentleman , and I would have ye bear in mind who says it .
#Text=I bear a king 's name , says he , cocking his hat ; and I and any that I call friend are company for the best .
#Text=But the gentleman is tired , and should sleep ; if he has no mind to the cartes , it will never hinder you and me .
#Text=And I 'm fit and willing , sir , to play ye any game that ye can name .
#Text=Sir , says Cluny , in this poor house of mine I would have you to ken that any gentleman may follow his pleasure .
#Text=If your friend would like to stand on his head , he is welcome .
#Text=And if either he , or you , or any other man , is not preceesely satisfied , I will be proud to step outside with him .
#Text=I had no will that these two friends should cut their throats for my sake .
#Text=Sir , said I , I am very wearied , as Alan says ; and what 's more , as you are a man that likely has sons of your own , I may tell you it was a promise to my father .
#Text=Say nae mair , say nae mair , said Cluny , and pointed me to a bed of heather in a corner of the Cage .
#Text=For all that he was displeased enough , looked at me askance , and grumbled when he looked .
#Text=And indeed it must be owned that both my scruples and the words in which I declared them , smacked somewhat of the Covenanter , and were little in their place among wild Highland Jacobites .

#Text=What with the brandy and the venison , a strange heaviness had come over me ; and I had scarce lain down upon the bed before I fell into a kind of trance , in which I continued almost the whole time of our stay in the Cage .

#Text=Sometimes I was broad awake and understood what passed ; sometimes I only heard voices , or men snoring , like the voice of a silly river ; and the plaids upon the wall dwindled down and swelled out again , like firelight shadows on the roof .

#Text=I must sometimes have spoken or cried out , for I remember I was now and then amazed at being answered ; yet I was conscious of no particular nightmare , only of a general , black , abiding horror--a horror of the place I was in , and the bed I lay in , and the plaids on the wall , and the voices , and the fire , and myself .

#Text=The barber-gillie , who was a doctor too , was called in to prescribe for me ; but as he spoke in the Gaelic , I understood not a word of his opinion , and was too sick even to ask for a translation .
#Text=I knew well enough I was ill , and that was all I cared about .
#Text=I paid little heed while I lay in this poor pass .

#Text=But Alan and Cluny were most of the time at the cards , and I am clear that Alan must have begun by winning ; for I remember sitting up , and seeing them hard at it , and a great glittering pile of as much as sixty or a hundred guineas on the table .
#Text=It looked strange enough , to see all this wealth in a nest upon a cliff-side , wattled about growing trees .
#Text=And even then , I thought it seemed deep water for Alan to be riding , who had no better battle-horse than a green purse and a matter of five pounds .
#Text=The luck , it seems , changed on the second day .
#Text=About noon I was wakened as usual for dinner , and as usual refused to eat , and was given a dram with some bitter infusion which the barber had prescribed .
#Text=The sun was shining in at the open door of the Cage , and this dazzled and offended me .
#Text=Cluny sat at the table , biting the pack of cards .
#Text=Alan had stooped over the bed , and had his face close to my eyes ; to which , troubled as they were with the fever , it seemed of the most shocking bigness .
#Text=He asked me for a loan of my money .
#Text=What for ?
#Text=said I. O , just for a loan , said he .
#Text=But why ?
#Text=I repeated .
#Text=I do n't see .
#Text=Hut , David !
#Text=said Alan , ye wouldnae grudge me a loan ?
#Text=I would , though , if I had had my senses !
#Text=But all I thought of then was to get his face away , and I handed him my money .

#Text=On the morning of the third day , when we had been forty-eight hours in the Cage , I awoke with a great relief of spirits , very weak and weary indeed , but seeing things of the right size and with their honest , everyday appearance .
#Text=I had a mind to eat , moreover , rose from bed of my own movement , and as soon as we had breakfasted , stepped to the entry of the Cage and sat down outside in the top of the wood .

#Text=It was a grey day with a cool , mild air : and I sat in a dream all morning , only disturbed by the passing by of Cluny 's scouts and servants coming with provisions and reports ; for as the coast was at that time clear , you might almost say he held court openly .
#Text=When I returned , he and Alan had laid the cards aside , and were questioning a gillie ; and the chief turned about and spoke to me in the Gaelic .
#Text=I have no Gaelic , sir , said I. Now since the card question , everything I said or did had the power of annoying Cluny .
#Text=Your name has more sense than yourself , then , said he angrily , for it 's good Gaelic .
#Text=But the point is this .
#Text=My scout reports all clear in the south , and the question is , have ye the strength to go ?
#Text=I saw cards on the table , but no gold ; only a heap of little written papers , and these all on Cluny 's side .
#Text=Alan , besides , had an odd look , like a man not very well content ; and I began to have a strong misgiving .
#Text=I do not know if I am as well as I should be , said I , looking at Alan ; but the little money we have has a long way to carry us .
#Text=Alan took his under-lip into his mouth , and looked upon the ground .
#Text=David , says he at last , I 've lost it ; there 's the naked truth .
#Text=My money too ?
#Text=said I. Your money too , says Alan , with a groan .
#Text=Ye shouldnae have given it me .
#Text=I 'm daft when I get to the cartes .
#Text=Hoot-toot !
#Text=hoot-toot !
#Text=said Cluny .
#Text=It was all daffing ; it 's all nonsense .
#Text=Of course you 'll have your money back again , and the double of it , if ye 'll make so free with me .
#Text=It would be a singular thing for me to keep it .
#Text=It 's not to be supposed that I would be any hindrance to gentlemen in your situation ; that would be a singular thing !
#Text=cries he , and began to pull gold out of his pocket with a mighty red face .
#Text=Alan said nothing , only looked on the ground .
#Text=Will you step to the door with me , sir ?
#Text=said I. Cluny said he would be very glad , and followed me readily enough , but he looked flustered and put out .
#Text=And now , sir , says I , I must first acknowledge your generosity .
#Text=Nonsensical nonsense !
#Text=cries Cluny .
#Text=Where 's the generosity ?
#Text=This is just a most unfortunate affair ; but what would ye have me do--boxed up in this bee-skep of a cage of mine--but just set my friends to the cartes , when I can get them ?
#Text=And if they lose , of course , it 's not to be supposed -- -- And here he came to a pause .
#Text=Yes , said I , if they lose , you give them back their money ; and if they win , they carry away yours in their pouches !
#Text=I have said before that I grant your generosity ; but to me , sir , it 's a very painful thing to be placed in this position .
#Text=There was a little silence , in which Cluny seemed always as if he was about to speak , but said nothing .
#Text=All the time he grew redder and redder in the face .
#Text=I am a young man , said I , and I ask your advice .
#Text=Advise me as you would your son .
#Text=My friend fairly lost his money , after having fairly gained a far greater sum of yours ; can I accept it back again ?
#Text=Would that be the right part for me to play ?
#Text=Whatever I do , you can see for yourself it must be hard upon a man of any pride .
#Text=It 's rather hard on me , too , Mr. Balfour , said Cluny , and ye give me very much the look of a man that has entrapped poor people to their hurt .
#Text=I wouldnae have my friends come to any house of mine to accept affronts ; no , he cried , with a sudden heat of anger , nor yet to give them !
#Text=And so you see , sir , said I , there is something to be said upon my side ; and this gambling is a very poor employ for gentlefolks .
#Text=But I am still waiting your opinion .
#Text=I am sure if ever Cluny hated any man it was David Balfour .
#Text=He looked me all over with a warlike eye , and I saw the challenge at his lips .
#Text=But either my youth disarmed him , or perhaps his own sense of justice .
#Text=Certainly it was a mortifying matter for all concerned , and not least Cluny ; the more credit that he took it as he did .
#Text=Mr. Balfour , said he , I think you are too nice and covenanting , but for all that you have the spirit of a very pretty gentleman .
#Text=Upon my honest word , ye may take this money--it 's what I would tell my son--and here 's my hand along with it !

#Text=CHAPTER XXIV THE FLIGHT IN THE HEATHER : THE QUARREL Alan and I were put across Loch Errocht under cloud of night , and went down its eastern shore to another hiding-place near the head of Loch Rannoch , whither we were led by one of the gillies from the Cage .

#Text=This fellow carried all our luggage and Alan 's great-coat in the bargain , trotting along under the burthen , far less than the half of which used to weigh me to the ground , like a stout hill pony with a feather ; yet he was a man that , in plain contest , I could have broken on my knee .
#Text=Doubtless it was a great relief to walk disencumbered ; and perhaps without that relief , and the consequent sense of liberty and lightness , I could not have walked at all .

#Text=I was but new risen from a bed of sickness ; and there was nothing in the state of our affairs to hearten me for much exertion ; travelling , as we did , over the most dismal deserts in Scotland , under a cloudy heaven , and with divided hearts among the travellers .

#Text=For long , we said nothing ; marching alongside or one behind the other , each with a set countenance : I , angry and proud , and drawing what strength I had from these two violent and sinful feelings ; Alan angry and ashamed , ashamed that he had lost my money , angry that I should take it so ill .
#Text=The thought of a separation ran always the stronger in my mind ; and the more I approved of it , the more ashamed I grew of my approval .
#Text=It would be a fine , handsome , generous thing , indeed , for Alan to turn round and say to me : Go , I am in the most danger , and my company only increases yours .

#Text=But for me to turn to the friend who certainly loved me , and say to him : You are in great danger , I am in but little ; your friendship is a burden ; go , take your risks and bear your hardships alone -- -- no , that was impossible ; and even to think of it privily to myself , made my cheeks to burn .
#Text=And yet Alan had behaved like a child , and ( what is worse ) a treacherous child .

#Text=Wheedling my money from me while I lay half-conscious was scarce better than theft ; and yet here he was trudging by my side , without a penny to his name , and by what I could see , quite blithe to sponge upon the money he had driven me to beg .
#Text=True , I was ready to share it with him ; but it made me rage to see him count upon my readiness .
#Text=These were the two things uppermost in my mind ; and I could open my mouth upon neither without black ungenerosity .
#Text=So I did the next worst , and said nothing , nor so much as looked once at my companion , save with the tail of my eye .
#Text=At last , upon the other side of Loch Errocht , going over a smooth , rushy place , where the walking was easy , he could bear it no longer , and came close to me .
#Text=David , says he , this is no way for two friends to take a small accident .
#Text=I have to say that I 'm sorry ; and so that 's said .
#Text=And now if you have anything , ye 'd better say it .
#Text=O , says I , I have nothing .
#Text=He seemed disconcerted ; at which I was meanly pleased .
#Text=No , said he , with rather a trembling voice , but when I say I was to blame ?
#Text=Why , of course , ye were to blame , said I , coolly ; and you will bear me out that I have never reproached you .
#Text=Never , says he ; but ye ken very well that ye 've done worse .
#Text=Are we to part ?
#Text=Ye said so once before .
#Text=Are ye to say it again ?
#Text=There 's hills and heather enough between here and the two seas , David ; and I will own I 'm no very keen to stay where I 'm no wanted .
#Text=This pierced me like a sword , and seemed to lay bare my private disloyalty .
#Text=Alan Breck !
#Text=I cried ; and then : Do you think I am one to turn my back on you in your chief need ?
#Text=You durs n't say it to my face .
#Text=My whole conduct 's there to give the lie to it .
#Text=It 's true , I fell asleep upon the muir ; but that was from weariness , and you do wrong to cast it up to me -- -- Which is what I never did , said Alan .
#Text=But aside from that , I continued , what have I done that you should even me to dogs by such a supposition ?
#Text=I never yet failed a friend , and it 's not likely I 'll begin with you .
#Text=There are things between us that I can never forget , even if you can .
#Text=I will only say this to ye , David , said Alan , very quietly , that I have long been owing ye my life , and now I owe ye money .
#Text=Ye should try to make that burden light for me .
#Text=This ought to have touched me , and in a manner it did , but the wrong manner .
#Text=I felt I was behaving badly ; and was now not only angry with Alan , but angry with myself in the bargain ; and it made me the more cruel .
#Text=You asked me to speak , said I. Well , then , I will .
#Text=You own yourself that you have done me a disservice ; I have had to swallow an affront : I have never reproached you , I never named the thing till you did .
#Text=And now you blame me , cried I , because I cannae laugh and sing as if I was glad to be affronted .
#Text=The next thing will be that I 'm to go down upon my knees and thank you for it !
#Text=Ye should think more of others , Alan Breck .

#Text=If ye thought more of others , ye would perhaps speak less about yourself ; and when a friend that likes you very well has passed over an offence without a word , you would be blithe to let it lie , instead of making it a stick to break his back with .
#Text=By your own way of it , it was you that was to blame ; then it shouldnae be you to seek the quarrel .
#Text=Aweel , said Alan , say nae mair .
#Text=And we fell back into our former silence ; and came to our journey 's end , and supped , and lay down to sleep , without another word .
#Text=The gillie put us across Loch Rannoch in the dusk of the next day , and gave us his opinion as to our best route .

#Text=This was to get us up at once into the tops of the mountains : to go round by a circuit , turning the heads of Glen Lyon , Glen Lochay , and Glen Dochart , and come down upon the lowlands by Kippen and the upper waters of the Forth .
#Text=Alan was little pleased with a route which led us through the country of his blood-foes , the Glenorchy Campbells .

#Text=He objected that by turning to the east , we should come almost at once among the Athole Stewarts , a race of his own name and lineage , although following a different chief , and come besides by a far easier and swifter way to the place whither we were bound .

#Text=But the gillie , who was indeed the chief man of Cluny 's scouts , had good reasons to give him on all hands , naming the force of troops in every district , and alleging finally ( as well as I could understand ) that we should nowhere be so little troubled as in a country of the Campbells .
#Text=Alan gave way at last , but with only half a heart .
#Text=It 's one of the dowiest countries in Scotland , said he .
#Text=There 's naething there that I ken , but heath , and crows , and Campbells .
#Text=But I see that ye 're a man of some penetration ; and be it as ye please !

#Text=We set forth accordingly by this itinerary ; and for the best part of three nights travelled on eerie mountains and among the well-heads of wild rivers ; often buried in mist , almost continually blown and rained upon , and not once cheered by any glimpse of sunshine .
#Text=By day , we lay and slept in the drenching heather ; by night , incessantly clambered upon break-neck hills and among rude crags .
#Text=We often wandered ; we were often so involved in fog , that we must lie quiet till it lightened .
#Text=A fire was never to be thought of .
#Text=Our only food was drammach and a portion of cold meat that we had carried from the Cage ; and as for drink , Heaven knows we had no want of water .
#Text=This was a dreadful time , rendered the more dreadful by the gloom of the weather and the country .

#Text=I was never warm ; my teeth chattered in my head ; I was troubled with a very sore throat , such as I had on the isle ; I had a painful stitch in my side , which never left me ; and when I slept in my wet bed , with the rain beating above and the mud oozing below me , it was to live over again in fancy the worst part of my adventures--to see the tower of Shaws lit by lightning , Ransome carried below on the men 's backs , Shuan dying on the round-house floor , or Colin Campbell grasping at the bosom of his coat .

#Text=From such broken slumbers , I would be aroused in the gloaming , to sit up in the same puddle where I had slept , and sup cold drammach ; the rain driving sharp in my face or running down my back in icy trickles ; the mist enfolding us like as in a gloomy chamber--or , perhaps , if the wind blew , falling suddenly apart and showing us the gulf of some dark valley where the streams were crying aloud .
#Text=The sound of an infinite number of rivers came up from all round .
#Text=In this steady rain the springs of the mountain were broken up ; every glen gushed water like a cistern ; every stream was in high spate , and had filled and overflowed its channel .
#Text=During our night tramps , it was solemn to hear the voice of them below in the valleys , now booming like thunder , now with an angry cry .
#Text=I could well understand the story of the Water Kelpie , that demon of the streams , who is fabled to keep wailing and roaring at the ford until the coming of the doomed traveller .

#Text=Alan I saw believed it , or half believed it ; and when the cry of the river rose more than usually sharp , I was little surprised ( though , of course , I would still be shocked ) to see him cross himself in the manner of the Catholics .
#Text=During all these horrid wanderings we had no familiarity , scarcely even that of speech .
#Text=The truth is that I was sickening for my grave , which is my best excuse .
#Text=But besides that I was of an unforgiving disposition from my birth , slow to take offence , slower to forget it , and now incensed both against my companion and myself .
#Text=For the best part of two days he was unweariedly kind ; silent , indeed , but always ready to help , and always hoping ( as I could very well see ) that my displeasure would blow by .
#Text=For the same length of time I stayed in myself , nursing my anger , roughly refusing his services , and passing him over with my eyes as if he had been a bush or a stone .
#Text=The second night , or rather the peep of the third day , found us upon a very open hill , so that we could not follow our usual plan and lie down immediately to eat and sleep .
#Text=Before we had reached a place of shelter , the grey had come pretty clear , for though it still rained , the clouds ran higher ; and Alan , looking in my face , showed some marks of concern .
#Text=Ye had better let me take your pack , said he , for perhaps the ninth time since we had parted from the scout beside Loch Rannoch .
#Text=I do very well , I thank you , said I , as cold as ice .
#Text=Alan flushed darkly .
#Text=I 'll not offer it again , he said .
#Text=I 'm not a patient man , David .
#Text=I never said you were , said I , which was exactly the rude , silly speech of a boy of ten .
#Text=Alan made no answer at the time , but his conduct answered for him .

#Text=Henceforth , it is to be thought , he quite forgave himself for the affair at Cluny 's ; cocked his hat again , walked jauntily , whistled airs , and looked at me upon one side with a provoking smile .
#Text=The third night we were to pass through the western end of the country of Balquhidder .
#Text=It came clear and cold , with a touch in the air like frost , and a northerly wind that blew the clouds away and made the stars bright .
#Text=The streams were full , of course , and still made a great noise among the hills ; but I observed that Alan thought no more upon the Kelpie , and was in high good spirits .
#Text=As for me , the change of weather came too late ; I had lain in the mire so long that ( as the Bible has it ) my very clothes abhorred me .
#Text=I was dead weary , deadly sick and full of pains and shiverings ; the chill of the wind went through me , and the sound of it confused my ears .
#Text=In this poor state I had to bear from my companion something in the nature of a persecution .
#Text=He spoke a good deal , and never without a taunt .
#Text=Whig was the best name he had to give me .
#Text=Here , he would say , here 's a dub for ye to jump , my Whiggie !
#Text=I ken you 're a fine jumper !
#Text=And so on ; all the time with a gibing voice and face .
#Text=I knew it was my own doing , and no one else 's ; but I was too miserable to repent .
#Text=I felt I could drag myself but little farther ; pretty soon , I must lie down and die on these wet mountains like a sheep or a fox , and my bones must whiten there like the bones of a beast .
#Text=My head was light perhaps ; but I began to love the prospect , I began to glory in the thought of such a death , alone in the desert , with the wild eagles besieging my last moments .
#Text=Alan would repent then , I thought ; he would remember , when I was dead , how much he owed me , and the remembrance would be torture .
#Text=So I went like a sick , silly , and bad-hearted schoolboy , feeding my anger against a fellow-man , when I would have been better on my knees , crying on God for mercy .
#Text=And at each of Alan 's taunts , I hugged myself .
#Text=Ah !
#Text=thinks I to myself , I have a better taunt in readiness ; when I lie down and die , you will feel it like a buffet in your face ; ah , what a revenge !
#Text=ah , how you will regret your ingratitude and cruelty !
#Text=All the while , I was growing worse and worse .

#Text=Once I had fallen , my leg simply doubling under me , and this had struck Alan for the moment ; but I was afoot so briskly , and set off again with such a natural manner , that he soon forgot the incident .
#Text=Flushes of heat went over me , and then spasms of shuddering .
#Text=The stitch in my side was hardly bearable .

#Text=At last I began to feel that I could trail myself no farther : and with that , there came on me all at once the wish to have it out with Alan , let my anger blaze , and be done with my life in a more sudden manner .
#Text=He had just called me Whig .
#Text=I stopped .
#Text=Mr. Stewart , said I , in a voice that quivered like a fiddle-string , you are older than I am , and should know your manners .
#Text=Do you think it either very wise or very witty to cast my politics in my teeth ?
#Text=I thought , where folk differed , it was the part of gentlemen to differ civilly ; and if I did not , I may tell you I could find a better taunt than some of yours .
#Text=Alan had stopped opposite to me , his hat cocked , his hands in his breeches pockets , his head a little on one side .
#Text=He listened , smiling evilly , as I could see by the starlight ; and when I had done he began to whistle a Jacobite air .
#Text=It was the air made in mockery of General Cope 's defeat at Preston Pans : Hey , Johnnie Cope , are ye waukin'yet ?
#Text=And are your drums a-beatin'yet ?
#Text=And it came in my mind that Alan , on the day of that battle , had been engaged upon the royal side .
#Text=Why do ye take that air , Mr. Stewart ?
#Text=said I. Is that to remind me you have been beaten on both sides ?
#Text=The air stopped on Alan 's lips .
#Text=David !
#Text=said he .
#Text=But it 's time these manners ceased , I continued ; and I mean you shall henceforth speak civilly of my King and my good friends the Campbells .
#Text=I am a Stewart -- began Alan .
#Text=O !
#Text=says I , I ken ye bear a king 's name .

#Text=But you are to remember , since I have been in the Highlands , I have seen a good many of those by small septs , and broken remnants , and what they call chiefless folk , driven into the wild country about the springs of Forth and Teith by the advance of the Campbells .
#Text=Here were Stewarts and Maclarens , which came to the same thing , for the Maclarens followed Alan 's chief in war , and made but one clan with Appin .
#Text=Here , too , were many of that old , proscribed , nameless , red-handed clan of the Macgregors .
#Text=They had always been ill-considered , and now worse than ever , having credit with no side or party in the whole country of Scotland .

#Text=Their chief , Macgregor of Macgregor , was in exile ; the more immediate leader of that part of them about Balquhidder , James More , Rob Roy 's eldest son , lay waiting his trial in Edinburgh Castle ; they were in ill-blood with Highlander and Lowlander , with the Grahames , the Maclarens , and the Stewarts ; and Alan , who took up the quarrel of any friend , however distant , was extremely wishful to avoid them .
#Text=Chance served us very well ; for it was a household of Maclarens that we found , where Alan was not only welcome for his name 's sake but known by reputation .
#Text=Here then I was got to bed without delay , and a doctor fetched , who found me in a sorry plight .

#Text=But whether because he was a very good doctor , or I a very young , strong man , I lay bedridden for no more than a week , and before a month I was able to take the road again with a good heart .

#Text=All this time Alan would not leave me though I often pressed him , and indeed his foolhardiness in staying was a common subject of outcry with the two or three friends that were let into the secret .
#Text=He hid by day in a hole of the braes under a little wood ; and at night , when the coast was clear , would come into the house to visit me .

#Text=I need not say if I was pleased to see him ; Mrs. Maclaren , our hostess , thought nothing good enough for such a guest ; and as Duncan Dhu ( which was the name of our host ) had a pair of pipes in his house , and was much of a lover of music , this time of my recovery was quite a festival , and we commonly turned night into day .
#Text=The soldiers let us be ; although once a party of two companies and some dragoons went by in the bottom of the valley , where I could see them through the window as I lay in bed .

#Text=What was much more astonishing , no magistrate came near me , and there was no question put of whence I came or whither I was going ; and in that time of excitement , I was as free of all inquiry as though I had lain in a desert .

#Text=Yet my presence was known before I left to all the people in Balquhidder and the adjacent parts ; many coming about the house on visits and these ( after the custom of the country ) spreading the news among their neighbours .
#Text=The bills , too , had now been printed .
#Text=There was one pinned near the foot of my bed , where I could read my own not very flattering portrait and , in larger characters , the amount of the blood money that had been set upon my life .
#Text=Duncan Dhu and the rest that knew that I had come there in Alan 's company , could have entertained no doubt of who I was ; and many others must have had their guess .

#Text=For though I had changed my clothes , I could not change my age or person ; and Lowland boys of eighteen were not so rife in these parts of the world , and above all about that time , that they could fail to put one thing with another , and connect me with the bill .
#Text=So it was , at least .
#Text=Other folk keep a secret among two or three near friends , and somehow it leaks out ; but among these clansmen , it is told to a whole countryside , and they will keep it for a century .
#Text=There was but one thing happened worth narrating ; and that is the visit I had of Robin Oig , one of the sons of the notorious Rob Roy .

#Text=He was sought upon all sides on a charge of carrying a young woman from Balfron and marrying her ( as was alleged ) by force ; yet he stepped about Balquhidder like a gentleman in his own walled policy .
#Text=It was he who had shot James Maclaren at the plough stilts , a quarrel never satisfied ; yet he walked into the house of his blood enemies as a might into a public Commercial traveller .
#Text=Duncan had time to pass me word of who it was ; and we looked at one another in concern .

#Text=You should understand , it was then close upon the time of Alan 's coming ; the two were little likely to agree ; and yet if we sent word or sought to make a signal , it was sure to arouse suspicion in a man under so dark a cloud as the Macgregor .

#Text=He came in with a great show of civility , but like a man among inferiors ; took off his bonnet to Mrs. Maclaren , but clapped it on his head again to speak to Duncan ; and having thus set himself ( as he would have thought ) in a proper light , came to my bedside and bowed .
#Text=I am given to know , sir , says he , that your name is Balfour .
#Text=They call me David Balfour , said I , at your service .

#Text=I would give ye my name in return , sir , he replied , but it 's one somewhat blown upon of late days ; and it 'll perhaps suffice if I tell ye that I am own brother to James More Drummond or Macgregor , of whom ye will scarce have failed to hear .
#Text=bedstead , and fell speedily asleep .
#Text=With the first peep of day I opened my eyes , to find myself in a great chamber , hung with stamped leather , furnished with fine embroidered furniture , and lit by three fair windows .

#Text=Ten years ago , or perhaps twenty , it must have been as pleasant a room to lie down or to awake in as a man could wish ; but damp , dirt , disuse , and the mice and spiders had done their worst since then .

#Text=Many of the window-panes , besides , were broken ; and indeed this was so common a feature in that house , that I believe my uncle must at some time have stood a siege from his indignant neighbours--perhaps with Jennet Clouston at their head .
#Text=Meanwhile the sun was shining outside ; and being very cold in that miserable room , I knocked and shouted till my gaoler came and let me out .

#Text=He carried me to the back of the house , where was a draw-well , and told me to wash my face there , if I wanted ; and when that was done , I made the best of my own way back to the kitchen , where he had lit the fire and was making the porridge .
#Text=The table was laid with two bowls and two horn spoons , but the same single measure of small beer .

#Text=Perhaps my eye rested on this particular with some surprise , and perhaps my uncle observed it ; for he spoke up as if in answer to my thought , asking me if I would like to drink ale--for so he called it .
#Text=I told him such was my habit , but not to put himself about .
#Text=Na , na , said he ; I 'll deny you nothing in reason .
#Text=He fetched another cup from the shelf ; and then , to my great surprise , instead of drawing more beer , he poured an accurate half from one cup to the other .
#Text=There was a kind of nobleness in this that took my breath away ; if my uncle was certainly a miser , he was one of that thorough breed that goes near to make the vice respectable .
#Text=When we had made an end of our meal , my uncle Ebenezer unlocked a drawer , and drew out of it a clay pipe and a lump of tobacco , from which he cut one fill before he locked it up again .
#Text=Then he sat down in the sun at one of the windows and silently smoked .
#Text=From time to time his eyes came coasting round to me , and he shot out one of his questions .
#Text=Once it was , And your mother ?
#Text=and when I had told him that she , too , was dead , Ay , she was a bonnie lassie !
#Text=Then , after another long pause , Whae were these friends o'yours ?

#Text=I told him they were different gentlemen of the name of Campbell ; though , indeed , there was only one , and that the minister , that had ever taken the least note of me ; but I began to think my uncle made too light of my position , and finding myself all alone with him , I did not wish him to suppose me helpless .
#Text=He seemed to turn this over in his mind ; and then , Davie , my man , said he , ye 've come to the right bit when ye came to your uncle Ebenezer .

#Text=I 've a great notion of the family , and I mean to do the right by you ; but while I 'm taking a bit think to mysel'of what 's the best thing to put you to--whether the law , or the meenistry , or maybe the army , whilk is what boys are fondest of--I wouldnae like the Balfours to be humbled before a wheen Hieland Campbells , and I 'll ask you to keep your tongue within your teeth .
#Text=Nae letters ; nae messages ; no kind of word to onybody ; or else--there 's my door .
#Text=Uncle Ebenezer , said I , I 've no manner of reason to suppose you mean anything but well by me .
#Text=For all that , I would have you to know that I have a pride of my own .
#Text=It was by no will of mine that I came seeking you ; and if you show me your door again , I 'll take you at the word .
#Text=He seemed grievously put out .
#Text=Hoots-toots , said he , ca'cannie , man--ca'cannie !
#Text=Bide a day or two .

#Text=I 'm nae warlock , to find a fortune for you in the bottom of a parritch bowl ; but just you give me a day or two , and say naething to naebody , and as sure as sure , I 'll do the right by you .
#Text=Very well , said I , enough said .
#Text=If you want to help me , there 's no doubt but I 'll be glad of it , and none but I 'll be grateful .

#Text=It seemed to me ( too soon , I dare say ) that I was getting the upper hand of my uncle ; and I began next to say that I must have the bed and bedclothes aired and put to sun-dry ; for nothing would make me sleep in such a pickle .
#Text=Is this my house or yours ?
#Text=said he , in his keen voice , and then all of a sudden broke off .
#Text=Na , na , said he , I didnae mean that .
#Text=What 's mine is yours , Davie , my man , and what 's yours is mine .
#Text=Blood 's thicker than water ; and there 's naebody but you and me that ought the name .

#Text=And then on he rambled about the family , and its ancient greatness , and his father that began to enlarge the house , and himself that stopped the building as a sinful waste ; and this put it in my head to give him Jennet Clouston 's message .
#Text=The limmer !
#Text=he cried .
#Text=Twelve hunner and fifteen--that 's every day since I had the limmer rowpit !
#Text=Dod , David , I 'll have her roasted on red peats before I 'm by with it !
#Text=A witch--a proclaimed witch !
#Text=I 'll aff and see the session clerk .
#Text=Sold up .
