#Text=And with that he opened a chest , and got out a very old and well-preserved blue coat and waistcoat , and a good enough beaver hat , that would just cover us if we lay flat .
#Text=Here it was we made our camp , within plain view of Stirling Castle , whence we could hear the drums beat as some part of the garrison paraded .
#Text=Shearers worked all day in a field on one side of the river , and we could hear the stones going on the hooks and the voices and even the words of the men talking .
#Text=It behoved to lie close and keep silent .
#Text=But the sand of the little isle was sun-warm , the green plants gave us shelter for our heads , we had food and drink in plenty ; and to crown all , we were within sight of safety .
#Text=As soon as the shearers quit their work and the dusk began to fall , we waded ashore and struck for the Bridge of Stirling , keeping to the fields and under the field fences .

#Text=The bridge is close under the castle hill , an old , high , narrow bridge with pinnacles along the parapet ; and you may conceive with how much interest I looked upon it , not only as a place famous in history , but as the very doors of salvation to Alan and myself .

#Text=The moon was not yet up when we came there ; a few lights shone along the front of the fortress , and lower down a few lighted windows in the town ; but it was all mighty still , and there seemed to be no guard upon the passage .
#Text=I was for pushing straight across ; but Alan was more wary .
#Text=It looks unco'quiet , said he ; but for all that we 'll lie down here cannily behind a dyke , and make sure .
#Text=So we lay for about a quarter of an hour , whiles whispering , whiles lying still and hearing nothing earthly but the washing of the water on the piers .

#Text=At last there came by an old , hobbling woman with a crutch stick ; who first stopped a little , close to where we lay , and bemoaned herself and the long way she had travelled ; and then set forth again up the steep spring of the bridge .

#Text=The woman was so little , and the night still so dark , that we soon lost sight of her ; only heard the sound of her steps , and her stick , and a cough that she had by fits , draw slowly farther away .
#Text=She 's bound to be across now , I whispered .
#Text=Na , said Alan , her foot still sounds upon the bridge .
#Text=Hollow .
#Text=And just then--Who goes ?
#Text=cried a voice , and we heard the butt of a musket rattle on the stones .
#Text=I must suppose the sentry had been sleeping , so that had we tried , we might have passed unseen ; but he was awake now , and the chance forfeited .
#Text=This 'll never do , said Alan .
#Text=This 'll never , never do for us , David .

#Text=And without another word , he began to crawl away through the fields ; and a little after , being well out of eye-shot , got to his feet again , and struck along a road that led to the eastward .
#Text=I could not conceive what he was doing ; and indeed I was so sharply cut by the disappointment , that I was little likely to be pleased with anything .

#Text=A moment back and I had seen myself knocking at Mr. Rankeillor 's door to claim my inheritance , like a hero in a ballad ; and here was I back again , a wandering , hunted blackguard , on the wrong side of Forth .
#Text=Well ?
#Text=said I. Well , said Alan , what would ye have ?
#Text=They 're none such fools as I took them for .
#Text=We have still the Forth to pass , Davie--weary fall the rains that fed and the hillsides that guided it !
#Text=And why go east ?
#Text=said I. Ou , just upon the chance !
#Text=said he .
#Text=If we cannae pass the river , we 'll have to see what we can do for the firth .
#Text=There are fords upon the river , and none upon the firth , said I. To be sure there are fords , and a bridge forbye , quoth Alan ; and of what service , when they are watched ?
#Text=Well , said I , but a river can be swum .
#Text=By them that have the skill of it , returned he ; but I have yet to hear that either you or me is much of a hand at that exercise ; and for my own part , I swim like a stone .
#Text=I 'm not up to you in talking back , Alan , I said ; but I can see we 're making bad worse .
#Text=If it 's hard to pass a river , it stands to reason it must be worse to pass a sea .
#Text=But there 's such a thing as a boat , says Alan , or I 'm the more deceived .
#Text=Ay , and such a thing as money , says I. But for us that have neither one nor other , they might just as well not have been invented .
#Text=Ye think so ?
#Text=said Alan .
#Text=I do that , said I. David , says he , ye 're a man of small invention and less faith .
#Text=But let me set my wits upon the hone , and if I cannae beg , borrow , nor yet steal a boat , I 'll make one !
#Text=I think I see ye !

#Text=said I. And what 's more than all that : if ye pass a bridge , it can tell no tales ; but if we pass the firth , there 's the boat on the wrong side--somebody must have brought it--the country-side will all be in a bizz- -- Man !
#Text=cried Alan , if I make a boat , I 'll make a body to take it back again !
#Text=So deave me with no more of your nonsense , but walk ( for that 's what you 've got to do)--and let Alan think for ye .

#Text=All night , then , we walked through the north side of the Carse under the high line of the Ochil mountains ; and by Alloa and Clackmannan and Culross , all of which we avoided : and about ten in the morning , mighty hungry and tired , came to the little clachan of Limekilns .
#Text=This is a place that sits near in by the water-side , and looks across the Hope to the town of the Queensferry .
#Text=Smoke went up from both of these , and from other villages and farms upon all hands .
#Text=The fields were being reaped ; two ships lay anchored , and boats were coming and going on the Hope .
#Text=It was altogether a right pleasant sight to me ; and I could not take my fill of gazing at these comfortable , green , cultivated hills and the busy people both of the field and sea .

#Text=For all that , there was Mr. Rankeillor 's house on the south shore , where I had no doubt wealth awaited me ; and here was I upon the north , clad in poor enough attire of an outlandish fashion , with three silver shillings left to me of all my fortune , a price set upon my head , and an outlawed man for my sole company .
#Text=O , Alan !
#Text=said I , to think of it !
#Text=Over there , there 's all that heart could want waiting me ; and the birds go over , and the boats go over--all that please can go , but just me only !
#Text=O , man , but it 's a heart-break !
#Text=In Limekilns we entered a small change-house , which we only knew to be a public by the wand over the door , and bought some bread and cheese from a good-looking lass that was the servant .
#Text=This we carried with us in a bundle , meaning to sit and eat it in a bush of wood on the sea-shore , that we saw some third part of a mile in front .
#Text=As we went , I kept looking across the water and sighing to myself ; and though I took no heed of it , Alan had fallen into a muse .
#Text=At last he stopped in the way .
#Text=Did ye take heed of the lass we bought this of ?
#Text=says he , tapping on the bread and cheese .
#Text=To be sure , said I , and a bonny lass she was .
#Text=Ye thought that ?
#Text=cries he .
#Text=Man , David , that 's good news .
#Text=In the name of all that 's wonderful , why so ?
#Text=says I. What good can that do ?
#Text=Well , said Alan , with one of his droll looks , I was rather in hopes it would maybe get us that boat .
#Text=If it were the other way about , it would be liker it , said I. That 's all that you ken , ye see , said Alan .
#Text=I do n't want the lass to fall in love with ye , I want her to be sorry for ye , David ; to which end there is no manner of need that she should take you for a beauty .
#Text=Let me see ( looking me curiously over ) .

#Text=I wish ye were a wee thing paler ; but apart from that ye 'll do fine for my purpose--ye have a fine , hang-dog , rag-and-tatter , clappermaclaw kind of a look to ye , as if ye had stolen the coat from a potato-bogle .
#Text=Come ; right about , and back to the change-house for that boat of ours .
#Text=I followed him , laughing .
#Text=David Balfour , said he , ye 're a very funny gentleman by your way of it , and this is a very funny employ for ye , no doubt .
#Text=For all that , if ye have any affection for my neck ( to say nothing of your own ) ye will perhaps be kind enough to take this matter responsibly .
#Text=I am going to do a bit of play-acting , the bottom ground of which is just exactly as serious as the gallows for the pair of us .
#Text=So bear it , if ye please , in mind , and conduct yourself according .
#Text=Well , well , said I , have it as you will .

#Text=As we got near the clachan , he made me take his arm and hang upon it like one almost helpless with weariness ; and by the time he pushed open the change-house door , he seemed to be half carrying me .

#Text=The maid appeared surprised ( as well she might be ) at our speedy return ; but Alan had no words to spare for her in explanation , helped me to a chair , called for a tass of brandy with which he fed me in little sips , and then breaking up the bread and cheese helped me to eat it like a nursery-lass ; the whole with that grave , concerned , affectionate countenance , that might have imposed upon a judge .
#Text=It was small wonder if the maid were taken with the picture we presented , of a poor , sick , overwrought lad and his most tender comrade .
#Text=She drew quite near , and stood leaning with her back on the next table .
#Text=What 's like wrong with him ?
#Text=said she at last .
#Text=Alan turned upon her , to my great wonder , with a kind of fury .
#Text=Wrong ?
#Text=cries he .
#Text=He 's walked more hundreds of miles than he has hairs upon his chin , and slept oftener in wet heather than dry sheets .
#Text=Wrong , quo'she !
#Text=Wrong enough , I would think !
#Text=Wrong , indeed !
#Text=and he kept grumbling to himself as he fed me , like a man ill-pleased .
#Text=He 's young for the like of that , said the maid .
#Text=Ower young , said Alan , with his back to her .
#Text=He would be better riding , says she .
#Text=And where could I get a horse to him ?
#Text=cried Alan , turning on her with the same appearance of fury .
#Text=Would ye have me steal ?
#Text=I thought this roughness would have sent her off in dudgeon , as indeed it closed her mouth for the time .
#Text=But my companion knew very well what he was doing ; and for as simple as he was in some things of life , had a great fund of roguishness in such affairs as these .
#Text=Ye neednae tell me , she said at last--ye 're gentry .
#Text=Well , said Alan , softened a little ( I believe against his will ) by this artless comment , and suppose we were ?
#Text=Did ever you hear that gentrice put money in folk 's pockets ?
#Text=She sighed at this , as if she were herself some disinherited great lady .
#Text=No , says she , that 's true indeed .

#Text=I was all this while chafing at the part I played , and sitting tongue-tied between shame and merriment ; but somehow at this I could hold in no longer , and bade Alan let me be , for I was better already .
#Text=My voice stuck in my throat , for I ever hated to take part in lies ; but my very embarrassment helped on the plot , for the lass no doubt set down my husky voice to sickness and fatigue .
#Text=Has he nae friends ?
#Text=said she , in a tearful voice .
#Text=That has he so !
#Text=cried Alan , if we could but win to them !
#Text=-- friends and rich friends , beds to lie in , food to eat , doctors to see to him--and here he must tramp in the dubs and sleep in the heather like a beggarman .
#Text=And why that ?
#Text=says the lass .
#Text=My dear , said Alan , I cannae very safely say ; but I 'll tell ye what I 'll do instead , says he , I 'll whistle ye a bit tune .
#Text=And with that he leaned pretty far over the table , and in a mere breath of a whistle , but with a wonderful pretty sentiment , gave her a few bars of Charlie is my darling .
#Text=Wheesht , says she , and looked over her shoulder to the door .
#Text=That 's it , said Alan .
#Text=And him so young !
#Text=cries the lass .
#Text=He 's old enough to -- -- and Alan struck his forefinger on the back part of his neck , meaning that I was old enough to lose my head .
#Text=It would be a black shame , she cried , flushing high .
#Text=It 's what will be , though , said Alan , unless we manage the better .
#Text=At this the lass turned and ran out of that part of the house , leaving us alone together .
#Text=Alan in high good humour at the furthering of his schemes , and I in bitter dudgeon at being called a Jacobite and treated like a child .
#Text=Alan , I cried , I can stand no more of this .
#Text=Ye 'll have to sit it then , Davie , said he .
#Text=For if ye upset the pot now , ye may scrape your own life out of the fire , but Alan Breck is a dead man .

#Text=This was so true that I could only groan ; and even my groan served Alan 's purpose , for it was overheard by the lass as she came flying in again with a dish of white puddings and a bottle of strong ale .
#Text=Poor lamb !
#Text=says she , and had no sooner set the meat before us , than she touched me on the shoulder with a little friendly touch , as much as to bid me cheer up .
#Text=Then she told us to fall to , and there would be no more to pay ; for the inn was her own , or at least her father 's , and he was gone for the day to Pittencrieff .

#Text=We waited for no second bidding , for bread and cheese is but cold comfort and the puddings smelt excellently well ; and while we sat and ate , she took up that same place by the next table , looking on , and thinking , and frowning to herself , and drawing the string of her apron through her hand .
#Text=I 'm thinking ye have rather a long tongue , she said at last to Alan .
#Text=Ay said Alan ; but ye see I ken the folk I speak to .
#Text=I would never betray ye , said she , if ye mean that .
#Text=No , said he , ye 're not that kind .
#Text=But I 'll tell ye what ye would do , ye would help .
#Text=I couldnae , said she , shaking her head .
#Text=Na , I couldnae .
#Text=No , said he , but if ye could ?
#Text=She answered him nothing .
#Text=Look here , my lass , said Alan , there are boats in the Kingdom of Fife , for I saw two ( no less ) upon the beach , as I came in by your town 's end .

#Text=Now if we could have the use of a boat to pass under cloud of night into Lothian , and some secret , decent kind of a man to bring that boat back again and keep his counsel , there would be two souls saved--mine to all likelihood--his to a dead surety .

#Text=If we lack that boat , we have but three shillings left in this wide world ; and where to go , and how to do , and what other place there is for us except the chains of a gibbet--I give you my naked word , I kenna !
#Text=Shall we go wanting , lassie ?
#Text=Are ye to lie in your warm bed and think upon us , when the wind gowls in the chimney and the rain tirls on the roof ?
#Text=Are ye to eat your meat by the cheeks of a red fire , and think upon this poor sick lad of mine , biting his finger ends on a blae muir for cauld and hunger ?

#Text=Sick or sound , he must aye be moving ; with the death grapple at his throat he must aye be trailing in the rain on the lang roads ; and when he gants his last on a rickle of cauld stanes , there will be nae friends near him but only me and God .

#Text=At this appeal , I could see the lass was in great trouble of mind , being tempted to help us , and yet in some fear she might be helping malefactors ; and so now I determined to step in myself and to allay her scruples with a portion of the truth .
#Text=Did ever you hear , said I , of Mr. Rankeillor of the Ferry ?
#Text=Rankeillor the writer ?
#Text=said she .
#Text=I daur say that !

#Text=Well , said I , it 's to his door that I am bound , so you may judge by that if I am an ill-doer ; and I will tell you more , that though I am indeed , by a dreadful error , in some peril of my life , King George has no truer friend in all Scotland than myself .
#Text=Her face cleared up mightily at this , although Alan 's darkened .
#Text=That 's more than I would ask , said she .
#Text=Mr. Rankeillor is a kennt man .
#Text=And she bade us finish our meat , get clear of the clachan as soon as might be , and lie close in the bit wood on the sea-beach .
#Text=And ye can trust me , says she , I 'll find some means to put you over .
#Text=At this we waited for no more , but shook hands with her upon the bargain , made short work of the puddings , and set forth again from Limekilns as far as to the wood .
#Text=It was a small piece of perhaps a score of elders and hawthorns and a few young ashes , not thick enough to veil us from passersby upon the road or beach .
#Text=Here we must lie , however , making the best of the brave warm weather and the good hopes we now had of a deliverance , and planing more particularly what remained for us to do .

#Text=We had but one trouble all day ; when a strolling piper came and sat in the same wood with us ; a red-nosed , bleareyed , drunken dog , with a great bottle of whisky in his pocket , and a long story of wrongs that had been done him by all sorts of persons , from the Lord President of the Court of Session , who had denied him justice , down to the Bailies of Inverkeithing who had given him more of it than he desired .
#Text=It was impossible but he should conceive some suspicion of two men lying all day concealed in a thicket and having no business to allege .

#Text=As long as he stayed there he kept us in hot water with prying questions ; and after he was gone , as he was a man not very likely to hold his tongue , we were in the greater impatience to be gone ourselves .

#Text=The day came to an end with the same brightness ; the night fell quiet and clear ; lights came out in houses and hamlets and then , one after another , began to be put out ; but it was past eleven , and we were long since strangely tortured with anxieties , before we heard the grinding of oars upon the rowing-pins .
#Text=At that , we looked out and saw the lass herself coming rowing to us in a boat .

#Text=She had trusted no one with our affairs , not even her sweetheart , if she had one ; but as soon as her father was asleep , had left the house by a window , stolen a neighbour 's boat , and come to our assistance single-handed .

#Text=I was abashed how to find expression for my thanks ; but she was no less abashed at the thought of hearing them ; begged us to lose no time and to hold our peace , saying ( very properly ) that the heart of our matter was in haste and silence ; and so , what with one thing and another , she had set us on the Lothian shore not far from Carriden , had shaken hands with us , and was out again at sea and rowing for Limekilns , before there was one word said either of her service or our gratitude .
#Text=Even after she was gone , we had nothing to say , as indeed nothing was enough for such a kindness .
#Text=Only Alan stood a great while upon the shore shaking his head .
#Text=It is a very fine lass , he said at last .
#Text=David , it is a very fine lass .
#Text=And a matter of an hour later , as we were lying in a den on the sea-shore and I had been already dozing , he broke out again in commendations of her character .

#Text=For my part , I could say nothing , she was so simple a creature that my heart smote me both with remorse and fear : remorse because we had traded upon her ignorance ; and fear lest we should have anyway involved her in the dangers of our situation .

#Text=CHAPTER XXVII I COME TO MR. RANKEILLOR The next day it was agreed that Alan should fend for himself till sunset ; but as soon as it began to grow dark , he should lie in the fields by the roadside near to Newhalls , and stir for naught until he heard me whistling .

#Text=At first I proposed I should give him for a signal the Bonnie House of Airlie , which was a favourite of mine ; but he objected that as the piece was very commonly known , any ploughman might whistle it by accident ; and taught me instead a little fragment of a Highland air , which has run in my head from that day to this , and will likely run in my head when I lie dying .

#Text=Every time it comes to me , it takes me off to that last day of my uncertainty , with Alan sitting up in the bottom of the den , whistling and beating the measure with a finger , and the grey of the dawn coming on his face .
#Text=I was in the long street of Queensferry before the sun was up .

#Text=It was a fairly built burgh , the houses of good stone , many slated ; the town-hall not so fine , I thought , as that of Peebles , nor yet the street so noble ; but take it altogether , it put me to shame for my foul tatters .
#Text=As the morning went on , and the fires began to be kindled , and the windows to open , and the people to appear out of the houses , my concern and despondency grew ever the blacker .
#Text=I saw now that I had no grounds to stand upon ; and no clear proof of my rights , nor so much as of my own identity .
#Text=If it was all a bubble , I was indeed sorely cheated and left in a sore pass .

#Text=Even if things were as I conceived , it would in all likelihood take time to establish my contentions ; and what time had I to spare with less than three shillings in my pocket , and a condemned , hunted man upon my hands to ship out of the country ?
#Text=Truly , if my hope broke with me , it might come to the gallows yet for both of us .

#Text=And as I continued to walk up and down , and saw people looking askance at me upon the street or out of windows , and nudging or speaking one to another with smiles , I began to take a fresh apprehension : that it might be no easy matter even to come to speech of the lawyer , far less to convince him of my story .

#Text=For the life of me I could not muster up the courage to address any of these reputable burghers ; I thought shame even to speak with them in such a pickle of rags and dirt ; and if I had asked for the house of such a man as Mr. Rankeillor , I suppose they would have burst out laughing in my face .

#Text=So I went up and down , and through the street , and down to the harbour-side , like a dog that has lost its master , with a strange gnawing in my inwards , and every now and then a movement of despair .

#Text=It grew to be high day at last , perhaps nine in the forenoon ; and I was worn with these wanderings , and chanced to have stopped in front of a very good house on the landward side , a house with beautiful , clear glass windows , flowering knots upon the sills , the walls and a chase-dog sitting yawning on the step like one that was at home .
#Text=Well , I was even envying this dumb brute , when the door fell open and there issued forth a shrewd , ruddy , kindly , consequential man in a well-powdered wig and spectacles .

#Text=I was in such a plight that no one set eyes on me once , but he looked at me again ; and this gentleman , as it proved , was so much struck with my poor appearance that he came straight up to me and asked me what I did .
#Text=Newly rough-cast .
#Text=I told him I was come to the Queensferry on business , and taking heart of grace , asked him to direct me to the house of Mr. Rankeillor .
#Text=Why , said he , that is his house that I have just come out of ; and for a rather singular chance , I am that very man .
#Text=Then , sir , said I , I have to beg the favour of an interview .
#Text=I do not know your name , said he , nor yet your face .
#Text=My name is David Balfour , said I. David Balfour ?
#Text=he repeated , in rather a high tone , like one surprised .
#Text=And where have you come from , Mr. David Balfour ?
#Text=he asked , looking me pretty drily in the face .
#Text=I have come from a great many strange places , sir , said I ; but I think it would be as well to tell you where and how in a more private manner .
#Text=He seemed to muse awhile , holding his lip in his hand , and looking now at me and now upon the causeway of the street .
#Text=Yes , says he , that will be the best , no doubt .

#Text=And he led me back with him into his house , cried out to some one whom I could not see that he would be engaged all morning , and brought me into a little dusty chamber full of books and documents .
#Text=Here he sate down , and bade me be seated ; though I thought he looked a little ruefully from his clean chair to my muddy rags .
#Text=And now , says he , if you have any business , pray be brief and come swiftly to the point .
#Text=Nec gemino bellum Trojanum orditur ab ovo--do you understand that ?
#Text=says he , with a keen look .
#Text=I will even do as Horace says , sir , I answered , smiling , and carry you in medias res .
#Text=He nodded as if he was well pleased , and indeed his scrap of Latin had been set to test me .
#Text=For all that , and though I was somewhat encouraged , the blood came in my face when I added : I have reason to believe myself some rights on the estate of Shaws .
#Text=He got a paper book out of a drawer and set it before him open .
#Text=Well ?
#Text=said he .
#Text=But I had shot my bolt and sat speechless .
#Text=Come , come , Mr. Balfour , said he , you must continue .
#Text=Where were you born ?
#Text=In Essendean , sir , said I , the year 1733 , the 12th of March .
#Text=He seemed to follow this statement in his paper book ; but what that meant I knew not .
#Text=Your father and mother ?
#Text=said he .
#Text=My father was Alexander Balfour , schoolmaster of that place , said I , and my mother Grace Pitarrow ; I think her people were from Angus .
#Text=Have you any papers proving your identity ?
#Text=asked Mr. Rankeillor .
#Text=No , sir , said I , but they are in the hands of Mr. Campbell , the minister , and could be readily produced .
#Text=Mr. Campbell , too , would give me his word ; and for that matter , I do not think my uncle would deny me .
#Text=Meaning Mr. Ebenezer Balfour ?
#Text=says he .
#Text=The same , said I. Whom you have seen ?
#Text=he asked .
#Text=By whom I was received into his own house , I answered .
#Text=Did you ever meet a man of the name of Hoseason ?
#Text=asked Mr. Rankeillor .

#Text=I did so , sir , for my sins , said I ; for it was by his means and the procurement of my uncle , that I was kidnapped within sight of this town , carried to sea , suffered shipwreck and a hundred other hardships , and stand before you to-day in this poor accoutrement .
#Text=You say you were shipwrecked , said Rankeillor ; where was that ?
#Text=Off the south end of the Isle of Mull , said I. The name of the isle on which I was cast up is the Island Earraid .
#Text=Ah !
#Text=says he , smiling , you are deeper than me in the geography .
#Text=But so far , I may tell you , this agrees pretty exactly with other informations that I hold .
#Text=But you say you were kidnapped ; in what sense ?

#Text=In the plain meaning of the word , sir , said I. I was on my way to your house , when I was trepanned on board the brig , cruelly struck down , thrown below , and knew no more of anything till we were far at sea .
#Text=I was destined for the plantations ; a fate that , in God 's providence , I have escaped .
#Text=The brig was lost on June the 27th , says he , looking in his book , and we are now at August the 24th .
#Text=Here is a considerable hiatus , Mr. Balfour , of near upon two months .
#Text=It has already caused a vast amount of trouble to your friends ; and I own I shall not be very well contented until it is set right .
#Text=Indeed , sir , said I , these months are very easily filled up ; but yet before I told my story , I would be glad to know that I was talking to a friend .
#Text=This is to argue in a circle , said the lawyer .
#Text=I cannot be convinced till I have heard you .
#Text=I cannot be your friend till I am properly informed .
#Text=If you were more trustful , it would better befit your time of life .
#Text=And you know , Mr. Balfour , we have a proverb in the country that evil-doers are aye evil-dreaders .
#Text=You are not to forget , sir , said I , that I have already suffered by my trustfulness ; and was shipped off to be a slave by the very man that ( if I rightly understand ) is your employer ?
#Text=All this while I had been gaining ground with Mr. Rankeillor , and in proportion as I gained ground , gaining confidence .
#Text=But at this sally , which I made with something of a smile myself , he fairly laughed aloud .
#Text=No , no , said he , it is not so bad as that .
#Text=Fui , non sum .

#Text=I was indeed your uncle 's man of business ; but while you ( imberbis juvenis custode remoto ) were gallivanting in the west , a good deal of water has run under the bridges ; and if your ears did not sing , it was not for lack of being talked about .
#Text=On the very day of your sea disaster , Mr. Campbell stalked into my office , demanding you from all the winds .
#Text=I had never heard of your existence ; but I had known your father ; and from matters in my competence ( to be touched upon hereafter ) I was disposed to fear the worst .

#Text=Mr. Ebenezer admitted having seen you ; declared ( what seemed improbable ) that he had given you considerable sums ; and that you had started for the continent of Europe , intending to fulfil your education , which was probable and praiseworthy .
#Text=Interrogated how you had come to send no word to Mr. Campbell , he deponed that you had expressed a great desire to break with your past life .
#Text=Further interrogated where you now were , protested ignorance , but believed you were in Leyden .
#Text=That is a close sum of his replies .

#Text=I am not exactly sure that any one believed him , continued Mr. Rankeillor with a smile ; and in particular he so much disrelished me expressions of mine that ( in a word ) he showed me to the door .
#Text=We were then at a full stand ; for whatever shrewd suspicions we might entertain , we had no shadow of probation .

#Text=In the very article , comes Captain Hoseason with the story of your drowning ; whereupon all fell through ; with no consequences but concern to Mr. Campbell , injury to my pocket , and another blot upon your uncle 's character , which could very ill afford it .
#Text=And now , Mr. Balfour , said he , you understand the whole process of these matters , and can judge for yourself to what extent I may be trusted .

#Text=Indeed he was more pedantic than I can represent him , and placed more scraps of Latin in his speech ; but it was all uttered with a fine geniality of eye and manner which went far to conquer my distrust .
#Text=Moreover , I could see he now treated me as if I was myself beyond a doubt ; so that first point of my identity seemed fully granted .
#Text=Sir , said I , if I tell you my story , I must commit a friend 's life to your discretion .
#Text=Pass me your word it shall be sacred ; and for what touches myself , I will ask no better guarantee than just your face .
#Text=He passed me his word very seriously .
#Text=But , said he , these are rather alarming prolocutions ; and if there are in your story any little jostles to the law , I would beg you to bear in mind that I am a lawyer , and pass lightly .
#Text=Thereupon I told him my story from the first , he listening with his spectacles thrust up and his eyes closed , so that I sometimes feared he was asleep .
#Text=But no such matter !
#Text=he heard every word ( as I found afterward ) with such quickness of hearing and precision of memory as often surprised me .
#Text=Even strange outlandish Gaelic names , heard for that time only , he remembered and would remind me of , years after .
#Text=Yet when I called Alan Breck in full , we had an odd scene .

#Text=The name of Alan had of course rung through Scotland , with the news of the Appin murder and the offer of the reward ; and it had no sooner escaped me than the lawyer moved in his seat and opened his eyes .
#Text=I would name no unnecessary names , Mr. Balfour , said he ; above all of Highlanders , many of whom are obnoxious to the law .
#Text=Well , it might have been better not , said I , but since I have let it slip , I may as well continue .
#Text=Not at all , said Mr. Rankeillor .
#Text=I am somewhat dull of hearing , as you may have remarked ; and I am far from sure I caught the name exactly .
#Text=We will call your friend , if you please , Mr. Thomson--that there may be no reflections .
#Text=And in future , I would take some such way with any Highlander that you may have to mention--dead or alive .
#Text=By this , I saw he must have heard the name all too clearly , and had already guessed I might be coming to the murder .
#Text=If he chose to play this part of ignorance , it was no matter of mine ; so I smiled , said it was no very Highland-sounding name , and consented .
#Text=Through all the rest of my story Alan was Mr. Thomson ; which amused me the more , as it was a piece of policy after his own heart .

#Text=James Stewart , in like manner , was mentioned under the style of Mr. Thomson 's kinsman ; Colin Campbell passed as a Mr. Glen ; and to Cluny , when I came to that part of my tale , I gave the name of Mr. Jameson , a Highland chief .

#Text=It was truly the most open farce , and I wondered that the lawyer should care to keep it up ; but , after all , it was quite in the taste of that age , when there were two parties in the state , and quiet persons , with no very high opinions of their own , sought out every cranny to avoid offence to either .
#Text=Well , well , said the lawyer , when I had quite done , this is a great epic , a great Odyssey of yours .
#Text=You must tell it , sir , in a sound Latinity when your scholarship is riper ; or in English if you please , though for my part I prefer the stronger tongue .
#Text=You have rolled much ; quae regio in terris--what parish in Scotland ( to make a homely translation ) has not been filled with your wanderings ?
#Text=You have shown , besides , a singular aptitude for getting into false positions ; and , yes , upon the whole , for behaving well in them .
#Text=This Mr. Thomson seems to me a gentleman of some choice qualities , though perhaps a trifle bloody-minded .
#Text=It would please me none the worse , if ( with all his merits ) he were soused in the North Sea , for the man , Mr. David , is a sore embarrassment .
#Text=But you are doubtless quite right to adhere to him ; indubitably , he adhered to you .
#Text=It comes--we may say--he was your true companion ; nor less paribus curis vestigia figit , for I dare say you would both take an orra thought upon the gallows .
#Text=Well , well , these days are fortunately by ; and I think ( speaking humanly ) that you are near the end of your troubles .
#Text=As he thus moralised on my adventures , he looked upon me with so much humour and benignity that I could scarce contain my satisfaction .

#Text=I had been so long wandering with lawless people , and making my bed upon the hills and under the bare sky , that to sit once more in a clean , covered house , and to talk amicably with a gentleman in broadcloth , seemed mighty elevations .
#Text=Even as I thought so , my eye fell on my unseemly tatters , and I was once more plunged in confusion .
#Text=But the lawyer saw and understood me .
#Text=He rose , called over the stair to lay another plate , for Mr. Balfour would stay to dinner , and led me into a bedroom in the upper part of the house .
#Text=Here he set before me water and soap , and a comb ; and laid out some clothes that belonged to his son ; and here , with another apposite tag , he left me to my toilet .

#Text=CHAPTER XXVIII I GO IN QUEST OF MY INHERITANCE I made what change I could in my appearance ; and blithe was I to look in the glass and find the beggarman a thing of the past , and David Balfour come to life again .
#Text=And yet I was ashamed of the change too , and , above all , of the borrowed clothes .
#Text=When I had done , Mr. Rankeillor caught me on the stair , made me his compliments , and had me again into the cabinet .
#Text=Sit ye down , Mr. David , said he , and now that you are looking a little more like yourself , let me see if I can find you any news .
#Text=You will be wondering , no doubt , about your father and your uncle ?
#Text=To be sure it is a singular tale ; and the explanation is one that I blush to have to offer you .
#Text=For , says he , really with embarrassment , the matter hinges on a love affair .
#Text=Truly , said I , I cannot very well join that notion with my uncle .
#Text=But your uncle , Mr. David , was not always old , replied the lawyer , and what may perhaps surprise you more , not always ugly .
#Text=He had a fine , gallant air ; people stood in their doors to look after him , as he went by upon a mettle horse .

#Text=I have seen it with these eyes , and I ingenuously confess , not altogether without envy ; for I was a plain lad myself and a plain man 's son ; and in those days it was a case of Odi te , qui bellus es , Sabelle .
#Text=It sounds like a dream , said I. Ay , ay , said the lawyer , that is how it is with youth and age .
#Text=Nor was that all , but he had a spirit of his own that seemed to promise great things in the future .
#Text=In 1715 , what must he do but run away to join the rebels ?
#Text=It was your father that pursued him , found him in a ditch , and brought him back multum gementem ; to the mirth of the whole country .
#Text=However , majora canamus--the two lads fell in love , and that with the same lady .

#Text=Mr. Ebenezer , who was the admired and the beloved , and the spoiled one , made , no doubt , mighty certain of the victory ; and when he found he had deceived himself , screamed like a peacock .

#Text=The whole country heard of it ; now he lay sick at home , with his silly family standing round the bed in tears ; now he rode from public-house to public-house , and shouted his sorrows into the lug of Tom , Dick , and Harry .
#Text=Your father , Mr. David , was a kind gentleman ; but he was weak , dolefully weak ; took all this folly with a long countenance ; and one day--by your leave !
#Text=-- resigned the lady .
#Text=She was no such fool , however ; it 's from her you must inherit your excellent good sense ; and she refused to be bandied from one to another .
#Text=Both got upon their knees to her ; and the upshot of the matter for that while was that she showed both of them the door .
#Text=That was in August ; dear me !
#Text=the same year I came from college .
#Text=The scene must have been highly farcical .
#Text=I thought myself it was a silly business , but I could not forget my father had a hand in it .
#Text=Surely , sir , it had some note of tragedy , said I. Why , no , sir , not at all , returned the lawyer .

#Text=For tragedy implies some ponderable matter in dispute , some dignus vindice nodus ; and this piece of work was all about the petulance of a young ass that had been spoiled , and wanted nothing so much as to be tied up and soundly belted .

#Text=However , that was not your father 's view ; and the end of it was , that from concession to concession on your father 's part , and from one height to another of squalling , sentimental selfishness upon your uncle 's , they came at last to drive a sort of bargain , from whose ill results you have recently been smarting .
#Text=The one man took the lady , the other the estate .

#Text=Now , Mr. David , they talk a great deal of charity and generosity ; but in this disputable state of life , I often think the happiest consequences seem to flow when a gentleman consults his lawyer , and takes all the law allows him .
#Text=Anyhow , this piece of Quixotry on your father 's part , as it was unjust in itself , has brought forth a monstrous family of injustices .
#Text=Your father and mother lived and died poor folk ; you were poorly reared ; and in the meanwhile , what a time it has been for the tenants on the estate of Shaws !
#Text=And I might add ( if it was a matter I cared much about ) what a time for Mr. Ebenezer !
#Text=And yet that is certainly the strangest part of all , said I , that a man 's nature should thus change .
#Text=True , said Mr. Rankeillor .
#Text=And yet I imagine it was natural enough .
#Text=He could not think that he had played a handsome part .

#Text=Those who knew the story gave him the cold shoulder ; those who knew it not , seeing one brother disappear , and the other succeed in the estate , raised a cry of murder ; so that upon all sides he found himself evited .
#Text=Money was all he got by his bargain ; well , he came to think the more of money .
#Text=He was selfish when he was young , he is selfish now that he is old ; and the latter end of all these pretty manners and fine feelings you have seen for yourself .
#Text=Well , sir , said I , and in all this , what is my position ?
#Text=The estate is yours beyond a doubt , replied the lawyer .
#Text=It matters nothing what your father signed , you are the heir of entail .
#Text=But your uncle is a man to fight the indefensible ; and it would be likely your identity that he would call in question .

#Text=A lawsuit is always expensive , and a family lawsuit always scandalous ; besides which , if any of your doings with your friend Mr. Thomson were to come out , we might find that we had burned our fingers .
#Text=The kidnapping , to be sure , would be a court card upon our side , if we could only prove it .

#Text=But it may be difficult to prove ; and my advice ( upon the whole ) is to make a very easy bargain with your uncle , perhaps even leaving him at Shaws where he has taken root for a quarter of a century , and contenting yourself in the meanwhile with a fair provision .
#Text=I told him I was very willing to be easy , and that to carry family concerns before the public was a step from which I was naturally much averse .
#Text=In the meantime ( thinking to myself ) I began to see the outlines of that scheme on which we afterwards acted .
#Text=The great affair , I asked , is to bring home to him the kidnapping ?
#Text=Surely , said Mr. Rankeillor , and if possible , out of court .

#Text=For mark you here , Mr. David : we could no doubt find some men of the Covenant who would swear to your reclusion ; but once they were in the box , we could no longer check their testimony , and some word of your friend Mr. Thomson must certainly crop out .
#Text=Which ( from what you have let fall ) I cannot think to be desirable .
#Text=Well , sir , said I , here is my way of it .
#Text=And I opened my plot to him .
#Text=But this would seem to involve my meeting the man Thomson ?
#Text=says he , when I had done .
#Text=I think so , indeed , sir , said I. Dear doctor !
#Text=cries he , rubbing his brow .
#Text=Dear doctor !
#Text=No , Mr. David , I am afraid your scheme is inadmissible .
#Text=I say nothing against your friend , Mr. Thomson : I know nothing against him ; and if I did--mark this , Mr. David !
#Text=-- it would be my duty to lay hands on him .
#Text=Now I put it to you : is it wise to meet ?
#Text=He may have matters to his charge .
#Text=He may not have told you all .
#Text=His name may not be even Thomson !
#Text=cries the lawyer , twinkling ; for some of these fellows will pick up names by the roadside as another would gather haws .

#Text=You must be the judge , sir , said I. But it was clear my plan had taken hold upon his fancy , for he kept musing to himself till we were called to dinner and the company of Mrs. Rankeillor ; and that lady had scarce left us again to ourselves and a bottle of wine , ere he was back harping on my proposal .

#Text=When and where was I to meet my friend Mr. Thomson ; was I sure of Mr. T. 's discretion ; supposing we could catch the old fox tripping , would I consent to such and such a term of an agreement--these and the like questions he kept asking at long intervals , while he thoughtfully rolled his wine upon his tongue .
#Text=When I had answered all of them , seemingly to his contentment , he fell into a still deeper muse , even the claret being now forgotten .
#Text=Then he got a sheet of paper and a pencil , and set to work writing and weighing every word ; and at last touched a bell and had his clerk into the chamber .

#Text=Torrance , said he , I must have this written out fair against to-night ; and when it is done , you will be so kind as put on your hat and be ready to come along with this gentleman and me , for you will probably be wanted as a witness .
#Text=What , sir , cried I , as soon as the clerk was gone , are you to venture it ?
#Text=Why , so it would appear , says he , filling his glass .
#Text=But let us speak no more of business .
#Text=The very sight of Torrance brings in my head a little droll matter of some years ago , when I had made a tryst with the poor oaf at the cross of Edinburgh .

#Text=Each had gone his proper errand ; and when it came four o'clock , Torrance had been taking a glass and did not know his master , and I , who had forgot my spectacles , was so blind without them , that I give you my word I did not know my own clerk .
#Text=And thereupon he laughed heartily .

#Text=I said it was an odd chance , and smiled out of politeness ; but what held me all the afternoon in wonder , he kept returning and dwelling on this story , and telling it again with fresh details and laughter ; so that I began at last to be quite put out of countenance and feel ashamed for my friend 's folly .

#Text=Towards the time I had appointed with Alan , we set out from the house , Mr. Rankeillor and I arm in arm , and Torrance following behind with the deed in his pocket and a covered basket in his hand .

#Text=All through the town , the lawyer was bowing right and left , and continually being button-holed by gentlemen on matters of burgh or private business ; and I could see he was one greatly looked up to in the county .
#Text=At last we were clear of the houses , and began to go along the side of the haven and towards the Hawes Inn and the Ferry pier , the scene of my misfortune .

#Text=I could not look upon the place without emotion , recalling how many that had been there with me that day were now no more : Ransome taken , I could hope , from the evil to come ; Shuan passed where I dared not follow him ; and the poor souls that had gone down with the brig in her last plunge .
#Text=All these , and the brig herself , I had outlived ; and come through these hardships and fearful perils without scath .
#Text=My only thought should have been of gratitude ; and yet I could not behold the place without sorrow for others and a chill of recollected fear .
#Text=I was so thinking when , upon a sudden , Mr. Rankeillor cried out , clapped his hand to his pockets , and began to laugh .
#Text=Why , he cries , if this be not a farcical adventure !
#Text=After all that I said , I have forgot my glasses !

#Text=At that , of course , I understood the purpose of his anecdote , and knew that if he had left his spectacles at home , it had been done on purpose , so that he might have the benefit of Alan 's help without the awkwardness of recognising him .

#Text=And indeed it was well thought upon ; for now ( suppose things to go the very worst ) how could Rankeillor swear to my friend 's identity , or how be made to bear damaging evidence against myself ?

#Text=For all that , he had been a long while of finding out his want , and had spoken to and recognised a good few persons as we came through the town ; and I had little doubt myself that he saw reasonably well .

#Text=As soon as we were past the Hawes ( where I recognised the landlord smoking his pipe in the door , and was amazed to see him look no older ) Mr. Rankeillor changed the order of march , walking behind with Torrance and sending me forward in the manner of a scout .
#Text=I went up the hill , whistling from time to time my Gaelic air ; and at length I had the pleasure to hear it answered and to see Alan rise from behind a bush .
#Text=He was somewhat dashed in spirits , having passed a long day alone skulking in the county , and made but a poor meal in an alehouse near Dundas .

#Text=But at the mere sight of my clothes , he began to brighten up ; and as soon as I had told him in what a forward state our matters were and the part I looked to him to play in what remained , he sprang into a new man .
#Text=And that is a very good notion of yours , says he ; and I dare to say that you could lay your hands upon no better man to put it through than Alan Breck .
#Text=It is not a thing ( mark ye ) that any one could do , but takes a gentleman of penetration .
#Text=But it sticks in my head your lawyer-man will be somewhat wearying to see me , says Alan .
#Text=Accordingly I cried and waved on Mr. Rankeillor , who came up alone and was presented to my friend , Mr. Thomson .
#Text=Mr. Thomson , I am pleased to meet you , said he .

#Text=But I have forgotten my glasses ; and our friend , Mr. David here ( clapping me on the shoulder ) , will tell you that I am little better than blind , and that you must not be surprised if I pass you by to-morrow .
#Text=This he said , thinking that Alan would be pleased ; but the Highlandman 's vanity was ready to startle at a less matter than that .

#Text=Why , sir , says he , stiffly , I would say it mattered the less as we are met here for a particular end , to see justice done to Mr. Balfour ; and by what I can see , not very likely to have much else in common .
#Text=But I accept your apology , which was a very proper one to make .
#Text=And that is more than I could look for , Mr. Thomson , said Rankeillor , heartily .

#Text=And now as you and I are the chief actors in this enterprise , I think we should come into a nice agreement ; to which end , I propose that you should lend me your arm , for ( what with the dusk and the want of my glasses ) I am not very clear as to the path ; and as for you , Mr. David , you will find Torrance a pleasant kind of body to speak with .
#Text=Only let me remind you , it 's quite needless he should hear more of your adventures or those of--ahem--Mr .
#Text=Thomson .
#Text=Accordingly these two went on ahead in very close talk , and Torrance and I brought up the rear .
#Text=Night was quite come when we came in view of the house of Shaws .

#Text=Ten had been gone some time ; it was dark and mild , with a pleasant , rustling wind in the south-west that covered the sound of our approach ; and as we drew near we saw no glimmer of light in any portion of the building .
#Text=It seemed my uncle was already in bed , which was indeed the best thing for our arrangements .

#Text=We made our last whispered consultations some fifty yards away ; and then the lawyer and Torrance and I crept quietly up and crouched down beside the corner of the house ; and as soon as we were in our places , Alan strode to the door without concealment and began to knock .
#Text=CHAPTER XXIX I COME INTO MY KINGDOM For some time Alan volleyed upon the door , and his knocking only roused the echoes of the house and neighbourhood .
#Text=At last , however , I could hear the noise of a window gently thrust up , and knew that my uncle had come to his observatory .

#Text=By what light there was , he would see Alan standing , like a dark shadow , on the steps ; the three witnesses were hidden quite out of his view ; so that there was nothing to alarm an honest man in his own house .
#Text=For all that , he studied his visitor awhile in silence , and when he spoke his voice had a quaver of misgiving .
#Text=What 's this ?
#Text=says he .
#Text=This is nae kind of time of night for decent folk ; and I hae nae wi'night-hawks .
#Text=What brings ye here ?
#Text=I have a blunderbush .
#Text=Dealings .
#Text=Is that yoursel ' , Mr. Balfour ?
#Text=returned Alan , stepping back and looking up into the darkness .
#Text=Have a care of that blunderbuss ; they 're nasty things to burst .
#Text=What brings ye here ?
#Text=and whae are ye ?
#Text=says my uncle , angrily .

#Text=I have no manner of inclination to rowt out my name to the country-side , said Alan ; but what brings me here is another story , being more of your affair than mine ; and if ye 're sure it 's what ye would like , I 'll set it to a tune and sing it to you .
#Text=And what is't ?
#Text=asked my uncle .
#Text=David , says Alan .
#Text=What was that ?
#Text=cried my uncle , in a mighty changed voice .
#Text=Shall I give ye the rest of the name , then ?
#Text=said Alan .
#Text=There was a pause ; and then , I 'm thinking I 'll better let ye in , says my uncle , doubtfully .
#Text=I dare say that , said Alan ; but the point is , Would I go ?
#Text=Now I will tell you what I am thinking .

#Text=I am thinking that it is here upon this doorstep that we must confer upon this business ; and it shall be here or nowhere at all whatever ; for I would have you to understand that I am as stiffnecked as yoursel ' , and a gentleman of better family .
#Text=This change of note disconcerted Ebenezer ; he was a little while digesting it , and then says he , Weel , weel , what must be must , and shut the window .

#Text=But it took him a long time to get down-stairs , and a still longer to undo the fastenings , repenting ( I dare say ) and taken with fresh claps of fear at every second step and every bolt and bar .

#Text=At last , however , we heard the creak of the hinges , and it seems my uncle slipped gingerly out and ( seeing that Alan had stepped back a pace or two ) sate him down on the top doorstep with the blunderbuss ready in his hands .
#Text=And , now says he , mind I have my blunderbush , and if ye take a step nearer ye 're as good as deid .
#Text=And a very civil speech , says Alan , to be sure .
#Text=Na , says my uncle , but this is no a very chanty kind of a proceeding , and I 'm bound to be prepared .
#Text=And now that we understand each other , ye 'll can name your business .
#Text=Why , says Alan , you that are a man of so much understanding , will both without lace .
#Text=These he threw on any way , and taking a staff from the cupboard , locked all up again , and was for setting out , when a thought arrested him .
#Text=I cannae leave you by yoursel'in the house , said he .
#Text=I 'll have to lock you out .
#Text=The blood came to my face .
#Text=If you lock me out , I said , it 'll be the last you 'll see of me in friendship .
#Text=He turned very pale , and sucked his mouth in .
#Text=This is no the way , he said , looking wickedly at a corner of the floor--this is no the way to win my favour , David .
#Text=Sir , says I , with a proper reverence for your age and our common blood , I do not value your favour at a boddle 's purchase .
#Text=I was brought up to have a good conceit of myself ; and if you were all the uncle , and all the family , I had in the world ten times over , I would n't buy your liking at such prices .
#Text=Uncle Ebenezer went and looked out of the window for awhile .
#Text=I could see him all trembling and twitching , like a man with palsy .
#Text=But when he turned round , he had a smile upon his face .
#Text=Well , well , said he , we must bear and forbear .
#Text=I 'll no go ; that 's all that 's to be said of it .
#Text=Uncle Ebenezer , I said , I can make nothing out of this .

#Text=You use me like a thief ; you hate to have me in this house ; you let me see it , every word and every minute : it 's not possible that you can like me ; and as for me , I 've spoken to you as I never thought to speak to any man .
#Text=Why do you seek to keep me , then ?
#Text=Let me gang back--let me gang back to the friends I have , and that like me !
#Text=Na , na ; na , na , he said , very earnestly .
#Text=I like you fine ; we 'll agree fine yet ; and for the honour of the house I couldnae let you leave the way ye came .
#Text=Bide here quiet , there 's a good lad ; just you bide here quiet a bittie , and ye 'll find that we agree .
#Text=Well , sir , said I , after I had thought the matter out in silence , I 'll stay awhile .
#Text=It 's more just I should be helped by my own blood than strangers ; and if we do n't agree , I 'll do my best it shall be through no fault of mine .
#Text=CHAPTER IV I RUN A GREAT DANGER IN THE HOUSE OF SHAWS For a day that was begun so ill , the day passed fairly well .
#Text=We had the porridge cold again at noon , and hot porridge at night ; porridge and small beer was my uncle 's diet .
#Text=He spoke but little , and that in the same way as before , shooting a question at me after a long silence ; and when I sought to lead him to talk about my future , slipped out of it again .
#Text=In a room next door to the kitchen , where he suffered me to go , I found a great number of books , both Latin and English , in which I took great pleasure all the afternoon .

#Text=Indeed , the time passed so lightly in this good company , that I began to be almost reconciled to my residence at Shaws ; and nothing but the sight of my uncle , and his eyes playing hide and seek with mine , revived the force of my distrust .
#Text=One thing I discovered , which put me in some doubt .
#Text=This was an entry on the fly-leaf of a chap-book ( one of Patrick Walker 's ) plainly written by my father 's hand and thus conceived : To my brother Ebenezer on his fifth birthday .

#Text=Now , what puzzled me was this : That , as my father was of course the younger brother , he must either have made some strange error , or he must have written , before he was yet five , an excellent , clear manly hand of writing .

#Text=I tried to get this out of my head ; but though I took down many interesting authors , old and new , history , poetry , and story-book , this notion of my father 's hand of writing stuck to me ; and when at length I went back into the kitchen , and sat down once more to porridge and small beer , the first thing I said to Uncle Ebenezer was to ask him if my father had not been very quick at his book .
#Text=Alexander ?
#Text=No him !
#Text=was the reply .
#Text=I was far quicker mysel ' ; I was a clever chappie when I was young .
#Text=Why , I could read as soon as he could .
#Text=This puzzled me yet more ; and a thought coming into my head , I asked if he and my father had been twins .
#Text=He jumped upon his stool , and the horn spoon fell out of his hand upon the floor .
#Text=What gars ye ask that ?

#Text=he said , and he caught me by the breast of the jacket , and looked this time straight into my eyes : his own were little and light , and bright like a bird 's , blinking and winking strangely .
#Text=What do you mean ?
#Text=I asked , very calmly , for I was far stronger than he , and not easily frightened .
#Text=Take your hand from my jacket .
#Text=This is no way to behave .
#Text=My uncle seemed to make a great effort upon himself .
#Text=Dod man , David , he said , ye should-nae speak to me about your father .
#Text=That 's where the mistake is .

#Text=He sat awhile and shook , blinking in his plate : He was all the brother that ever I had , he added , but with no heart in his voice ; and then he caught up his spoon and fell to supper again , but still shaking .
#Text=Now this last passage , this laying of hands upon my person and sudden profession of love for my dead father , went so clean beyond my comprehension that it put me into both fear and hope .
#Text=On the one hand , I began to think my uncle was perhaps insane and might be dangerous ; doubtless have perceived that I am a Hieland gentleman .
#Text=My name has nae business in my story ; but the county of my friends is no very far from the Isle of Mull , of which ye will have heard .
#Text=It seems there was a ship lost in those parts ; and the next day a gentleman of my family was seeking wreck-wood for his fire along the sands , when he came upon a lad that was half drowned .
#Text=Well , he brought him to ; and he and some other gentleman took and clapped him in an auld , ruined castle , where from that day to this he has been a great expense to my friends .

#Text=My friends are a wee wild-like , and not so particular about the law as some that I could name ; and finding that the lad owned some decent folk , and was your born nephew , Mr. Balfour , they asked me to give ye a bit call and confer upon the matter .
#Text=And I may tell ye at the off-go , unless we can agree upon some terms , ye are little likely to set eyes upon him .
#Text=For my friends , added Alan , simply , are no very well off .
#Text=My uncle cleared his throat .
#Text=I 'm no very caring , says he .
#Text=He wasnae a good lad at the best of it , and I 've nae call to interfere .
#Text=Ay , ay , said Alan , I see what ye would be at : pretending ye do n't care , to make the ransom smaller .
#Text=Na , said my uncle , it 's the mere truth .
#Text=I take nae manner of interest in the lad , and I 'll pay nae ransome , and ye can make a kirk and a mill of him for what I care .
#Text=Hoot , sir , says Alan .
#Text=Blood 's thicker than water , in the deil 's name !
#Text=Ye cannae desert your brother 's son for the fair shame of it ; and if ye did , and it came to be kennt , ye wouldnae be very popular in your country-side , or I 'm the more deceived .
#Text=I 'm no just very popular the way it is , returned Ebenezer ; and I dinnae see how it would come to be kennt .
#Text=No by me , onyway ; nor yet by you or your friends .
#Text=So that 's idle talk , my buckie , says he .
#Text=Then it 'll have to be David that tells it , said Alan .
#Text=How that ?
#Text=says my uncle , sharply .
#Text=Ou , just this way , says Alan .

#Text=My friends would doubtless keep your nephew as long as there was any likelihood of siller to be made of it , but if there was nane , I am clearly of opinion they would let him gang where he pleased , and be damned to him !
#Text=Ay , but I 'm no very caring about that either , said my uncle .
#Text=I wouldnae be muckle made up with that .
#Text=I was thinking that , said Alan .
#Text=And what for why ?
#Text=asked Ebenezer .

#Text=Why , Mr. Balfour , replied Alan , by all that I could hear , there were two ways of it : either ye liked David and would pay to get him back ; or else ye had very good reasons for not wanting him , and would pay for us to keep him .
#Text=It seems it 's not the first ; well then , it 's the second ; and blythe am I to ken it , for it should be a pretty penny in my pocket and the pockets of my friends .
#Text=I dinnae follow ye there , said my uncle .
#Text=No ?
#Text=said Alan .
#Text=Well , see here : you dinnae want the lad back ; well , what do ye want done with him , and how much will ye pay ?
#Text=My uncle made no answer , but shifted uneasily on his seat .
#Text=Come , sir , cried Alan .
#Text=I would have you to ken that I am a gentleman ; I bear a king 's name ; I am nae rider to kick my shanks at your hall door .
#Text=Either give me an answer in civility , and that out of hand ; or by the top of Glencoe , I will ram three feet of iron through your vitals .
#Text=Eh , man , cried my uncle , scrambling to his feet , give me a meenit !
#Text=What 's like wrong with ye ?
#Text=I 'm just a plain man and nae dancing master ; and I 'm tryin to be as ceevil as it 's morally possible .
#Text=As for that wild talk , it 's fair disrepitable .
#Text=Vitals , says you !
#Text=And where would I be with my blunderbush ?
#Text=he snarled .
#Text=Powder and your auld hands are but as the snail to the swallow against the bright steel in the hands of Alan , said the other .
#Text=Before your jottering finger could find the trigger , the hilt would dirl on your breast-bane .
#Text=Eh , man , whae 's denying it ?
#Text=said my uncle .
#Text=Pit it as ye please , hae't your ain way ; I 'll do naething to cross ye .
#Text=Just tell me what like ye 'll be wanting , and ye 'll see that we 'll can agree fine .
#Text=Troth , sir , said Alan , I ask for nothing but plain dealing .
#Text=In two words : do ye want the lad killed or kept ?
#Text=O , sirs !
#Text=cried Ebenezer .
#Text=O , sirs , me !
#Text=that 's no kind of language !
#Text=Killed or kept !
#Text=repeated Alan .
#Text=O , keepit , keepit !
#Text=wailed my uncle .
#Text=We 'll have nae bloodshed , if you please .
#Text=Well , says Alan , as ye please ; that 'll be the dearer .
#Text=The dearer ?
#Text=cries Ebenezer .
#Text=Would ye fyle your hands wi'crime ?
#Text=Hoot !
#Text=said Alan , they 're baith crime , whatever !
#Text=And the killing 's easier , and quicker , and surer .
#Text=Keeping the lad 'll be a job , a fashious , kittle business .
#Text=Troublesome .
#Text=I 'll have him keepit , though , returned my uncle .
#Text=I never had naething to do with onything morally wrong ; and I 'm no gaun to begin to pleasure a wild Hielandman .
#Text=Ye 're unco scrupulous , sneered Alan .
#Text=I 'm a man o'principle , said Ebenezer , simply ; and if I have to pay for it , I 'll have to pay for it .
#Text=And besides , says he , ye forget the lad 's my brother 's son .
#Text=Well , well , said Alan , and now about the price .
#Text=It 's no very easy for me to set a name upon it ; I would first have to ken some small matters .
#Text=I would have to ken , for instance , what ye gave Hoseason at the first off-go ?
#Text=Hoseason !
#Text=cries my uncle , struck aback .
#Text=What for ?
#Text=For kidnapping David , says Alan .
#Text=It 's a lee , it 's a black lee !
#Text=cried my uncle .
#Text=He was never kidnapped .
#Text=He leed in his throat that tauld ye that .
#Text=Kidnapped ?
#Text=He never was !
#Text=That 's no fault of mine nor yet of yours , said Alan ; nor yet of Hoseason 's , if he 's a man that can be trusted .
#Text=What do ye mean ?
#Text=cried Ebenezer .
#Text=Did Hoseason tell ye ?
#Text=Why , ye donnered auld runt , how else would I ken ?
#Text=cried Alan .
#Text=Hoseason and me are partners ; we gang shares ; so ye can see for yoursel'what good ye can do leeing .
#Text=And I must plainly say ye drove a fool 's bargain when ye let a man like the sailor-man so far forward in your private matters .
#Text=But that 's past praying for ; and ye must lie on your bed the way ye made it .
#Text=And the point in hand is just this : what did ye pay him ?
#Text=Has he tauld ye himsel ' ?
#Text=asked my uncle .
#Text=That 's my concern , said Alan .
#Text=Weel , said my uncle , I dinnae care what he said , he leed , and the solemn God 's truth is this , that I gave him twenty pound .
#Text=But I 'll be perfec'ly honest with ye : forby that , he was to have the selling of the lad in Caroliny , whilk would be as muckle mair , but no from my pocket , ye see .
#Text=Thank you , Mr. Thomson .
#Text=That will do excellently well , said the lawyer , stepping forward ; and then mighty civilly , Good-evening , Mr. Balfour , said he .
#Text=And , Good-evening , Uncle Ebenezer , said I. And , It 's a braw nicht , Mr. Balfour , added Torrance .
#Text=Never a word said my uncle , neither black nor white ; but just sat where he was on the top door-step and stared upon us like a man turned to stone .

#Text=Alan filched away his blunderbuss ; and the lawyer , taking him by the arm , plucked him up from the doorstep , led him into the kitchen , whither we all followed , and set him down in a chair beside the hearth , where the fire was out and only a rush-light burning .
#Text=There we all looked upon him for a while , exulting greatly in our success , but yet with a sort of pity for the man 's shame .
#Text=Come , come , Mr. Ebenezer , said the lawyer , you must not be down-hearted , for I promise you we shall make easy terms .
#Text=In the meanwhile give us the cellar key , and Torrance shall draw us a bottle of your father 's wine in honour of the event .
#Text=Then , turning to me and taking me by the hand , Mr. David , says he , I wish you all joy in your good fortune , which I believe to be deserved .
#Text=And then to Alan , with a spice of drollery , Mr. Thomson , I pay you my compliment ; it was most artfully conducted ; but in one point you somewhat outran my comprehension .
#Text=Do I understand your name to be James ?
#Text=or Charles ?
#Text=or is it George , perhaps ?
#Text=And why should it be any of the three , sir ?
#Text=quoth Alan , drawing himself up , like one who smelt an offence .

#Text=Only , sir , that you mentioned a king 's name , replied Rankeillor ; and as there has never yet been a King Thomson , or his fame at least has never come my way , I judged you must refer to that you had in baptism .
#Text=This was just the stab that Alan would feel keenest , and I am free to confess he took it very ill .

#Text=Not a word would he answer , but stepped off to the far end of the kitchen , and sat down and sulked ; and it was not till I stepped after him , and gave him my hand , and thanked him by title as the chief spring of my success , that he began to smile a bit , and was at last prevailed upon to join our party .

#Text=By that time we had the fire lighted , and a bottle of wine uncorked ; a good supper came out of the basket , to which Torrance and I and Alan set ourselves down ; while the lawyer and my uncle passed into the next chamber to consult .
#Text=They stayed there closeted about an hour ; at the end of which period they had come to a good understanding , and my uncle and I set our hands to the agreement in a formal manner .
#Text=By the terms of this , my uncle bound himself to satisfy Rankeillor as to his intromissions , and to pay me two clear thirds of the yearly income of Shaws .
#Text=So the beggar in the ballad had come home ; and when I lay down that night on the kitchen chests , I was a man of means and had a name in the country .

#Text=Alan and Torrance and Rankeillor slept and snored on their hard beds ; but for me who had lain out under heaven and upon dirt and stones , so many days and nights , and often with an empty belly , and in fear of death , this good change in my case unmanned me more than any of the former evil ones ; and I lay till dawn , looking at the fire on the roof and planning the future .

#Text=CHAPTER XXX GOOD-BYE So far as I was concerned myself , I had come to port ; but I had still Alan , to whom I was so much beholden , on my hands ; and I felt besides a heavy charge in the matter of the murder and James of the Glens .

#Text=On both these heads I unbosomed to Rankeillor the next morning , walking to and fro about six of the clock before the house of Shaws , and with nothing in view but the fields and woods that had been my ancestors'and were now mine .
#Text=Even as I spoke on these grave subjects , my eye would take a glad bit of a run over the prospect , and my heart jump with pride .
#Text=About my clear duty to my friend , the lawyer had no doubt .
#Text=I must help him out of the county at whatever risk ; but in the case of James , he was of a different mind .
#Text=Mr. Thomson , says he , is one thing , Mr. Thomson 's kinsman quite another .
#Text=I know little of the facts , but I gather that a great noble ( whom we will call , if you like , the D. of has some concern and is even supposed to feel some animosity in the matter .
#Text=The D. of A. is doubtless an excellent nobleman ; but , Mr. David , timeo qui nocuere deos .
#Text=If you interfere to balk his vengeance , you should remember there is one way to shut your testimony out ; and that is to put you in the dock .
#Text=There , you would be in the same pickle as Mr. Thomson 's kinsman .
#Text=You will object that you are innocent ; well , but so is he .
#Text=And to be tried for your life before a Highland jury , on a Highland quarrel and with a Highland Judge upon the bench , would be a brief transition to the gallows .
#Text=The Duke of Argyle .
#Text=Now I had made all these reasonings before and found no very good reply to them ; so I put on all the simplicity I could .
#Text=In that case , sir , said I , I would just have to be hanged--would I not ?
#Text=My dear boy , cries he , go in God 's name , and do what you think is right .
#Text=It is a poor thought that at my time of life I should be advising you to choose the safe and shameful ; and I take it back with an apology .
#Text=Go and do your duty ; and be hanged , if you must , like a gentleman .
#Text=There are worse things in the world than to be hanged .
#Text=Not many , sir , said I , smiling .
#Text=Why , yes , sir , he cried , very many .
#Text=And it would be ten times better for your uncle ( to go no farther afield ) if he were dangling decently upon a gibbet .
#Text=Thereupon he turned into the house ( still in a great fervour of mind , so that I saw I had pleased him heartily ) and there he wrote me two letters , making his comments on them as he wrote .
#Text=This , says he , is to my bankers , the British Linen Company , placing a credit to your name .
#Text=Consult Mr. Thomson , he will know of ways ; and you , with this credit , can supply the means .
#Text=I trust you will be a good husband of your money ; but in the affair of a friend like Mr. Thomson , I would be even prodigal .

#Text=Then for his kinsman , there is no better way than that you should seek the Advocate , tell him your tale , and offer testimony ; whether he may take it or not , is quite another matter , and will turn on the D. of A. Now , that you may reach the Lord Advocate well recommended , I give you here a letter to a namesake of your own , the learned Mr. Balfour of Pilrig , a man whom I esteem .
#Text=It will look better that you should be presented by one of your own name ; and the laird of Pilrig is much looked up to in the Faculty and stands well with Lord Advocate Grant .
#Text=I would not trouble him , if I were you , with any particulars ; and ( do you know ?
#Text=) I think it would be needless to refer to Mr. Thomson .
#Text=Form yourself upon the laird , he is a good model ; when you deal with the Advocate , be discreet ; and in all these matters , may the Lord guide you , Mr. David !
#Text=Thereupon he took his farewell , and set out with Torrance for the Ferry , while Alan and I turned our faces for the city of Edinburgh .
#Text=As we went by the footpath and beside the gateposts and the unfinished lodge , we kept looking back at the house of my fathers .

#Text=It stood there , bare and great and smokeless , like a place not lived in ; only in one of the top windows , there was the peak of a nightcap bobbing up and down and back and forward , like the head of a rabbit from a burrow .
#Text=I had little welcome when I came , and less kindness while I stayed ; but at least I was watched as I went away .
#Text=Alan and I went slowly forward upon our way , having little heart either to walk or speak .
#Text=The same thought was uppermost in both , that we were near the time of our parting ; and remembrance of all the bygone days sate upon us sorely .

#Text=We talked indeed of what should be done ; and it was resolved that Alan should keep to the county , biding now here , now there , but coming once in the day to a particular place where I might be able to communicate with him , either in my own person or by messenger .

#Text=In the meanwhile , I was to seek out a lawyer , who was an Appin Stewart , and a man therefore to be wholly trusted ; and it should be his part to find a ship and to arrange for Alan 's safe embarkation .

#Text=No sooner was this business done , than the words seemed to leave us ; and though I would seek to jest with Alan under the name of Mr. Thomson , and he with me on my new clothes and my estate , you could feel very well that we were nearer tears than laughter .

#Text=We came the by-way over the hill of Corstorphine ; and when we got near to the place called Rest-and-be-Thankful , and looked down on Corstorphine bogs and over to the city and the castle on the hill , we both stopped , for we both knew without a word said that we had come to where our ways parted .

#Text=Here he repeated to me once again what had been agreed upon between us : the address of the lawyer , the daily hour at which Alan might be found , and the signals that were to be made by any that came seeking him .
#Text=Then I gave what money I had ( a guinea or two of Rankeillor 's ) so that he should not starve in the meanwhile ; and then we stood a space , and looked over at Edinburgh in silence .
#Text=Well , good-bye , said Alan , and held out his left hand .
#Text=Good-bye , said I , and gave the hand a little grasp , and went off down hill .
#Text=Neither one of us looked the other in the face , nor so long as he was in my view did I take one back glance at the friend I was leaving .
#Text=But as I went on my way to the city , I felt so lost and lonesome , that I could have found it in my heart to sit down by the dyke , and cry and weep like any baby .
#Text=It was coming near noon when I passed in by the West Kirk and the Grassmarket into the streets of the capital .

#Text=The huge height of the buildings , running up to ten and fifteen storeys , the narrow arched entries that continually vomited passengers , the wares of the merchants in their windows , the hubbub and endless stir , the foul smells and the fine clothes , and a hundred other particulars too small to mention , struck me into a kind of stupor of surprise , so that I let the crowd carry me to and fro ; and yet all the time what I was thinking of was Alan at Rest-and-be-Thankful ; and all the time ( although you would think I would not choose but be delighted with these braws and novelties ) there was a cold gnawing in my inside like a remorse for something wrong .
#Text=The hand of Providence brought me in my drifting to the very doors of the British Linen Company 's bank .

#Text=on the other , there came up into my mind ( quite unbidden by me and even discouraged ) a story like some ballad I had heard folk singing , of a poor lad that was a rightful heir and a wicked kinsman that tried to keep him from his own .
#Text=For why should my uncle play a part with a relative that came , almost a beggar , to his door , unless in his heart he had some cause to fear him ?

#Text=With this notion , all unacknowledged , but nevertheless getting firmly settled in my head , I now began to imitate his covert looks ; so that we sat at table like a cat and a mouse , each stealthily observing the other .

#Text=Not another word had he to say to me , black or white , but was busy turning something secretly over in his mind ; and the longer we sat and the more I looked at him , the more certain I became that the something was unfriendly to myself .
#Text=When he had cleared the platter , he got out a single pipeful of tobacco , just as in the morning , turned round a stool into the chimney corner , and sat awhile smoking , with his back to me .
#Text=Davie , he said , at length , I 've been thinking ; then he paused , and said it again .
#Text=There 's a wee bit siller that I half promised ye before ye were born , he continued ; promised it to your father .
#Text=O , naething legal , ye understand ; just gentlemen daffing at their wine .

#Text=Well , I keepit that bit money separate--it was a great expense , but a promise is a promise--and it has grown by now to be a matter of just precisely--just exactly--and here he paused and stumbled--of just exactly forty pounds !
#Text=This last he rapped out with a sidelong glance over his shoulder ; and the next moment added , almost with a scream , Scots !

#Text=The pound Scots being the same thing as an English shilling , the difference made by this second thought was considerable ; I could see , besides , that the whole story was a lie , invented with some end which it puzzled me to guess ; and I made no attempt to conceal the tone of raillery in which I answered -- O , think again , sir !
#Text=Pounds sterling , I believe !
#Text=That 's what I said , returned my uncle : pounds sterling !
#Text=And if you 'll step out-by to the door a minute , just to see what kind of a night it is , I 'll get it out to ye and call ye in again .
#Text=I did his will , smiling to myself in my contempt that he should think I was so easily to be deceived .
#Text=It was a dark night , with a few stars low down ; and as I stood just outside the door , I heard a hollow moaning of wind far off among the hills .
#Text=I said to myself there was something thundery and changeful in the weather , and little knew of what a vast importance that should prove to me before the evening passed .

#Text=When I was called in again , my uncle counted out into my hand seven and thirty golden guinea pieces ; the rest was in his hand , in small gold and silver ; but his heart failed him there , and he crammed the change into his pocket .
#Text=There , said he , that 'll show you !
#Text=I 'm a queer man , and strange wi ' strangers ; but my word is my bond , and there 's the proof of it .
#Text=Now , my uncle seemed so miserly that I was struck dumb by this sudden generosity , and could find no words in which to thank him .
#Text=No a word !
#Text=said he .
#Text=Nae thanks ; I want nae thanks .
#Text=I do my duty .

#Text=I 'm no saying that everybody would have done it ; but for my part ( though I 'm a careful body , too ) it 's a pleasure to me to do the right by my brother 's son ; and it 's a pleasure to me to think that now we 'll agree as such near friends should .

#Text=I spoke him in return as handsomely as I was able ; but all the while I was wondering what would come next , and why he had parted with his precious guineas ; for as to the reason he had given , a baby would have refused it .
#Text=Presently he looked towards me sideways .
#Text=And see here , says he , tit for tat .
#Text=I told him I was ready to prove my gratitude in any reasonable degree , and then waited , looking for some monstrous demand .

#Text=And yet , when at last he plucked up courage to speak , it was only to tell me ( very properly , as I thought ) that he was growing old and a little broken , and that he would expect me to help him with the house and the bit garden .
#Text=I answered , and expressed my readiness to serve .
#Text=Well , he said , let 's begin .
#Text=He pulled out of his pocket a rusty key .
#Text=There , says he , there 's the key of the stair-tower at the far end of the house .
#Text=Ye can only win into it from the outside , for that part of the house is no finished .
#Text=Gang ye in there , and up the stairs , and bring me down the chest that 's at the top .
#Text=There 's papers i n't , he added .
#Text=Can I have a light , sir ?
#Text=said I. Na , said he , very cunningly .
#Text=Nae lights in my house .
#Text=Very well , sir , said I. Are the stairs good ?
#Text=They 're grand , said he ; and then , as I was going , Keep to the wall , he added ; there 's nae bannisters .
#Text=But the stairs are grand underfoot .
#Text=Out I went into the night .
#Text=The wind was still moaning in the distance , though never a breath of it came near the house of Shaws .
#Text=It had fallen blacker than ever ; and I was glad to feel along the wall , till I came the length of the stairtower door at the far end of the unfinished wing .
